PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I inform the Senate that the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) left Australia on 7 June to attend talks on trade and resource matters in Brazil and Argentina. The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) is Acting Minister for Trade and Resources until Mr Anthony returns on 25 June.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) left Australia on 6 June to attend talks with Lord Carrington in London, an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development ministerial meeting in Paris, a meeting of Foreign Ministers of the Association of South East Asian Nations in the Philippines and an ANZUS Council meeting in New Zealand. The Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) is Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs until Mr Street returns on 24 June.

I also inform the Senate that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) left Australia on 7 June to visit South East Asia and Europe on refugee and immigration matters. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is Acting Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs until Mr Macphee returns on 7 July. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) is representing the Attorney-General in the House in his capacity as Acting Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Deregulation of Trading Hours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: LAJOVIC

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 1,693 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: The Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That we wish to express our strongest opposition to any deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
2. That if trading hours are deregulated in the Australian Capital Territory, the present restrictions on trading hours in other parts of Australia may be lifted.

3. Past performances have proven that longer trading hours do not lead to increased sales. However, they do increase costs, because shops have to be staffed for longer periods. To cover these increased costs, retailers are forced to increase prices and reduce staff levels. This means that longer trading hours increase both prices and unemployment.
4. There is no real consumer demand for longer trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
5. The deregulation of trading hours would force small retail companies out of business.
6. Extended trading hours would gravely disrupt weekend recreation and family life of shop assistants.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Stop the deregulation of retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory, by disallowing the Ordinance which amends the Trading Hours Ordinance, 1962.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I draw the Minister's attention to reports that the Israeli Air Force has wiped out a nuclear plant in Iraq which was capable of building nuclear weapons. Can the Minister say which other countries in the Middle East have the capability of building nuclear weapons and which nations in Asia have this capability?

—I am not able to say that any country in the Middle East, including Iraq, has the capacity to build nuclear weapons, but I will follow that up and see whether there is any further information. The Government has been informed that on 7 June Israeli aircraft attacked the Iraqi nuclear research facility close to Baghdad. The Government, of course, can in no way condone the Israeli attack, which is a grave and serious development and which can only exacerbate tensions in a region where tensions are already critically high. The Government regrets military action of this kind, particularly at a time when every effort needs to be made to encourage actions which are designed to reduce tensions in the region. As to the substance of Senator Button's question concerning the capacity of the Iraqis to produce highly enriched uranium as a first step or to develop actual weapons or weapon systems, I have no specific information. I will seek information and let the honourable senator have what comes to hand.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission on the formula for the distribution among the States of tax reimbursement funds expected this week? In view of the obvious fact that if some States are to receive relatively more per capita others will have to receive less, is it realistic to believe that there is any possibility of the Premiers agreeing among themselves on the distribution formula? If agreement among the Premiers is not possible, will the Federal Government accept and implement the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission as it has invariably done in the 48-year history of the Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission on a review of relativities is to be forwarded to the Commonwealth and State governments in the early future. I believe it will be done this week. It is true, as Senator Hamer indicates, that any review of relativities is likely to create situations in which some States will have recommendations for gains and other States will have recommendations for losses, and that inevitably therefore only those States which have recommendations for gains will be in favour of the report. It is equally true that in the years since 1934, when the Commonwealth Grants Commission was established by a Liberal government of the day, the reports of the Commission have been received and adopted.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a very important report. The Premiers and the Commonwealth will put it under study and this will take some little time. I do not imagine that the report will receive other than preliminary discussion at the Premiers Conference which is scheduled for the immediate days ahead. I am unable to predict the outcome of such discussions, but it is true that when one looks to relativities it is inevitable that there will be pluses and minuses. The States themselves should accept that fact. The aim is to provide services in the various States throughout Australia of an average quality of those appertaining in Victoria and New South Wales. This has been the consideration in the past. I think the discussions will take place in the near future between the Commonwealth and the States. It will probably take a considerable time to digest the report itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister repre- senting the Minister for Communications noted newspaper reports to the effect that unions representing all staff employed by the Australian Broadcasting Commission have banded together to oppose Budget cuts foreshadowed by the Government? Is this the first time ever that the ABC Senior Officers Association, which represents the management of the ABC, has joined the other ABC unions in protest against cuts in government funding of the Commission? Does the Minister agree with last week's statement by John Norgard, the Chairman of the Commission, that if the proposed cuts are implemented 'the Commission will have no option but to cut programs and services to both radio and television'? In view of this unanimous opposition to the Government's moves, will the Minister undertake to reconsider the situation and to do everything in his power to preserve the independence and viability of our national broadcasting service?

—I begin my answer by asserting that neither the independence nor the viability of the ABC is at risk in any way. That is a very important point to make. Neither the independence nor the viability of the ABC is under threat in any way. What we are hearing-I am not saying that it is improper-is special interest pleading and the application of a little pressure. I do not know whether the facts as set out by Senator Chipp are correct-whether people have banded together and whether the newspaper reports are correct. I certainly do not know what the Budget situation of the ABC will be. As I have said on several occasions, that matter is still under negotiation and we do not intend to foreshadow any part of the Federal Budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. The Minister for Defence would be aware that notices to quit have been given to cottage owners on Garden Island, now better known as HMAS Stirling. Is the Minister aware that, apparently without reason, some cottage owners have been asked to quit by 30 June 1981 while others are being allowed to stay until September this year? Will the Minister give the reasons for the difference or, better still, will he make all the notices to quit uniform to September this year?

—I have some general knowledge in relation to this question of those remaining owners of cottages on Garden Island which has been developed as a naval facility known as HMAS Stirling. I certainly was aware that some owners had been given notices to quit, but I was not aware that those notices had varying dates. I will refer the question to the Minister for Defence and ask him to explain the reasons for this variation and to consider the proposal made by Senator Martyr.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications: Is it a fact that, as reported by Australian Associated Press today, Cabinet authorised the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, in the event of strong opposition from his own back bench or senators, to fall back to two positions on quite important provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill? Are these two fall-back positions, firstly, that the Government is prepared to leave undisturbed the present discretionary power of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with respect to public interest but to insert a clause saying that holding two metropolitan licences is not in itself against the public interest; and, secondly, that the Bill could provide for prior approval for all changes of share ownership in licensee companies?

—This question anticipates a debate about to occur in the Senate; so I am not certain that it is entirely in order. In any event, I have not read the AAP report to which the honourable senator referred and I do not choose to make any comment on the matters he has raised.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is it a fact that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has ceased to fund the activities of Applied Ecology Pty Ltd?
—And not before time.

—I thank the honourable senator. If this is the case, has the Government ceased to fund the company completely, or are the funds being supplied through another department? If this is the case, which department is making the payments and what amounts of money are being provided to the various projects?

—I was attracted immediately by Senator Georges's interjection. I observe to the Senate that, once Senator Cavanagh retires, the Senate can no longer be treated to the sight of Senators Cavanagh and Georges fighting round 11 of the turtle farm battle with which Applied Ecology Pty Ltd was concerned some years ago. It is a fact that one of the decisions in the Review of Commonwealth Functions was that Applied Ecology would no longer be funded, and it is intended that that funding should cease. There will be some minor provision for winding down operations, and Applied Ecology has at present been put on a winding down basis or a care and maintenance basis while the winding down takes place. No other Commonwealth or State department of which I am aware will be picking up the funding for Applied Ecology. I am not sure what final decisions eventually will be taken in relation to the two major projects-that is, the emu project at Wiluna and the crocodile project on Cape York, I think, on the Edward River. As I said, I am not quite sure what final decision will be taken, but we are at present investigating what is the appropriate course of action for these projects. I think the short answer to the honourable senator's question is that there will be no alternative source of government funding for Applied Ecology.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and it refers to the question of merchant seamen's eligibility for wider repatriation benefits. The Minister will be well aware of the claims by petitioners and organisations, including Mr Meredith, a merchant seaman of South Australia who served as a prisoner-of-war in Japan and whose ship was sunk by Japanese action. I ask the Minister: As we are in the concluding stages of the session, is he in a position to give the Senate any indication that the Government is seriously considering the extension of repatriation benefits to persons in that category and to ensuring that they may be eligible for service pensions?

—Yes, I am aware of the concerns in the community generally, and certainly I am aware of the petitions that have been lodged in this place in connection with merchant seamen. I think I have had a letter from just about every member of parliament in this regard. I think Senator Bishop would appreciate that it is a matter to be considered by the Government in the Budget context. Consequently, I am not in any position to indicate the intentions of the Government in that regard at this stage.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Education comment on the suggestion made by the Opposition spokesman on education that the concentration on vocational training by the Government will mean higher school fees and expenses?

—The Minister for Education announced, I think on 4 June, that the Commonwealth wishes to accelerate the development of transition courses in secondary schools and colleges of technical and further education relevant particularly to the needs of low-achieving students. In October 1979, the Commonwealth and the States agreed that concerted action should be taken. The Commonwealth undertook to provide a total of $150m-a very large sum-over five years from 1980 for the transition program and asked the States to match this expenditure from 1982 onwards. Because the States have not been prepared to match the Commonwealth expenditure, the Commonwealth has felt compelled to earmark up to $27m within Commonwealth general recurrent grants to the States for government schools in 1982. If the States increase their expenditure, this will be offset against the amount to be earmarked. There should be no need to increase any form of school fees for this reason, any more than for recent increases in teachers' salaries. The costs to the States of their contribution in 1982 in any event will represent something less than 2 per cent of total expenditure in government secondary schools. The program is a very important one and the results being achieved are very heartening.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and refers to the arrangements for low income earners to be considered disadvantaged in the new health arrangements. The Minister has informed me that the allowable income for a married couple will in fact be indexed to the unemployment benefit and will go up with the twice-yearly indexation of that benefit. I ask: What is the situation with a single person, in which case the unemployment benefit is not indexed and goes up only intermittently at the whim of the Government and, on past records, may go for two years or more without being increased? Will that cut-off point be fixed and not subject to indexation of any sort?

—Senator Grimes asked me a question about this matter some time ago. I indicated then that the total sum of $160 which is the present income limit for a married couple is not indexed but that component of it which is made up of the married rate unemployed benefit is, and therefore will be, adjusted twice yearly. The single person rate is set at 60 per cent of the married person rate and will move in that relationship with the married person rate.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: In view of the increasingly disastrous effects on the Tasmanian economy of each of the current rounds of maritime union strikes and the enormous damage being done to Tasmanian development and potential generally as a result, can he advise honourable senators whether the Prime Minister has received any request for action, suggestions or expressions of concern about the matter from the Tasmanian Premier or his Minister for Industrial Relations? If so, what suggestions were made or assistance requested? If not, what action does this Government propose taking to overcome the impossible, unacceptable and untenable situation which puts Tasmania at the mercy of those overpaid and underworked maritime unions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is extremely concerned about the effects of industrial disputes on the Tasmanian economy which is particularly vulnerable to air and sea transport disputes. The recent campaign of rolling strikes by maritime unions is especially harmful, coming so soon after a series of airline strikes, so Tasmania has had a very rough time. As I understand it, the maritime dispute is now back before the Commission. Recent disputes have arisen from the failure of the unions involved to avail themselves of arbitral mechanisms and one can only hope that the due processes will now result in a speedy resolution.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the Prime Minister has not received a letter from Mr Lowe on the subject of disputes in the maritime industry. It is up to the Tasmanian Government to approach the Australian Council of Trade Unions to seek for the State exemption from industrial action. It is a great hardship upon the Tasmanian people to be subjected to such hostage actions, wherein a handful of people hold a majority of people hostage in order to exact tribute.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask my question, which is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, mindful of the fact that he was a top organisation man in the Liberal Party in New South Wales. I ask: Is he aware that the President of the Liberal Party's Queensland Branch, and the executive of that Branch, were the architects of a move to refuse endorsement to Liberal Party members of parliament who did not vote for a redistribution of boundaries in Queensland, in accordance with Liberal Party branch proposals? How does the Leader of the Government in the Senate equate this with the oft-quoted contention that Liberal Party members of this Parliament are free agents and not in any way subject to outside administrative political pressures? Would he not agree that the claim of the late Sir Robert Menzies that the Labor Party was controlled by faceless men could more appropriately be applied to the Liberal Party executive in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would answer the last part of the honourable senator's question by saying that I would have thought that events in the various branches of the Labor Party in New South Wales had been exposing faceless men in very large numbers. As to the first part of his question-although I do not attempt to hit it to leg on this ground, it does not concern my ministerial responsibility-I am not aware of any statement or threat being made by the President of the Liberal Party in Queensland. However, I must say that no one could deliver any such threat because the preselection methods of the Liberal Party throughout Australia are in the hands of committees which vote by secret ballot and it is entirely up to responsible and mature people to vote in that ballot according to their conscience. As Senator John Martyr indicates, he is living proof of that. I am asked by Senator McAuliffe how I reconcile this with my comment that Liberal Party members in this and the other chamber are free agents and act according to conscience. I have noted the phenomenon that the Labor Party urges others to act according to conscience but itself acts according to its Caucus. I am strongly reminded of the words of Horatius at the bridge:

ANSWER.PARA: Was none who would be foremost
To lead such dire attack;
But those behind cried 'Forward'
And those before cried 'Back'.
The fact of the matter is that members of the Liberal Party and the National Country Party demonstrate their freedom of conscience. The Labor Party seeks it in virtue in others but not in itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. When the River Murray Waters Agreement of 1914 eventually is altered to provide the Commission with control over water quality in the River Murray will this extend to its tributaries? Is it a fact that the Commission will have the power only to make recommendations on this important question and that such proposals will be subject to veto by any one of the parties to the agreement? As the matter of water quantity and quality management transcends State borders and must be regarded as a subject of national consequence and as the establishment of a national water authority to deal with this meets with the tripartisan agreement of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, can the Minister say whether there are any means, other than by referendum, whereby the management of this vital resource can be placed with the national government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole question of the quantity and quality of water in the River Murray has, as indicated by the number of questions asked in the Senate, been of major importance and will continue to be so. The proposed new River Murray Waters Agreement will enable the River Murray Commission to take account of water quality in its operations and studies. These apply only to the main stem of the river, the tributaries above Albury and the Darling River below the Menindee Lakes. They do not apply to other tributaries. However, it will also be empowered to make representations to the States on all matters which affect the quality of water under its control or supervision subject to unanimous decisions within the River Murray Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that those from the various States and indeed the Commonwealth who have studied this new Agreement believe that it will be a considerable advance in the management of this great resource. Control of the River Murray system could, of course, be placed with the national government if the States were to cede to it the necessary powers. That, in itself, is unlikely. I believe that with good will and co-operation under a federal system we can achieve suitable control.

I am reminded that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in its 1978 report on the role of the Commonwealth in water matters decided against a central fresh water research institute because of the wide range of tasks of development, the diverse range of water and related problems-climate and topography-and the great distances involved. It doubted that a central water research authority could meet the specific needs of a particular region or State. On that basis, it is generally believed that with good will and co-operation the results can be achieved best, as indeed they have, within the federalist system. They could of course have been achieved and written under a former Labor government but this was not done.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. When the member for Albert Park in the South Australian Parliament, Mr Kevin Hamilton, sent out pamphlets to his electorate advising people of their entitlements with regard to pensions and unemployment and other benefits, he had over 60 calls in the first week from people who were not aware that they were eligible for benefits. Is this due to a deliberate lack of dissemination of information about social service benefits on the part of the Government? Instead of spending large sums in advertising its opposition to the 35-hour working week campaign, would the Government not serve the people better by placing advertisements with regard to available pension, unemployment and sickness benefits? Will the Minister seriously consider publishing such information in all the daily newspapers in Australia, preferably in several languages?

—The Department of Social Security does have an information program which includes some limited advertising in the media. That program is aimed at ensuring that members of the public are aware of their entitlements. I think all honourable senators receive copies of the pamphlets which are issued and regularly updated by the Department. Indeed, we have made some effort to ensure that those updated pamphlets are available at the time changes are made to benefits so that people are fully aware of their entitlements. The Government does take seriously its obligation to ensure that people are aware of their entitlements with regard to benefits. I think most honourable senators are aware that there has been an extensive decentralisation of the Department under this Government. Scattered around Australia there are now more than 160 offices which are readily accessible to most pensioners and beneficiaries. I think most honourable senators are aware that the Department employs social workers who have the important role of ensuring that people who have difficulty in coming to grips with the social security system receive assistance. I will examine the matter that the honourable senator raised. If particular examples of non-availability of information are drawn to my attention, we will do our best to cover them. I would welcome hearing from Mr Hamilton on the particular case so that I can examine what further measures might be necessary.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer but it also may relate to the Minister for Social Security. It concerns the National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry, the Hancock Committee, which I believe reported to the Government some four years ago. Nearly two years ago the Treasurer announced the appointment of an interdepartmental task force to consider occupational superannuation plans and their integration with government benefits, together with the recommendation of the Hancock Committee. Has the task force completed its report and when will that report be available to honourable senators?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not sure whether that task force has reported yet. I will refer the matter to the Treasurer, subject to anything that Senator Chaney might wish to add.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, follows a question asked of him by Senator Jessop. Is the Minister aware that a national water resources convention is being convened at Bourke in New South Wales on 8 July next to propose the appointment of a national water resources association? Is the Minister also aware that the aims of the proposed association, amongst others, are to ask the Federal Government to plan an in-depth, multi-purpose engineering study of the Clarence and Mitchell rivers in New South Wales and Queensland for effective water resource and use purposes? Has the Minister noted that a private member's Bill has been introduced into the House of Representatives by the Labor member for Hawker seeking the establishment of an institute of fresh water studies to carry out the type of work envisaged by the proposed national water resources association? Will the Minister be prepared to study Mr Jacobi's proposal as outlined in the Bill and also, as the responsible Minister, to urge the Government to bring the matter forward for both debate and determination in the next parliamentary session?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the proposal to hold a convention in Bourke on 8 July. Indeed, I was privileged to have discussions some weeks ago in this building with delegates who are planning that convention. I am aware that one of their aims is to propose that there should be an in-depth study which would aim basically to turn the Clarence water system back inland. Both Mr Anthony and I discussed two main matters with the delegation: Firstly, the very great importance of getting the River Murray Waters Agreement into position as quickly as possible; and, secondly, the fact that the New South Wales Government has undertaken, in association with the Federal Government, a study of the northern rivers of New South Wales. The Federal Government has been urging the expedition of the study. We have pointed out to these delegates that, before any kind of study can be made in further depth, it is necessary to find the material that will come forward from the New South Wales Government. We are looking forward to that. I point out without attempting in any way to deprecate the situation-and Senator Douglas McClelland will understand it-that not only would the deviation of the Clarence River through the mountain range be extremely costly, being measured in some billions of dollars, but also is the likelihood of that water managing to go the 2,500 mile journey very remote because of evaporation and also because, no doubt, of riparian rights along the river. So there is an enormous amount to be done in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of Mr Jacobi's proposed private member's Bill in another place with regard to the aim of a central fresh water institute. I repeat part of an answer that I gave a moment ago, that is, that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in its 1978 report on the role of the Commonwealth in water matters decided against a central fresh water research institute because of the wide range of tasks of development, the diverse range of water and related problems-climate and topography-and the great distances involved. It doubted that a central water research authority could meet the specific needs of a particular region or State. It is open to question, therefore, whether the institute proposed by Mr Jacobi would add in any way to the basis for solutions to the River Murray problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Social Security. I have been prompted to ask my question by a letter appearing in today's Australian in which the correspondent takes up a matter which I, amongst others, have drawn to the attention of the Minister and his predecessor on several occasions. It relates to the reciprocity of overseas payment of pensions. Is the Minister able to say how much the Australian Government pays overseas by way of pensions to people living overseas and how much is received into Australia on the reciprocal basis? As pensions are taxable in Australia, will the Minister consider taxing any pensions that are sent overseas at least at the base tax rate so that, if people are working and living in another country, they are not better off than Australian pensioners? Finally, is this whole matter of reciprocity of pensions being examined?

—To answer the last part of the honourable senator's question first, the answer is yes, the matter is being considered. In fact, as I think a number of honourable senators with an interest in the subject would know, there has been a number of discussions between Ministers and officials of this Government and Ministers and officials of foreign governments with a concern about this matter. The matter is still no more than at the point of consideration and I am not in a position really to report progress on it to the Senate. With respect to how much is paid overseas, I have seen those figures but rather than guess I will obtain an accurate figure for the honourable senator. I am not sure that I would be able to give an accurate figure with respect to the amounts which are paid in this country. I will make inquiries and find out. As to whether people who are receiving pensions from the Commonwealth Government are better off in or out of Australia, there are some areas in which a pensioner going overseas is worse off because he or she loses certain entitlements which he or she would receive here-fringe benefits and so on-and which are regarded by pensioners as being of considerable value. I will also examine the taxation point which the honourable senator has raised and let him have a more authoritative reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. The Melbourne Age of 5 June carried an item stating that Energy Resources of Australia had signed a contract to sell 1,429 tonnes of uranium to a private Belgian company, Synatom. When did Australia sign a safeguards agreement with Belgium? What guarantees has this Government that this material will not be used to produce weapons grade uranium-plutonium-or will not be sold to other people who are not a party to any safeguards agreement?

—It is not possible for contracts on uranium between Australia and other countries to be carried out unless the other countries are members of the non-proliferation treaty. I do not know the details of the date and arrangements with Belgium. I will find out and let the honourable senator know.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to the general aviation study carried out recently by the Department of Transport and its recommendations in regard to cost recovery for the general aviation sector. Will the Government arrange for a critical examination of the report rather than accept the recommendations at face value? In doing so, will the Government ensure that such items as movement charges do not prove to be the deathknell of flying training and of small commuter and private flying operations, and therefore recognise that these aircraft operations are the lifeblood of the people of the outback? Further, before any recommendations of the study are introduced, will the Minister ensure that the cost structure of the Department of Transport is reviewed so that it is not forced to level any unnecessary expenses and costs at the industry, which is also having its difficulties?

—As I think most honourable senators would know, the whole area of general aviation policy is up for review. Certainly, as Mr Hunt has pointed out on other occasions in the House of Representatives and in public generally, the date by which the report has to be completed is to be extended until 30 June to enable the general aviation industry to report formally to the Government on the recommendations contained in that study. I believe that the matters which Senator Kilgariff has brought to the attention of the Senate today are of very real concern to the people of the outback-certainly the Northern Territory-and, indeed, to the people of most States of Australia. Consequently, as I understand the Minister's intentions in this regard, he will be taking such factors as Senator Kilgariff has mentioned into account during the final determinations. Nevertheless, I will refer the detailed matters which he has put forward in his question to the Minister and obtain an early reply.

—Is the Attorney-General aware that the book by Jim Spigelman called Secrecy: Political Censorship in Australia, which essentially began the freedom of information debate in this country when it was published in 1972, contained an appendix labelled 'An Inside Dopester's Index of 100 Examples of Secrecy'? Is the Attorney-General aware that six months ago last week-on 5 December 1980-I placed on notice 20 questions to 20 different departments, including his own, seeking information as to whether any of those 100 documents in the Spigelman list had been published or made available in the ensuing nine years? Is he aware that now, six months later, 11 of the 20 departments in question, including the Attorney-General's Department-his own Department-and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Defence and the Department of the Treasury have still not replied, that 64 of the 100 documents are still as a result unaccounted for and that, of the 36 documents in respect of which some information has been given, only 15 have been released in those nine years, seven are still secret and there are another 14 in respect of which the department says that it does not know what Spigelman is talking about? I ask the Attorney-General: Is this a fair demonstration of the Government's and the bureaucracy's present commitment to freedom of information principles? Will the result be likely to be any different if and when the Freeedom of Information Bill is ever enacted? When will the Senate be put in the position of being able to debate further-if so, when and for how long-the inadequacies in the present Bill?

—Senator Evans has a great penchant for arithmetic of a simple kind in relation to freedom of information matters. I am indebted to him for his latest calculations. I hope that they prove to be more accurate than some of those that he made in a recent debate here on the subject. I cannot comment on those sorts of details. I am aware of some of the questions that he has asked in relation to this matter. I am concerned that he has not had an answer in respect of all of them. As far as the matters that are addressed to me are concerned, I will certainly seek to hasten an answer. As to the other Ministers concerned, of course it will be a matter for them to deal with the questions addressed to them. Generally I will have a look at the matters that he has raised to see whether we can get more speedy answers to the questions.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I did ask the Attorney about the prospects of debating the Bill this week.
—The Bill will be listed for consideration before the end of the session.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the government enforced monopoly given to the Australian shipping industry in the Australian coastal trade. Is it a fact that one result of this control has been to increase costs and inefficiencies to the extent that the cost of transporting one tonne of steel from Port Kembla to Fremantle is now 44 per cent higher than the cost of shipping that tonne of steel from Japan to Fremantle? In the light of the Government's current deregulation philosophy, is the Minister considering any inquiry into this industry and the protection given to it?

—I am unable to say whether the points which Senator Lewis has made in his question are, in fact, correct, but I will undertake to make some inquiries of the Minister and bring the honourable senator an early reply.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security a question. In view of the fact that it is the policy of the Government, as announced in the Budget Speech of last August, to grant rail concessions to people on sickness benefits and in view of the fact that the Australian railways, supported by the Minister for Transport, will not carry out Government policy, will the Minister pay an amount to those sickness beneficiaries who have been denied this concession, to compensate them for the additional fares they have paid as a result of the Department of Transport's refusal to carry out Government policy?

—I have seen a report on this matter. I understand that administrative difficulties are in the way of the railways meeting the request or the instruction of the Government. It is a matter on which I have an imperfect recollection and I will seek further information and let the honourable senator have a longer reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Is the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs monitoring the import of textiles and textile goods from New Zealand? If so, is the Department aware of certain dumping practices, especially in the woollen worsted yarn area? I cite the case of twofold 22s worsted, which has a domestic price in New Zealand of $14.97 and which sells in Australia for $10.40, plus or minus 30c. The same Australian produced yarn sells for $12.40. Is the Minister aware that imports of worsteds, excluding handknits and woollens other than handknits, and carpet yarns, rose from 170,495 kilos in 1979 to 359,435 in 1980? I ask: What effect is this having on the local industry? Will the Minister take this into account when negotiating the free trade deal with New Zealand?

—I think most honourable senators would be aware of Senator Watson's very keen interest in matters of protection concerning Australian industry. Unfortunately, I am not able to indicate to him whether the details outlined in the question are correct. I will check them with the Minister and bring forward a reply for the honourable senator.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It arises from information provided by Dr Bruno Kalnins, the Chairman of the Latvian Social Democratic Workers Party in exile, a party associated with the Socialist International. According to this information, a Mr Juris Bumeisters, a 63-year-old electrical engineer in Riga who, despite the illegality of the Social Democratic Party in all parts of the Soviet Union, has been recognised as the leader of the social democratic movement in that country and has a long association with the labour movement-his father having been a Social Democrat member of the Latvian Parliament elected at the last free elections held in Latvia-was taken into custody in November last by the state security committee, the KGB, and has been subjected to constant interrogation thereafter. On 25 May the Supreme Court of the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic instituted a prosecution against him on the ground of treason against the fatherland. It would appear from the information that the sole basis of the allegation of treason consists of his activities on behalf of the social democratic movement in Latvia. Will the Minister ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs to confirm this information, showing as it does the inherent hostility of the Soviet system to independent labour parties? If the information is verified, as I believe it will be, will the Australian Government make appropriate representations to the Soviet Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer this matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, seeking whatever information is available. I will also seek the Minister's reaction to our making representations on this matter. I will see whether I can get an answer before the Senate rises.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. The report of the Bureau of Transport Economics on the land bridge concept as a means of equating Tasmania's transport needs as a consequence of its isolated position raises the question of freight equalisation payments on goods transported by air and currently not covered by the scheme. In view of the increasing necessity for shippers of goods to use air transport, because of maritime strikes, when orders have to be filled to keep faith with customers and to replenish supplies of essential stores and materials, will the Minister give consideration to allowing equivalent equalisation payments under circumstances when ships on which equalisation payments would have been available cannot be used? As air transport is Tasmania's only viable alternative in what is developing into a siege situation, will the Minister undertake to consider air transport as a complete alternative under the land bridge concept when the next revision of the scheme is undertaken?

—The Minister for Transport has provided me with some information for Senator Archer in regard to the freight equalisation scheme and its workings. I note that the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme was introduced to overcome the transport cost disability suffered by Tasmanians when shipping cargoes interstate by sea because of the lack of access to road and rail transport. The scheme has not been developed to place Tasmanians at an advantage over their mainland counterparts; rather, it has been developed only to remove a disability. When the scheme was established in 1976 consideration was given to the inclusion of air cargo at that time. However, it was found that Tasmania's interstate air freight rates were no higher than comparable air freight rates on the mainland. Accordingly, the Government did not introduce assistance on air freight as no disability existed. It may well be that that situation has changed and, if that is implied in Senator Archer's question, I will undertake to refer that matter to the Minister and to obtain a reply for him.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware that figures as at 31 October 1978 show that more than 370,000 eligible non-British migrants have not applied for Australian citizenship? What effort has the Government made to encourage eligible migrants to become citizens and thus enrol for voting? Does the Minister have any explanation for this apparent reluctance? Does the Minister agree that one reason might be the distaste that many non-British migrants have for swearing the oath of allegiance to the Queen as the symbol of a monarchy? Does the Government have in mind the substitution of allegiance to the Australian Constitution as a preferable alternative?

—Most honourable senators from time to time are involved in citizenship ceremonies. Many of them would do the same thing, and that is, encourage people who are becoming Australian citizens to take the next step and to enrol themselves as voters. I agree with Senator Gietzelt that, if that is not happening and if there are considerable numbers of people who are eligible but are not registered, that is undesirable. I think the honourable senator asked a question in a similar vein not so long ago, about people who were not enrolling for voting. I imagine that most members of parliament do encourage this form of registration. I do not know what steps the Government is taking, but we can find that out for the honourable senator. I doubt whether it is the form of the oath of allegiance which serves as a significant barrier to people becoming citizens. I undertake to pass that matter on to my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services. As I say, I doubt whether that is the reason why people do not enrol; but, if the honourable senator has any survey evidence or any other evidence to indicate that that is the reason, I would be pleased to have it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EDUCATION: POWERS OF COMMONWEALTH AND STATES

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Education comment with reference to the guidelines on what has been called a dramatic turnaround of the policies of the past decade and a radical shift in the educational powers of the Commonwealth and the States?

—On 4 June the Minister for Education stated that the Commonwealth will maintain its overall commitment to education as a priority area of direct Commonwealth endeavour. Indeed, he announced an increase in real money terms-I repeat, an increase in real money terms-of 1.5 per cent in total Commonwealth spending in 1982 in the programs administered by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and the Commonwealth Schools Commission. The Minister reiterated that the States have the primary responsibility for the administration and delivery of educational services, particularly at the schools level, and that the Commonwealth has a particular role in identifying and bringing resources to bear on educational issues of national importance. On the basis of current assessments, the Commonwealth will continue to give priority to the areas of technical and further education, vocational education and transitional education. I repeat that the overall funds available for the coming year are, in real money terms, 1.5 per cent larger than those for this year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The matter raised by Senator McLaren was not one of the matters considered by the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee. I will see what can be done to deal with the question if it is placed on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy and refers to the Government policy, which was introduced while he was a Minister, to administer the wholesale price of liquefied petroleum gas at export parity. Is the current administered price $250 a tonne? Is the current export parity price of LPG around $240 a tonne? I understand that it is expected to go lower. Is the Government forcing Australian consumers to pay $10 a tonne above export parity? What windfall revenue are Esso, BHP and Australian oil refiners picking up from the Government's above export parity price? Will the Government allow this situation to continue?

—In recent days, as I foreshadowed and indeed as the Australian Labor Party pooh-poohed, the world price of liquefied petroleum gas has started to fall. I repeat that when I foreshadowed that some months ago the Labor Party derided the suggestion. It has fallen by a dimension--
—I didn't.

—It does not surprise me that Senator Walsh is out of step with everybody, including his own party. The fact is that the world price has fallen, probably by roughly $A20 a tonne. That is being determined at this moment. The aim of the Government when it fixed the price, particularly when it fixed the price of LPG in relation to automotive use and when it fixed the price with regard to the $80 a tonne subsidy, was to ensure that if the world price fell below a particular level in relation to oil the consumers would get the benefit of it. This has happened within recent days, not in recent weeks or months. The matter is immediately under the consideration of the Government. It may not be possible-indeed, it cannot be possible-to bring in legislation to have effect this side of the end of June, but it will be a priority measure in the August session. Indeed, the aim will be to ensure that equity is done to the Australian people in terms of this matter. I would hope that as more supplies of LPG become available, particularly from the departure from flaring in the Middle East and the stripping of the gas, the price may continue to fall.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister provide the Senate with an estimate of the windfall revenue which BHP, Esso and the Australian refiners will pick up for as long as this Government policy of pricing LPG for domestic consumers at above export parity continues?

—First of all, I must say that this Government has not been pricing LPG above export parity. That is not our policy at all and it is not intended that it should be our policy. It is intended that if world prices fall, as they look as though they are doing, the benefit will be passed on to the consumers. I will not know what benefit, if any, accrues to producers or distributors until, firstly, the Government is able to make calculations as to the prices and, secondly, the Government is able to bring in legislation and, of course, proclaim that legislation. But, if in due course Senator Walsh seeks that information, I will be happy to give it to him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. The Confederation of Australian Industry recently prepared a report which showed that Australia wanted 20,000 New Zealanders a year for the next five years to fill manpower shortages. Given our current unemployment problem, would it not be more advantageous to Australia's present and future if young Australians were given greater opportunity to develop skills rather than our nation's industry and commerce having to rely on recruitment from New Zealand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.
