PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The principal purpose of this Bill is to amend the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946 to allow the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) to form or participate in the formation of a company that may be established to own and manage the national communications satellite system. On 18 September 1980, the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications informed Parliament that tenders were to be called for the supply of a communications satellite system, and that the Government was considering the possibility of establishing a company to own and manage that system, the public sector to hold 51 per cent of the share capital in such a company and the private sector to hold 49 per cent of the shares. A committee of officials was requested to report on the interest of the private sector in participating in such a company in which OTC would have a major interest on behalf of the Government, the company to operate as a commercial tax paying enterprise. As an interim measure, OTC had been designated as the authority to own and manage the communications satellite system. For this purpose, licences under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905 had been issued to OTC to provide telecommunications services by way of a satellite system.

A request for tenders for the satellite communications system was issued in October last year. The request for tenders is a comprehensive set of documents inviting tenders for the supply of the space segment of the satellite system, the major city earth stations and minor earth stations to access the satellite, earth stations required by Telecom for telephony services as well as receive-only earth stations for regional and remote area national broadcasting services. Also included in the request for tender was the supply of earth terminals for the Department of Transport's air safety and navigational services. Twenty tenders were received for the space and earth segments of the satellite communications system and evaluation of tenders is now taking place.

In introducing this Bill, I would make it clear that the Government has not taken decisions on what the final ownership arrangements should be. The report of officials on their discussions with the private sector on participation in a company to own and manage the satellite communications system is now being considered by the Government. An announcement about the outcome of these considerations should be made in the near future. Honourable senators will appreciate that if the Government decides to proceed with the concept of establishing a company with public and private sector involvement, there will be a need for further discussion and negotiation on the detailed arrangements which might apply before the company, as a legal entity, is established. The provisions of the Bill in this regard should therefore be seen as a contingency measure only. Whether there would be a need for recourse to the provisions of the Bill will depend on government decisions regarding the organisation or authority which will be the ultimate owner of the satellite communications system and the timing for implementing those decisions. For this reason the Bill provides that action by OTC to form or participate in such a company requires the approval of the Minister.

Other objectives of the Bill are to enable OTC to provide technical services, on a commercial basis, to such a company, and to enable OTC to provide consultative services to the governments of neighbouring countries on the use of the satellite system for their own purposes. Again the Minister's approval is required before OTC could take action along those lines. The provision for OTC to provide consultative services of this nature to neighbouring countries reflects the Government's policy of assisting less developed nations in the region to develop their telecommunications services. Provision has been made in the design of the system for the satellite to provide telecommunications services for the Government of Papua New Guinea. This is an optional feature in the system design and the Papua New Guinea Government has yet to make decisions regarding its use of the Australian satellite system for its own needs.

For technical reasons, it has not been possible to provide in the first generation satellite system for services to be available to other countries in the South West Pacific region. The Government has offered, however, to participate in a study of the telecommunications needs of those countries and a formal invitation has now been received for Australia to take part in such a study. The results of that study will be taken into account when planning later generations of communications satellites. The OTC has had considerable experience in the provision of telecommunications services by satellites. It now provides tracking, telemetry, command and monitoring facilities for the Intelsat satellites in orbital locations over the Pacific and Indian oceans. It will provide similar services for satellites to be launched by the European Space Agency. The OTC also provides the major facilities at Moree, Ceduna and Carnarvon for the receiving and transmitting by satellite of international communications. Since the taking of the decision to invest OTC with the interim responsibility for developing the satellite communications system, that authority has built up its technical resources on satellite communications. The skills and experiences of OTC officers in satellite communications systems will be of major benefit in pursuing the Government's policy on extending modern telecommunications services to all people in Australia.

In seeking the support of honourable senators to this Bill, I would emphasise that the development of the national communications satellite system is a major project. The evaluation of tenders will be one of the most critical aspects. It has to be undertaken within a time frame which would allow contracts for the supply of the system to be entered into in early 1982, so that the space and earth segments of the system are available to coincide with reservations which have been made with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration-NASA-and the European Space Agency to place the satellites in their orbital positions. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 to provide for changes covering:
(a) supplementary licences for radio stations;
(b) public interest criteria
(c) ownership or control provisions;
(d) the Australian Broadcasting Commission's merchandising and contractual activities; and
(e) other minor amendments.

Before turning to the detail of the proposed amendments to the Bill, I make general comment on the intent of the changes. The Senate will recall that, in a statement on 9 October 1980, the Honourable A. A. Staley, M.P., foreshadowed legislation to introduce supplementary licences as a means of increasing the range of broadcasting services available in non-metropolitan areas. The Government recogised that in those areas where an additional fully competitive commercial station was not a viable proposition an alternative needed to be found which widened the choice of services. The supplementary licence concept was conceived as a means of providing additional radio and television services, while protecting the commercial viability of existing services in the area and preserving the principle of localism in broadcasting.

The Bill provides for the introduction of supplementary licences for commercial FM radio in areas outside Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth. While commercial FM services have begun operation in mainland metropolitan areas, no commercial FM services are available in regional areas. Many such areas cannot support fully competitive FM services and accordingly the only means of providing these services in those areas is through the supplementary licence concept. This will enable an existing commercial AM operator to provide an FM service in any area not able to support a fully competitive service.

Honourable senators will note that the Bill does not provide for supplementary television licences. The Government has decided not to proceed at this time with supplementary television licences, following extensive discussions with the television industry and following representations by regional television operators that in many cases supplementary television licences would not be commercially viable without a subscription television component. Before any introduction of subscription television services is contemplated, a number of issues will need to be considered, not the least of which is the desirability of such services and the ground rules within which they should operate. Furthermore, the Government believes it would, in any case, be anomalous to introduce subscription television into regional areas without also considering such services for metropolitan areas. Accordingly, the Government has referred the matter of subscription television to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for consideration in conjunction with its inquiry into cable television. No decision regarding subscription television will be made until the Tribunal has presented its report, which is expected in March 1982.

The Government is conscious of the fact that in a limited number of areas supplementary television licences may be viable without a subscription television component. However, the Government is not prepared to make separate provision specifically for those areas. It believes that any introduction of supplementary television licences to increase commercial services should be considered in a wider context. The Government is anxious that large regional cities and the smaller capitals should have the opportunity for increased services at the earliest practicable opportunity. It is anticipated that Government will be making further decisions on the subject following receipt of the Tribunal's report.

The Senate will also recall that on 9 April 1981, the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) announced to Parliament the broad thrust of the conclusions reached by the Government after its review of the Act, and he foreshadowed amendments covering:
1. The machinery and procedural aspects of sections 90 to 92KA of the Act; and
2. Inadvertent breaches of the Act by shareholders in companies acquiring interests in radio and television broadcasting licences through share trading on the stock exchange.

Necessarily that statement did not express with the same precision as legislation the changes proposed to the Act, and honourable senators will note that in some respects the Bill differs from the proposals outlined previously. The changes follow from further consultation with the industry. However, that statement did outline in general terms a package of proposals with two major themes which remain relevant.

Firstly, the amendments will maintain the basic structure of decision making that has been in operation since 1977. The amendments will provide the means for more effective administration of the broadcasting system in accordance with Government policy. The lack of reference points for the Tribunal in deciding whether a particular licensing decision would be in the 'public interest' has led to some uncertainty in Tribunal proceedings. The incorporation of legislative guidelines for 'public interest' will provide a clearer statement of Government policy in relation to the major discretionary powers of the Tribunal.

Secondly, the amendments are designed to ensure that the ownership or control provisions will remain effective and appropriate to the commercial environment of the 1980s. Restrictions on the free transfer of interests should be no greater than are necessary to achieve a reasonable balance between the desirability of preventing uncontrolled trading in licences, and the need for a vigorous share market. It has become apparent that the present share transaction procedures, which require the Tribunal's approval prior to any purchase, may operate to prevent a large diversified industrial corporation, for example, from lawfully purchasing shares on the open market in another such corporation, if the second corporation has an indirect interest in a radio or television station of as little as 6 per cent of issued capital. The Government regards such a result as inappropriate for an Act which is designed only to regulate radio and television, and unnecessary to achieve the aims of the legislation. This applies even more strongly in the case of third party breaches of the Act. It is only in exceptional circumstances in our system of justice that a person should be immediately liable for an offence as a result of some other person's actions. In this instance, the circumstances do not warrant such a result. In the Government's view, any person being put into inadvertent breach of the Act should not face possible prosecution, without first being allowed at least six months to comply with the ownership limitations.

On 9 April last, the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Minister representing him in the other place tabled in Parliament a report by the Administrative Review Council on the inquiry procedures of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. In his statement to the House of Representatives on the same day, the Minister for Communications said that there would not be any decision as to specific recommendations until the public and the broadcasting industry had the opportunity to comment. Interested persons and organisations have been contacted and asked for their comments on the report by the end of July. It is expected that the Government will be in a position to consider specific recommendations of the report later in the year. I would also point out that during the preparation of the Bill and particularly following the Minister's announcement to the House of Representatives on 9 April there has been considerable public debate. In particular, details of the proposals have been discussed with a wide range of broadcasting and television groups, which are most immediately affected by ownership or control amendments, with the objective of assessing the overall impact of suggested changes before finalising Government decisions. In summary, the intention of the present amendments is to streamline procedures, avoid delays in the Tribunal's consideration of transactions, minimise the necessary number of inquiries and provide clearer guidance in relation to the Tribunal's major discretionary powers. I turn now to the detail of the proposed amendments.
Supplementary Licences for Radio Stations

The Bill will enable commercial AM licensees, in areas other than Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth, to apply for a supplementary licence to operate an FM radio service in their area. Provision has also been made to allow licensees, in areas where there is more than one AM station, if they so choose, to form a consortium to apply for one supplementary licence on a joint basis. Because of the different propagation characteristics of FM as opposed to AM signals, provision is also made for the Minister to invite an applicant to apply for associated commercial translator licences. The intent behind this provision is to ensure that an area currently served by a commercial AM station and its associated translator stations will as far as possible be able to be served by a supplementary FM station together with its associated translator stations.

Applicants will make their applications to the Minister in accordance with a form approved by him. Applications can only be made by commercial AM operators to provide a supplementary FM service in their own areas. Unlike other licence applications, where applicants apply in response to an invitation by the Minister, applicants for supplementary licences will be able to apply at any time. The Minister will however be able to refer the application to the Tribunal or to reject the application on grounds relating to technical matters or to the planning or development of broadcasting and television services. This provision arises from the Minister's statutory responsibilities for the planning and development of these services.

In considering applications for supplementary licences, the Tribunal will follow similar procedures to those applying to other licences. For example, in considering an application for a supplementary licence, the Tribunal will be required to take account of the criteria applying to the grant of other licences. However, an additional provision will enable the Tribunal to refuse to grant a supplementary licence in any area which can sustain a fully competitive commercial broadcasting station without endangering the viability of existing services. If the Tribunal finds that an additional commercial station would be viable then it will be required to inform the Minister of its determination and the reasons for it.

Supplementary licences will be granted for up to five years and renewed for up to three years. The Tribunal shall, in considering any renewal of a supplementary licence not less than eight years after the initial grant of a supplementary licence, determine whether an additional commercial station is reasonably likely to be viable in that area, and whether it would be in the public interest, as defined, to call for applications for a commercial licence. If the Tribunal is satisfied on both grounds, it shall recommend to the Minister that he invite applications for a commercial licence and shall give the supplementary licensee three years' notice of its intention not to renew the supplementary licence. A licensee, but not a consortium, will be able in such a case to opt to retain the broadcasting station operated under this supplementary licence and instead forgo the station operated under his commercial licence. This provision is intended to cover a broadcaster wishing to retain his supplementary FM station rather than his commercial AM station. In this case the supplementary licence will convert to a normal commercial licence.

I need to comment on some aspects of supplementary licences which have been the subject of some recent concern by the broadcasting industry. A decision to seek a supplementary licence is entirely a decision for the licensee in the area concerned. The Ministerial discretion to dismiss applications can only be on technical grounds or for planning and development reasons, for example, where no frequencies are available, or where the calling of applications for a fully competitive service is contemplated. I would emphasise that the Ministerial discretion must be interpreted within the scope, purpose and objects of the Act. The minimum duration of a supplementary licence is 11 years with no consideration of non-renewal before eight years. The Government believes this provides an adequate period for licensees to recoup their investment.

Finally, it is not correct to say that there are appeals available for other classes of licences which are not available for supplementary licences. The appeal provisions in section 119A apply equally to supplementary licences as to other classes of licences, the only difference being that there is no appeal against non-renewal after eight years. Special provisions have been inserted to allow the supplementary licence to continue in operation in circumstances where the Tribunal has decided not to renew the licence but for one reason or another competitive licences have not been issued.

The Bill includes a number of special provisions relating to localism and arrangements with other radio stations. Specifically, supplementary licencees will need to seek Tribunal approval for arrangements entered into with other stations for the regular broadcasting of:
(i) the programs of a related commercial AM station or other commercial stations;
(ii) the programs of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Special Broadcasting Service or public stations.

This provision will provide some degree of Tribunal oversight over the simulcasting of programs-that is, the simultaneous transmission, in one area of the same radio program by two or more stations-or the networking of radio programs from other areas. Other provisions intended to preserve the principle of localism are those relating to:
(i) the minimum amount of locally produced or originated programs as provided for by licence conditions; and
(ii) the encouragement of local advertising.

The proposed amendments will provide a legal basis for the introduction of supplementary licences for radio. However, it should be noted that substantial lead times are involved both for industry and for the Department. This involves giving reasonable notice to those required to vacate the 88-108MHz band, and the determination of station service areas. Substantial costs may also be involved. The decisions required can only be made, and the costs minimised, if all concerned in the process of clearing the band are given adequate notice of the Government's intention. There is already a considerable backlog of applications to be considered relating to the existing range of broadcasting and television services. Planning for supplementary licences will proceed in parallel with the clearing of this backlog and the introduction of non-metropolitan commercial FM services. Accordingly, at a later date, the Minister intends to make a major statement regarding planning guidelines for this stage of development of commercial FM services. For these reasons, the Bill includes a transitional provision that no applications for supplementary licences may be made before a date to be fixed by proclamation.
Public Interest Criteria

Clauses 13, 16, 18, 19, 28 and 38 of the Bill provide for legislative guidelines for the 'public interest' component of the major discretionary powers of the Tribunal in relation to licence grant, renewal, suspension, revocation or transfer and in relation to the approval of share (or debenture) transactions. Although the words 'public interest' do not currently appear in the Act in respect of licence grants and transfers, the High Court has confirmed in the 2HD case that the concept of public interest is a relevant factor in the exercise of the Tribunal's discretionary powers even where it is not explicitly stated. The Bill provides a consistent codification of public interest for all the major discretionary powers.
Dependent on the type of application, the public interest criteria will be established according to the following guidelines:
(i) whether the applicant will meet or has met an undertaking to:
(a) comply with the conditions of a licence;
(b) provide an adequate and comprehensive service in pursuance of the licence, having regard to:
the nature of the community served or to be served;
the diversity of the interests of that community; and
the nature of other radio/ television services which may be received in the same area;
(c) encourage the provision of Australian produced programs and the use of Australian creative resources;
(ii) whether a person or company is fit and proper to hold an interest in a licence;
(iii) the financial, technical and management capacity to undertake the operations of a licence;
(iv) in non-metropolitan areas-that is, outside the six State capitals-the degree of concentration of influence of radio or television stations; and
(v) the commercial viability of stations in the area.

The undertaking concerning the provision of an adequate and comprehensive service in pursuance of the licence provides a focus for public input at licensing inquiries. It is also intended to generate greater awareness in the public and the industry of the need to provide programming which not only complies with general standards, but also to take account of the particular characteristics of the audience served. With regard to the concentration of influence on radio and television in regional areas, honourable senators should be aware that the principal Act already applies much stricter limits on ownership in metropolitan areas than in regional areas. It is not possible for any individual to hold prescribed interests in more than one television station and one radio station in any one State capital city within the overall limit of two television or eight radio stations. On the other hand it would not be illegal for one person to control up to two television stations and four radio stations in a regional city such as Newcastle. In this latter case, it is clearly desirable that the Tribunal should be able to limit undesirable concentration.
Ownership or Control Provisions
PROCEDURES FOR THE EXAMINATION OF SHARE TRANSACTIONS

The current ownership or control provisions of the Act provide that it is an offence to hold 'prescribed interests' in more than two commercial television licences or more than eight commercial radio licences. The acquisition of a 'prescribed interest' or an increase in a 'prescribed interest', as defined in the Act, is currently subject to prior approval by the Tribunal. The provisions restrict the opportunities to purchase shares or debentures in a company if they would confer on the purchaser a prescribed interest in a licence. It is proposed that the requirement for prior approval of such transactions be relaxed whilst preserving the principle that changes in the ownership or control of licences be subject to effective public scrutiny. Most importantly, the Tribunal is being given effective powers to collect information on proposed transactions, and to give directions to avoid irreversible adverse effects on the licensee prior to approval being given.

Sections 90J and 92F of the principal Act-clauses 27 and 37 of the Bill-are being amended to provide for the notification to the Tribunal of any intended transaction and the lodgement of an application for approval of either an intended transaction or a completed transaction. Failure to lodge a notice or application prior to a transaction will be an offence on each day until a notice or application is lodged. However, such an offence will not preclude ultimate approval by the Tribunal of a transaction provided an application is lodged within 28 days. These amendments will allow the Tribunal to receive applications for approval of share transactions after, as well as before, transactions have taken place.
New sections 90JA and 92FAA-clauses 28 and 38 of the Bill-make provision for the approval of share and debenture transactions. In summary, these sections provide:
(i) that the Tribunal may approve an application in respect of share transactions after, as well as before, a transaction has taken place.

(ii) that the Tribunal may disapprove an application made before or after a transaction provided that it first holds an inquiry into the intended transaction; that inquiry may at the Tribunal's discretion be:
(a) a separate inquiry into the transaction; or
(b) an inquiry into both the transaction and the renewal of the licence;

(iii) that any inquiry may be required by the purchaser, in his application, to commence within three months after the application and if the inquiry does not commence within three months, the transaction is deemed to have been approved; and
(iv) that the Tribunal shall take all reasonable steps to complete an inquiry within three months of commencing the inquiry.

Where a transaction has taken place without prior approval the Tribunal may give directions to prevent any action it considers will have an adverse affect on the ability of a company holding the licence to comply with the conditions of the licence, or on the operations, management or the selection or provision of programs by the licensee company. These powers are conferred by clause 40 in new section 92M. Clauses 28 and 38 of the Bill also provide the criteria which must be taken into account by the Tribunal in considering whether to approve a transaction. In particular, the clauses provide the grounds on which the Tribunal may refuse an application for the approval of a transaction, in whole or in part where an application is lodged in accordance with section 90J or 92F. These are:

(i) in the case of a purchaser acquiring or increasing a 'major' interest in the licence: If the Tribunal would be empowered to refuse consent to the transfer of that licence to the applicant. This provision recognises that a major share transaction affecting a licensee and a transfer of the licence are, in practical terms, similar, and the Tribunal would consider the same public interest criteria and other criteria as are provided for in clause 19, that is, section 89A dealing with transfers.

(ii) in the case of a purchaser acquiring any interest in the licence: If the licence has been granted within the previous two years. This provision is intended to preserve the integrity of the licence grant process, by preventing an unsuccessful applicant for a licence from taking over the company of the successful applicant.

(iii) in the case of a purchaser acquiring a minor interest, or any other applicant acquiring an indirect interest through the purchaser: If the applicant does not comply with the public interest criteria. This provision applies the criteria in a more appropriate way to minor and indirect interests than if the acquisition were equated with licence transfers, and takes into account:

(a) the effect the transaction will have on the capacity of the holder of the licence to comply with the conditions of the licence and the written undertakings given to the Tribunal in relation to program services;

(b) whether the applicant is a fit and proper person to hold a licence and, as far as is relevant, has the necessary financial, technical and management capacities to carry out the requirements of a licence; and
(c) the degree of concentration of influence either directly or indirectly, on commercial radio and television stations, in a non-metropolitan area.

These streamlined procedures and guidelines will provide adequate controls on the ownership of radio and television. The Tribunal's approval will be necessary for the acquisition or increase of a prescribed interest, and the Tribunal will retain a discretion to consider an acquisition in the context of a public inquiry. At the same time the share market will be freed from unnecessary restrictions, but adequate checks will remain to discourage 'trading' in licences.

I should like to make two further points. Firstly, the Government has decided that the new provisions relating to approval of share transactions will apply only to transactions taking place after commencement of this legislation. Clause 50 gives effect to this decision. Secondly, in 1965 when the last substantial amendments were made to the ownership limitations, special provision was made for persons holding interests in excess of the new limitations, such that those interests could be retained as long as they were not increased or restructured. The commercial environment has changed since 1965. Companies locked in by sub-section 92 (3) have been at a disadvantage in adjusting to the market place. The Government believes that there should not be immediate application of the new share transaction procedures to those few companies whose interests remain frozen under sub-section 92 (3). Accordingly, new section 92FAB provides that the purchase of shares in these companies will be subject to the prior approval of the Tribunal. This restriction ceases on 1 July 1983, when the companies covered by section 92FAB will become subject to the same share transaction procedures as any other company.
Loan Interest and Registered Lenders

Under the existing Act, loan interests in a television station may result in a lender acquiring a prescribed interest in a licence. In some cases this will restrict opportunities to obtain finance, except by bank overdraft, to which exemption already applies, when in practice the investor might only be able to influence a licence where a licensee defaults on a loan. New section 91C-clause 31 of the Bill-empowers the Tribunal to register approved lenders and so exclude them from the prescribed interest provisions of the Act provided the Tribunal is satisfied that a person will not be in a position to exercise, directly or indirectly, a significant influence on any company holding a licence. In circumstances where a registered lender used a loan interest to exercise undue control over a licensee the Tribunal could deregister the lender. The lender would then be subject to the prescribed interest provisions applying to loan interests.
Variation of Limits on Permissible Holdings

New section 91D-clause 31 of the Bill-addresses the problem of breaches of section 92 of the Act by third parties acquiring excess prescribed interests as a result of share transactions by other persons. Experience has shown that an investor can be put in breach of the Act through the purchase of shares by another party in which the investor is a shareholder, because of the tracing provisions of the Act. Problems of third party breaches of the Act have arisen particularly with institutional investors, because of their large and diversified portfolio shareholdings.

New section 91D provides that any person wishing to hold an interest of from 5 per cent up to 10 per cent, on any test, in a television licence without it being considered as a prescribed interest may apply to the Tribunal for a certificate authorising them to do so. However, the benefits of the section will be extended only to persons acquiring an interest in a television licence which operates in an area where there is at least one other commercial television station-that is, the five mainland State capitals-and then only if those persons can satisfy the Tribunal that the interest in question will not give rise to a person exercising, either directly or indirectly, a significant influence on the licensee company. Clause 31 of the Bill -incorporating both section 91 and section 91D-will commence on a date to be proclaimed. Some preliminary work by the Tribunal is necessary to enable introduction of these provisions. However, the Government will be looking to proclaim this provision as soon as practicable.
Foreign Shareholdings

The existing sections 90G and 92D of the Act restrict ownership of shares, but not voting rights, in licensee companies by any individual non-resident to 15 per cent, and by the aggregate of non-resident shareholders to 20 per cent, of issued share capital. The interpretation of the provision has presented difficulties because of the lack of definition of 'resident' and the meaning of 'control'-that is, whether it is commercial control, 50 per cent of votes, or control as defined in the Act, 15 per cent of votes and shares. These sections have been redrafted to provide a redefinition of restrictions on foreign shareholdings to provide that only Australian citizens and companies in which Australian citizens hold more than 50 per cent of the votes and/or shares may be 'in a position to control' a licensee company. Clause 53 is a transitional provision for non-resident shareholdings, enabling residents who are not Australian citizens to retain any interests they hold at commencement which comply with the existing provisions of the Act. I should like to emphasise that apart from the alteration of 'resident' to 'Australian citizen' and the introduction of voting rights as a relevant interest, this new provision simply restates the interpretation which has in fact been applied to the existing sections 90G and 92D.
Provisions Relating to Enforcement and Penalty Provisions

The changes proposed by the Bill to the ownership or control provisions will produce a system which gives considerably more flexibility to licensees and persons acquiring interests in licences. The Government expects strict compliance with the new provisions. To this end existing sanctions and penalties have been strengthened substantially. New section 92N in clause 40 provides for the Tribunal to give directions for the purpose of securing disposal of excess interests if it is satisfied that a person has breached the provisions of Division 2 or 3 of Part IV of the Act by the acquisition of shares, debenture or loan interests. Directions given under clause 40 will be enforceable in the Federal Court. Additionally, the Bill provides in clauses 40 and 46 that non-compliance with directions will attract substantially higher penalties than those presently in force.
Australian Broadcasting Commission Merchandising and Contractual Activities

Clauses 7 and 8 of the Bill amend merchandising and contractual provisions relating to the operations of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. These provisions will enable the ABC to make, promote, circulate or sell non-literary matter associated with its programs. Clause 8 allows the ABC to enter into contracts for the sale of its programs without Ministerial approval. This delegation is essential for the quick negotiation of contracts.
Other Minor Amendments

The Bill contains a number of other provisions which are either consequential to the changes outlined or are minor changes which update and standardise provisions to accord with current legislative practice.

The proposed changes I have outlined to the ownership or control provisions will be the first major alterations for 16 years, yet there have been significant developments in the industry over that time. These changes, together with the introduction of supplementary licences for radio stations, will provide a sound basis for the continued development of broadcasting in the coming decade without undue constraint on commercial activity. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY GAMING AND LIQUOR AUTHORITY BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is the first step to be taken in implementing the Government's decision to amalgamate the Australian Capital Territory Totalizatory Agency Board, the Liquor Licensing Board and the Poker Machine Licensing Board and thereby to rationalise the number of statutory authorities in the Territory. The proposed authority will bring together a range of like and interrelated functions leading to a more effective and efficient co-ordination of gambling and liquor controls. The amalgamation offers scope for administrative efficiency with the sharing of common facilities and computer services.

The new Authority will consist of five members, including a chairman and deputy chairman. No specific membership qualifications are prescribed but because of the important community implications of the Authority's activities I propose that it should include a member of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly and a legal practitioner. The Bill includes a number of transfer arrangements and savings provisions to facilitate the establishment of the new Authority. It vests all the assets and liabilities of the TAB and the Poker Machine Licensing Board in the Authority and protects the employment conditions of TAB staff. The rights of the public servants who service the Liquor Licensing and Poker Machine Licensing Boards will not be affected under the Bill. Once the legislation is in operation and the new Authority constituted, the Government will consult with it on the further changes that might be necessary to facilitate the amalgamation process. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) BILL 1981LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was interrupted by the impending adjournment last Thursday, I had just explained that I was not going to deal in detail with the reduction in funding for health care entailed in this legislation. That will be done in detail by Senator Grimes. But I had made a few general observations, and I want to make a few more, about the changes that the Government has made, the most important of which is that this is not a cost reduction measure as far as the Commonwealth is concerned. The net effect of the changes will be that the Commonwealth will be some $340m a year worse off than it would have been without the changes. The reason that on a net basis the changes are costly to the Commonwealth in spite of reduced payments to the States is that health insurance premiums will, from now on, be tax deductible. Provided a person is in a so-called voluntary or more accurately, private health fund, medical costs will be subsidised to the extent of 30 per cent directly by the Commonwealth and to the extent of 32 per cent or, more accurately, something like 24 per cent on a net basis, by the Commonwealth through the taxation system because premiums paid to private health funds will be deductible to arrive at taxable income. Other medical expenses incurred by people who are not members of a private health fund will neither be tax deductible in practice nor attract a Commonwealth subsidy. The only exception will be if total deductions of an individual taxpayer are in excess of $1,590.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a measure of encouraging self-reliance; it is a device to subsidise and provide a captive market for private insurance funds. It is also a device to encourage the expansion of private hospitals when there is already, on a national basis, a surplus of hospital capacity. It is a device to guarantee the incomes of doctors operating on a fee-for-service basis. The theory upon which this dreadful policy is based is that of fiscal deterrents-that unless people are charged in an obvious and noticeable way for medical services they will over-use those services. It is ironic that the Bill should have been debated last Friday, the same day that the Liberal member for Moore, Mr Hyde, had an article in the Melbourne Age headed 'A Dry explains his viewpoint' in which, among other things, Mr Hyde said:
. . . an a priori, or doctrinal, position should stand a test of efficacy: It must work in practice. If it doesn't then there is something wrong with the theory and it should be revised.'

It is ironic that that viewpoint should be published on the day that the Government was having debated these measures which are based on the fiscal deterrent theory-that unles people are charged directly for health services they will over-use them. In other words, the Government assumes we are a nation of hypochondriacs. Apart from any argument there may be about that, the fiscal deterrent theory is in fact cancelled by the provision of private insurance because the nexus between the service which the patient may or may not demand and the payment for that service is broken. Once there is any sort of insurance-whether it be through the so-called voluntary funds, the private funds or on a national basis-that nexus is broken no matter which way we look at it.

This Government is providing a financial deterrent so strong that virtually everybody who can afford it will be in one of these voluntary funds. So the Government thereby destroys the rationale of its own policy and there is a fundamental contradiction between the hypothesis upon which the Government policy is based and the details of the policy itself. Even overlooking that fundamental illogicality it is well known to anyone who has looked even superficially at this question that the great majority of the really expensive medical services involving surgery and/or hospitalisation are initiated not by hypochondriacs but by doctors. These provisions again will certainly provide no financial deterrent to doctors to the use of that sort of service; they will provide a financial incentive to use it.

The empirical evidence to which Mr Hyde attributes such respect shows that in the area of health services market forces are not efficient. Market forces are efficient in many instances. The empirical evidence clearly shows that they are not efficient in the area of health services. The empirical evidence shows that, for example, in the area of elective surgery-tonsillectomies, appendectomies and so on-the Australian rate of tonsillectomies is about three times as high as the rate in the United Kingdom, the United Kingdom having predominantly a panel system and Australia having predominantly a fee for service system. Of course, most frightening of all is the experience in the United States of America, which has the extreme free market medical system, where operations which are not only superfluous but also, in many cases, actually damaging are encouraged and where there is a very high level of health expenditure and a relatively low standard of health care.

One of the more absurd manifestations of the United States policy came out recently when it was reported that American women who are assessed-that is, assessed by the doctors and the hospitals which would provide the services and make the profit from them-to be at risk of having breast cancer will have preventive mastectomies performed. That is what lies at the end of the road on which this Government has commenced to travel. If medicine is to be marketed like Coca-Cola or Blue Omo the result will be higher costs and lower health standards. The changes contained in this Bill are a move in that direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to address myself to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill 1981 in particular and to make some reference to tax sharing arrangements. Contained in this legislation is some formalising of an agreement made at the Premiers Conference. However, as I understand from Press reports, this week we can expect to see tabled in the Parliament the Commonwealth Grants Commission report on tax relativities. I have also read in the newspapers that after the Premiers Conference scheduled for 19 June there will be an additional meeting which will deal with this issue. I seek, on the general subject of tax sharing, to make comment in relation to the subject of tax sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and also to take the opportunity to make some specific response to cases that have been put in the Senate in relation to tax sharing and my State in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: On 14 May, Senator Hamer gave the Senate a full account of events in Australian fiscal federalism with particular emphasis on the current review of State relativities being undertaken by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. As I have said, we understand that the report on that matter will be tabled in Parliament this week. I for one look forward to that report with some eagerness. In the course of this account Senator Hamer outlined in some detail the plight of his home State, Victoria, which he saw as having been severely disadvantaged under current financial arrangements with the Commonwealth. I cannot fault the honourable senator's account of the history of Federal-State financial relations up to and including the recent Premiers Conference, nor can I fault his outline of the principle to be followed by the Grants Commission in its review of State relativities.

However, it seemed to me that Senator Hamer had come to the conclusion that the Grants Commission has no role to play in the determination of State relativities. In this regard, whilst he claimed that the concept of differential payments to the States is not in dispute, but rather the amount, he concluded that Victoria should receive no less per capita than any other State-in other words, the differential payment should be zero. It would seem to me that, whilst his theoretical understanding of the reasons why there would be differences between relative revenue raising capacities and expenditure needs of the States is basically sound, his understanding of how these factors impact on the States in the practical sense is deficient. I think it is worth mentioning that we are probably all very well aware that the Victorian Government has been waging a very vigorous campaign on the subject of tax relativities and making claims in relation to its State. This campaign was echoed in Senator Hamer's speech.

It is not my desire nor my intention on this occasion to traverse the background of Federal-State financial relations, but simply to rectify some mistaken ideas about the plight of Victoria versus the too-favourable deal which, it is claimed, is the lot of my State, Queensland. I do not dispute the fact that household income in Victoria is the highest in Australia, nor the fact that the differential between the States has diminished in recent years. However, I believe that we should look behind this simplistic situation and ask ourselves why Victoria is in this advantageous position. The answer is quite simple-protection. Senator Hamer dismissed protection as a significant benefit to Victoria. Indeed, he indicated that the Victorian Government gains only $12 per capita annually from protection, or approximately $48m through payroll tax. It is claimed that this is the only benefit that Victoria receives. I venture to say that this estimate is a gross underestimation. Indeed, protection pervades the entire fabric of the Victorian economy. In pure dollar terms industry in Victoria is subsidised through tariff protection to the extent of over $750m annually.

Looked at in another way, Victoria received tariff assistance which was estimated in 1977-78-the year for which the most recent figures are available-at $430 per capita compared with the Australian average of $289 per capita, whereas Queensland received only $123 per capita. Again, Victoria has 27 per cent of the population but receives 41 per cent of total tariff assistance. Whilst Queensland has 16 per cent of the population it receives only 7 per cent of the total tariff assistance. These figures are outlined by the Industries Assistance Commission in 'Information Paper No. 1, Trends in the Structure of Assistance to Manufacturing', published in May 1980. These subsidies to Victoria not only add to the cost in Queensland of purchasing Victorian manufactured goods, but also provide Victoria with a higher taxable base. The aggregation and concentration of head office operations in Victoria, which continue in operation only through heavy subsidies, provide Victoria with the benefits of dutiable transactions which occur not only within that State but also in relation to the activities throughout Australia of those large organisations. If we were to reduce tariffs-Senator Hamer proposes this-I suggest that the effect on the Victorian Budget would be far greater than the loss of $48m in payroll tax.

With regard to the comparisons made of the percentage of income tax revenue returned to the States, I point out that, as I indicated earlier, Victoria's taxation revenues are inflated by the existence of heavily subsidised industries. Furthermore, while States receive a percentage of personal income taxation back from the Commonwealth, their contribution to Commonwealth revenues and to the economy generally is far greater than personal income tax alone. In this regard profits from unsubsidised industries in Queensland and Western Australia add significantly to national economic wealth, as do the substantial export earnings generated again by both Queensland and Western Australia. Indeed, if it were not for the export surpluses that Queensland and Western Australia earn we could not afford the tariffs which presently obtain so advantageously for Victoria.

As to Senator Hamer's contention that Queensland has done well out of the tax sharing arrangements, I point out that Queensland has been in receipt of a special grant from the Commonwealth on the recommendation of the Commonwealth Grants Commission in every year since 1971-72. These special grants are assessed only after comprehensive inquiry, with evidence under oath, by this expert independent body and are based on a direct comparison between Queensland and the standard States of New South Wales and Victoria. I can assure honourable senators that if they wish to peruse the detailed working papers of the Commission they will discover that Queensland has been assessed as being entitled to supplementary assistance not only because of its relative fiscal position compared with New South Wales but also because of its fiscal situation relative to Victoria. Further, whilst it is true that Queensland has no statutory corporation payments, no petrol tax, no tobacco tax and no probate duty whatsoever, the Grants Commission, through its complex procedures, calculates notional revenues for Queensland based on the taxation rate applicable in the standard States. In other words, it assesses what Queensland would raise if it had those taxes and incorporates this in the assessment it makes of Queensland revenue and expenditure needs. It even calculates the revenue that Queensland would raise if it had poker machines-a form of taxation which, contrary to the claim that taxes in Victoria currently cover every field of taxation available to the States, does not exist in Victoria.

Having given this general background to the comparison between Queensland and Victoria I shall now comment on some of the more specific matters raised by Senator Hamer. Firstly, I shall talk about payroll tax. In this regard it is disappointing that Senator Hamer sought leave to incorporate in Hansard a table on payroll tax which indicated a source which is just not correct. It is possible that Senator Hamer made an error; however, without a correction of that error we must take his speech at face value. If he did make an error I cannot deduce just what the simple nature of the error was. His table on 1979-80 revenue from State payroll tax indicates that it came from Budget Paper No. 7 1979-80. The honourable senator must have a different set of Budget papers to the one I have, because I can find no reference in Budget Paper No. 7 to State payroll receipts. Furthermore, the figures indicated in the table, regardless of their source, are incorrect. I seek leave to rectify those inaccuracies by incorporating in Hansard the correct statistics derived from the public Budget Papers for 1980-81 for each of the States.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I comment just briefly on the table, which shows that the payroll tax per capita payment in 1979-80 for Victoria was $142.77 and for Queensland, $113.56. I outlined earlier in my speech the significance of payroll tax payments per capita in relation to tariff policies. Moreover, whilst Senator Hamer correctly stated that payroll tax is uniformly levied at 5 per cent he neglected to make reference to the exemption levels which each State allows. As a consequence of differences in industry concentration as well as employment numbers between States these exemption levels affect quite differently the various States' capacities to raise revenue from this source. Indeed, the Grants Commission, in its 1978-79 assessment of Queensland's special grant, determined that Queensland's needs, using Victoria as the standard, amounted to $58m. In other words, Queensland's taxable capacity in this area was such that it would fall short of Victoria's per capita receipts by $58m, even with the same tax rate and the same exemption levels. Also with regard to payroll tax I cannot accept that Victoria was disadvantaged when payroll tax was transferred to the States. I do not deny that relatively more would have been deducted from Victoria's financial assistance grant base than would have been deducted in Queensland, but Victoria had the capacity to raise more from this revenue source than did Queensland. Indeed, Victoria would have been advantaged over other States in that the States increased the level of payroll tax subsequent to its transfer and this increase would have provided a greater benefit to Victoria than to other States.

SPEECH.PARA: I was surprised that Senator Hamer, in his discussion of hospital funding, referred to discrimination against Victoria in favour of Queensland. I am not claiming that the distribution of hospital funds by the Commonwealth Government is necessarily equitable. The Jamison report hit the nail on the head when it pointed out how the cost sharing arrangements rewarded the expensive and punished the efficient. It is to be regretted that this feature of the arrangements is to be perpetuated for another year at least under the interim arrangements that are applying pending the Grants Commission review. There is no question that Victoria and Queensland are disadvantaged by this situation, and even though Queensland's position has received some recognition by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) offering a further $16m, the Queensland payment from the Commonwealth will still be significantly below the average on a per capita basis, as will Victoria's.

For the record, I cite the following estimated per capita payments from the Commonwealth to the States in 1981-82 for hospital and certain other health services of a relatively minor nature. The figures are derived from statements recently distributed by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and take account of the extra $16m granted to Queensland in recognition of its low per capita payment. They show that New South Wales will receive a per capita payment of $93, Victoria $80, Queensland $75, South Australia $91, Western Australia $118, Tasmania $92 and the Northern Territory $168. The national average is $89 a head. Furthermore, the common position of Queensland and Victoria is brought about for quite different reasons. It is important to note that Victoria, despite its relatively small size, concentrated population, higher level of hospital fee recoveries and greater incidence of private hospital services has not been able to reduce its net per capita hospital operating costs below those of Queensland, which are the lowest in the country. This is despite the fact that Queensland has an above average number of hospital and nursing home beds-a necessity because of the dispersion of our population-and the fact that we have the highest number of aged people, relative to the population, of any State.

Senator Hamer also discussed the matter of revenues from mineral resources. In this regard there has been considerable Press comment in recent weeks about the rich resource developments currently taking place in Queensland and Western Australia and that the economic rent to these States from the exploitation of such resources should lessen these States' dependence on Commonwealth funds. I do not argue with this argument in principle. However, the value of mineral royalties and surrogates such as rail freight profits as a contribution towards State revenues needs to be kept in perspective. For example, in 1979-80 Queensland's revenue from mining royalties was $73m, not $78m as quoted by Senator Hamer, plus $86m in rail profits, not the $108m quoted. That is $159m in total which represents a mere 7.2 per cent of the State's recurrent Budget.

Furthermore, while the revenue to the State from increasing coal production is likely to trend upwards, the volatile nature of returns from resource developments should be borne in mind. The terms of such enterprises are vitally dependent upon the vagaries of the world markets and Australia has no monopoly powers with any of her resources. A recent example in Queensland of projects which upon commencement appeared to be very attractive and viable but which subsequently turned sour include the production of nickel at Greenvale and phosphate at Duchess. The latter ceased production and the former would not have survived without intervention by the Queensland Government. With regard to the treatment of mineral rail line profits and mineral royalties, Queensland, in its case to the Grants Commission, has never denied that mineral line profits are, in essence, surrogate royalties. However, what I understand it has strenuously argued is that its inventiveness or ingenuity in devising a method for financing the establishment of its rail infrastructure and its successful negotiations with project developers reflects an extra effort to raise State finances not made by the other States. Surely a State should not be penalised when it comes to receiving a share of the tax reimbursement grants because of its extraordinary attempts to raise finances for itself.

With regard to the relative needs for police, I note that Senator Hamer has quoted from the Victorian Government's submission to the Grants Commission on the relative police staffing ratios necessary in various population densities. I point out to the Senate that those ratios are based on conditions in Great Britain and Victoria which are not representative of the geographic distribution of population in other parts of Australia, especially Queensland. In this regard, experience in Queensland has shown, and the Grants Commission has accepted this to date, that population dispersion and distances are highly significant in the determination of police staffing needs. Accordingly, in Queensland the police staffing ratios are the reverse of those proposed for Victoria. So far as railways are concerned, Queensland would very much like to be in the same situation as Victoria with its highly concentrated population and small area. However, this is not the case in Queensland and it is unavoidable that State country railways will make substantial losses. In this regard it is interesting to note that Senator Hamer considers that large losses on passenger services in Victoria are acceptable because the Victorian Government is committed to running those services, but at the same time considers it inappropriate that large losses occur in Queensland's rural railway network, even though that State is committed to running these in the same manner as Victoria is in running its suburban passenger services.

I will now focus some attention on the share of total payments to the States that Victoria receives and particularly on the way in which Senator Hamer and apparently also the Victorian Government see that State as having been hard done by over the past two decades. Senator Hamer started with the premise that it was appropriate for his State to receive almost its population share of the total grant in 1958-59. However, I find this starting point difficult as I am unable to reconcile how a state like Victoria, with an area of 228,000 square kilometres, 91 per cent of its population within 200 kilometres of Melbourne and its acknowledged high per capita household income base, could expect to receive a grant equal in per capita terms to Queensland which has an area of 1,729,000 square kilometres and only 65 per cent of its population within 200 kilometres of Brisbane. Senator Hamer presented no evidence that demonstrated that the 1958-59 distribution of grants was equitable when regard was had to the criterion of this fiscal equalisation. To the contrary, the fact that over the years other States have received special grants on the basis of a comparison with Victoria seems to indicate that the Grants Commission at least did not regard this as so. The mere fact that Victoria once received a percentage of the pool equivalent to its population share is not sacrosanct. Indeed, Senator Hamer provides the explanation of why Victoria receives less than its population share. He said:

The arguments for Victoria's receiving such a low proportion of income tax funds can only be that Victoria has a significantly higher State taxing capacity than other States or that the cost of providing equivalent services is significantly less in Victoria than in other States, or both.

I suggest to the Senate that these are precisely the reasons that Victoria receives a less-than-population share. With regard to the raw deal that Victoria is supposedly receiving in the area of specific purpose payments and works and borrowing programs, I can only repeat that Senator Hamer must have a Budget Paper No. 7 different from the one that I have. I seek leave to incorporate the correct table in Hansard.
Leave granted.
