Honourable senators will see, from perusing that table, that there is not the inequity claimed. In closing, I stress that Queensland has, over the past decade, received no more than its just entitlement from tax sharing and has been able to achieve this only through constant application for grants and special assistance which entail a great deal of extra work and submission to searching inquiry from the Commonwealth Grants Commission. If in future years Queensland's revenue raising capacity is increased at a greater rate than the other States, we would accept that there should be an appropriate adjustment to our share of the tax reimbursement grants. However, it is unlikely that these movements are sufficiently marked at this point to have a serious impact on the recommendation of the current review. Furthermore, we argue that the current relativities do not place adequate weight on the cost imposed on Queensland by virtue of its vast population dispersion, the small scale of many of its operations and the resultant higher unit costs associated therewith.

I regret that I have had to raise this issue in this chamber, particularly as the Grants Commission has not yet reported on its findings. However, there has been an orchestrated plan by Victoria to attempt to influence the decision of the Grants Commission and the Commonwealth Government by the application of subtle political pressure. This campaign has been mounting in recent months and even extends to the publication of a brochure by the Victorian Government. I also note that recently the Premier of Victoria, Mr Lindsay Thompson, has made direct approaches to the Prime Minister on the matter. I believe that we should let the Commission make its report without pressure at the political level. In any case, I am sure that it will not be swayed.

The real issue quite simply is that Victoria cannot expect to get a population share of tax sharing payments for two basic reasons. Firstly, it has a higher than average capacity to raise revenue from its own State taxes and, secondly, it is such a compact State that its expenditure on State services will be below the all-States averages. Furthermore, we must not lose sight of the fact that a substantial part of the higher taxable capacity results from the massive tariff subsidisation received in Victoria from citizens in all other States of Australia, and Queensland and Western Australia in particular. During Senator Hamer's speech in the Senate, Senator Thomas and I attempted, by way of interjection, to raise this issue with Senator Hamer. He, as is the wont of Victorians in discussing this subject, waved it aside and said that tariffs are not applicable. If we so radically restructure our tax sharing base, as Senator Hamer suggests, if that is the recommendation of the Grants Commission when it reports to the Parliament this week on tax relativities, then I suggest that there are other issues which would need to be opened. It would be necessary to look at just how that tax sharing base is arrived at and why average household incomes, which consistently show Queensland and Western Australia to be at the bottom of the list, turn out the way they do. In short, I have sought to inject into the debate on tax sharing arrangements with the States, both for the present and for the future, some of the political and financial realities that the Government must face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Far be it from me to intervene in the internecine debate between Senator Martin and her colleague Senator Hamer on the Government side. Senator Martin in fact gives those of us on the Opposition side of the House even more heart in opposing this sort of legislation, an action which we take in concert with her Premier and all other State Premiers. If I may just comment in passing, I certainly agree with Senator Martin who said that Senator Hamer's proposal that we should have tax sharing arrangements based on a per capita basis is quite contrary to the whole concept of federalism in this country. I also find it strange for Senator Martin to make such a complaint on the basis of Victoria's increased capacity to raise taxes when she, first of all, comes from a State which is willing to forgo large amounts of tax revenue by willy-nilly abolishing probate and estate duties and whose Premier has such a concern for Federation that he considers, as he has said in remarks on many occasions, that Tasmania is a foreign country and in fact states that anyone who favours Tasmanian meat exports, for instance, is favouring a foreign country rather than his or her own State.
—But the Grants Commission assumes that we do meet those taxes.
—I will leave the good senator to fight that out in her party room with her colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to confine my remarks on this legislation to Part III of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill which in fact deals with health grants to the States and represents the first legislative step towards the latest health and health insurance scheme to be inflicted on the people in this country by the present Government. I repeat that these proposals were in fact opposed by all State Ministers for Health as were the tax sharing arrangements opposed by all the State Premiers at the last Premiers Conference. We of the Labor Party are in strange company, but we believe we are on good grounds, in opposing this legislation. This piece of legislation is the introduction of the fifth health package which has been produced by this Government-a government, I remind the Senate, whose pledge before coming to power was in fact: 'We will preserve Medibank'. It represents not only a turning back to the pre-Medibank days but also a positive effort by the Government to force the citizens of this country into the private health system and into the private insurance funds where in fact wealth will buy privileged health care. It is the first step back to the days of neglect of public funding of public health facilities which will lead to the public squalor and the private affluence that we had in the health system in the past-a system which concerned not only the Opposition at the time but also the Liberal-Country Party governments from 1969 through to 1972. Apart from the inadequacy of the new system which is introduced, the confusion, the inefficiency and chaos in the health systems in this country are compounded where there need be no such chaos, inefficiency and confusion.

Under this legislation, the States will receive a block grant for health funds to replace the grants under the previous hospital sharing agreements, the community health programs, the programs for women's refuges about which I will have more to say later and the school dental health program. These grants are not to be earmarked. In other words, there is no earmarking of the moneys. The funds need not be directed in any particular direction. In respect of Tasmania and South Australia, the first a Labor State and the other a Liberal State, the governments have wisely decided to persist with their present hospital cost sharing arrangements until they expire. They have taken this decision for the simple and sensible reason that the new arrangements are less generous. The Government funding in these health areas will in fact be some 16 per cent lower. In respect of the hospital portion of the grant, the grant is judged on a base figure on hospital costs which, as Senator Martin said in her speech, is a varying figure in each State. In fact, in each State there was a loss on the operations of hospitals last year. So, we already start off on a low base. Built into the grant is an inflation figure of 10 per cent, which on every prediction will be inadequate for the forthcoming year. These moneys will be discontinued by some 60 per cent of the assessment of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) of what each State can raise from hospital charges. These are that the States will charge $80 a day for a shared ward, $110 a day for a private ward and $15 a day for what is called an out-patient service-an entity that we on the Opposition side do not believe is defined in this legislation. It was not defined by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) in another place, primarily because he did not appear to defend this legislation in that place. He left it to the Treasurer (Mr Howard). This is obviously causing confusion amongst health funds. Where will, for instance, reimbursement for these out-patient services come from? Will it come from the medical insurance funds or the hospital insurance funds? This is something of which we are uncertain and of which everyone seems to be uncertain.

These changes to the health funding arrangements were introduced, firstly, without any proper consultation with the States; secondly, the basis of the calculations which were used were disputed by all the States, by every State health department and every State Minister for Health; thirdly, they clearly will not result in any decrease in total health costs and in fact by increasing the number of people in private health care and increasingly encouraging fee for service medicine may, and almost certainly will, increase costs. The changes will reintroduce the system of bad debts, particularly bad debts to public hospitals, at the level that existed before 1975 when Medibank was introduced and they introduced a demeaning and complicated means test for patients in public hospitals in some States, particularly Tasmania and Queensland, for the first time ever. The State Ministers, Labor and conservative, at their meeting on 8 May had this to say: 'We observe we have never been consulted in the real sense of the word. At no time prior to its recent decision has the Commonwealth indicated any clear intention to the States.' At the meeting with the State Ministers to discuss these arrangements, the Federal Minister for Health was asked to produce the figures on which his calculations were based. The meeting was here in Canberra. He replied that he could not do so because the figures were 'over at Woden'. The South Australian Government at least, and the others in agreement, offered to have its officers sit down with officers from the Federal Department of Health and recalculate the figures with the Government and, if the figures were wrong, they would suffer the penalty. The Minister replied that it did not matter as the figures could be fixed up at the end of the financial year anyway.

This is new federalism at its worst. This sort of distribution of taxpayers' funds at a meeting like this is more suited to a banana republic than what is allegedly an advanced nation. We have a system which is designed to force the States to charge what the Commonwealth wants them to charge, to introduce a means test that the Commonwealth wants and that some of the States do not want, to introduce a funding system that the States say is based on shonky figures, which allegation they are willing to demonstrate is so. The Commonwealth defends all this without putting up adequate argument, without putting up adequate figures, because it has the purpose of introducing a health scheme which will assist the private health industry particularly the private health funds run by the very same people who supply free advertising, donations and free workers at election time for the conservative government and supplied at contributors' expense. This, I suggest, is political patronage at its worst and should be condemned by everyone in this country.

This Government has a view of health care which is held in very few countries, certainly very few advanced countries. The Minister continually compares hospital care and hospital costs with costs in expensive hotels and motels. He forgets or never mentions that the people who stay in expensive hotels do so by choice. They usually are still earning their income while they are there and in many cases, such as in the case of businessmen and in fact in the case of politicians, they have their expenses paid while they are there. The opposite applies to a hospital patient, who frequently is not earning while he is in hospital and is not there by choice. The Government has a view that the user pays principle is appropriate to health funding in this country, forgetting that the user in fact is often someone who is chronically ill, a family member with children or a person with a recurrent illness. The person in hospital is not there by choice. As Senator Walsh pointed out, the choice is not made by the patient. The patient is there from necessity or from what he sees as a necessity because his doctor says that it is necessary for him to be there.

Finally, the Government has a view that market forces will in some way control costs in health care, and that in particular-we have had this repeated many times in this chamber and in other places-hospital costs can be kept down by increasing the fees paid by people who go to hospital and that therefore, in some mystical way, we will be able to cut down the number of hospital beds which are occupied. I repeat that the choice of hospitalisation is not made by the patient. It is not like a situation with a motel. The decision is almost entirely made by the doctor. The market in this situation is in the control of the middle man, and the middle man in fact will benefit from the person who is in hospital. We wonder what has happened to the community rating principle-a principle which has been espoused in this place in the past by the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, and which provided that for essential services whose need was out of the control of the patient or the citizen the principle of ability to pay through levy or direct taxation should apply. That principle simply does not suit those who benefit from the private health industry and therefore that principle is interred in this legislation. The Government is stepping out of responsibility for public hospitals in this country but is bending over backwards to direct people into private funds and private hospitals-private hospitals which are increasingly becoming foreign-owned and increasingly becoming known as hot bed hospitals, hospitals which deal with acute short term illnesses because they are more efficient at handling them and a bigger profit can be made from them.

The Government is making the criteria for assistance for disadvantaged persons in another piece of legislation more rigid and in fact is herding people more frequently into public hospitals. What we need is an efficient, effective and economical health system. We will not get it by increasing the number of people treated in this country on a fee for service basis, where the amount of money received depends on the performance of an individual service. We will not get it by turning the health system over to so-called market forces, when the people who are buying have very little knowledge or insufficient knowledge of what they are buying, and of the need for them to buy it. It is a retrograde step and that is why we are disturbed at and opposed to Part III of this legislation as far as the hospitals are concerned. The States are concerned because of the inadequacy of the base figure, the inadequacy of the inflation figure and what they see as the hopeless inadequacy of the amount they will be able to recover from patients. They realise, from years of experience, the difficulties which will arise in this situation.

Because my time is limited, I will deal now with one other aspect of Part III of this legislation. I wish to express our concern at the fate of funds which are directed to the States from the previous community health budget and, in particular, those funds which were directed to the States for the use of women's refuges. Women's refuges, as everyone in this chamber realises, provide a service which is utilised not only directly by the women and children in distress whom they serve but also by the authorities in each State-by local authorities, by federal governments, by the police departments, by the State welfare departments and by the Department of Social Security-which direct people in distress to women's refuges in every State. They are also utilised by the voluntary welfare agencies, which refer women in distress to these refuges. They are almost univerally, if not universally, run on a shoestring. The whole budget from the Government is less than $5m. In general, those who run the refuges are grossly underpaid, often with two or more sharing a salary. They work in conditions which are emotionally draining and physically unsatisfactory, and if the refuges were under the control of labour regulations and were unionised they would not be tolerated. Despite their use continually by community and government bodies, they are subject at times to denigration by some segments of the community, by honourable senators in this place and certainly more often in other places by State governments. It is for all these reasons-the emotionally draining problems faced by people who work in these refuges, the extreme difficulties they work under, the financial difficulties involved, the long hours these people work and the unsatisfactory conditions they work under-that there was the demonstration here last week. No matter how inappropriate Government senators may consider the actions which were taken last week, no matter how disturbed the more sensitive souls in this Parliament may be by such a display of frustration and anger, the complaints are real and these people's problems are real and severe and will not go away. They perform a service for which they receive little recognition and they certainly receive inadequate support.

In this legislation they face another threat because the legislation provides that the money which was previously earmarked for women's refuges will be subsumed into the health grant and eventually will be subsumed into general purpose grants. This is a cause for concern because some State governments, particularly the Western Australian and Queensland governments, are hostile to the very existence of women's refuges, despite the fact that their agencies use them, and use them frequently. In the past, Queensland has refused to hand on federal funds for the purpose of women's centres and refuges and the Federal Government had to fund them direct. The present Western Australian Minister for Community Welfare, whose name appropriately is Mr Hassell, put so many restrictions on the distribution of these funds, particularly the child care funds, that life is made almost impossible for those who are trying to run these refuges.

A majority in this Parliament, I believe, recognise the needs for women's refuges. They recognise that when funding was introduced for women's refuges in the time of the Labor Government those moneys were directed to a worthy cause and what has happened since has demonstrated that they were fulfilling a previously unfulfilled need. We should insist that money previously earmarked for this purpose is directed to these shelters in the future and, if not, the Commonwealth should fund them directly and ensure that the funds go to them. In fact, we should insist that funds for these refuges are increased so that we have increasing support for these people who are doing a job which is recognised by all sections of the community. It is reasonable for us, as a parliament, to do so in the light of recent history. It is reasonable for us as a parliament to do so in view of some of the statements of the more conservative member of State governments. For this purpose, I foreshadow that in the Committee stage I will move an amendment expressing this Parliament's concern that this should be done. I would like to do this also in regard to funding rape crisis centres and health centres. As these are already funded by State funds it is not appropriate to move such an amendment directly to clauses in this legislation. I believe that the Federal Government should watch at all times what is happening to the funding of these centres and be willing to step in at any time to directly take over and fund these important organisations. If it does not, it will neglect a large number of people in the community. If we do not advance the situation which exists now so that women's refuges in fact are properly funded and are properly looked after, I believe we neglect an important section of the community. I foreshadow that in the Committee stages I, on behalf of the Opposition, will move such an amendment on the assumption, of course, that this most unsatisfactory legislation will pass the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks to the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1981. The Opposition is in support of the Government in regard to this Bill because we support an active local government in Australia and an adequately funded role for local government as an equal partner in the three-tier system of government. Of course we support that. We find ourselves in fundamental disagreement with the policies being pursued by the Fraser Administration. I say that because it is clear that in its desire to wind down the public sector, not only are the States under pressure from the Fraser Government but also local government equally is required to cut back and reduce its services to the Australian people. Whilst this Bill provides machinery to allow local government a 2 per cent share in net personal income tax collection through general revenue assistance, it nevertheless fails to take into consideration the expanding role of local government which is so much a part of the way in which the system of government operates in this country. We support the Government because we believe this is only a first step in the need for government at the national level to encourage a more active Federal government involvement in funding local government generally throughout Australia. We see local government in an expanding role. This piece of legislation is assisting in that process and is not developing that process.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's policy in respect of local government differs considerably from that of the Fraser Government. Firstly, we guarantee that the real level of funds made available for the purchasing power of local government will not fall below that of the previous year. Of course, it has to be recognised that in the Budgets of last year and of this year sufficient funds are not taking into account the level of inflation that is so apparent in our country. Particularly is that so in respect of road making and other essential services provided by local government. In fact, as the statistics show, the rate of increase in those areas is greater by far than the general rate of inflation. Secondly, Labor proposes that 30 per cent of general revenue assistance should be allocated on a per capita basis and 70 per cent on the basis of need as assessed by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The reason is that such a method of distributing payments to local government would take proper account of the principle of equalisation with due regard to the differences in cost disabilities of regions as a result of population structures, area, geography, topography and so on. Thirdly, a Labor Government will provide an additional program of special block grants to areas of need. Surely that should be the basis upon which local government should be assisted by a central government.

There are, as we have said many times in this place, great differences in need between different regions of local government throughout our country. One only has to compare a municipality in a developed area on the north side of Sydney with the developing suburbs on the far western side of Sydney to see the comparisons which we regard ought to be taken into consideration by a national government prepared to accept its national responsibilities. Of course, since we first raised that relevant question some years back we now see that as a result of the direction in which certain policies are being pursued by the Fraser Administration-that is to say, in regions associated with resource development-a new factor is emerging which has not been taken into consideration by the mere passage of this legislation. There now are specific needs in certain areas with expanded industrial activity and population. I refer particularly to those regions which are affected by what is commonly called the resource boom in this country. We well recall the series of articles that have spoken about the problems in Gladstone, for example, and the problems in the Hunter Valley that obviously have occurred and will occur in those regions as a result of private sector activity, initiated in some cases by the Commonwealth Government and in others by State governments. Of course, that pattern has been repeated in a great number of regions throughout Australia.

For a Commonwealth Government not to accept some areas of responsibility of Federal funding for these problems that are occurring is an abdication of responsibility. It is this abdication by an irresponsible government headed by Malcolm Fraser that causes us to be so critical of the Government's general direction. I refer to the migrant intake of some 80,000 to 90,000 per annum. When one relates that intake to the next 20 years or so one sees that one has to recognise the need, therefore, to duplicate our urban infrastructure. Consequently, this can be done only by either a Federal government accepting financial responsibility, by the taxpayers or, in this case, by the ratepayers accepting an undue proportion of the costs involved in that duplication. As we know, of course, the rating system is an unfair form of taxation insofar as it does not have regard to the ability of a person to pay. Rather, it is related in a great majority of cases to the value of the land rather than to income. As a result of policies pursued in Canberra by the Fraser Administration we see very drastic changes taking place in manufacturing activities; the closure of rail services, post offices, banks and other service sector activities. Changes are taking place in our population and in our demography. Changes are taking place on a location basis. We have some responsibility, therefore, as a national government, to take this into consideration.

Local government, therefore, in order to retain its viability, needs to be able to assess both the needs and the potential of the region over which it has responsibility. A sensible government should be able to intervene in these areas not only to enable the areas to fulfil their proper function of government but also to establish a viable and durable employment generating activity. That, of course, is ignored by the Fraser Administration. It is important to have an expanding local government because it is substantially the most labour intensive public sector in our country. Whilst we accept that these locally felt problems require local responses, they also require national responses as they are often problems which are not of local origin, as I have indicated. They are problems that will follow from broader decisions made not only by a Federal government but also by the corporate sector in our society. It is the corporate sector that decides to develop regions as a result of the exploitation of our natural resources. The corporate sector makes decisions based upon the location of an area and upon the nature and scale of investment. These matters are related to economic management into which the local authority has absolutely no input whatsoever, even though it is conceded that the States often are consulted as a result of the major decisions which materially alter a region.

Consequently, the problems to which I refer require co-operative intervention at the different levels of government and the active participation of regional communities. Obviously, if there are to be dramatic changes, such as have taken place in Gladstone, the local communities should be involved. As honourable senators know, the people of that region have just stated that they do not want any more private sector development. The thrust of this Government's approach to inter-government relations, especially between itself and the local level, is merely one involving a flow of money. That is all that this legislation seeks to do. Important as it is to have such funding, it bears no relationship to the problems created as a result of private and public sector activity.

The reductions in specific purpose grants have meant that there has been a reduction in the amount and quality of contract between bureaucrats at the different levels of government. Honourable senators will recall that during the term of the Whitlam Government there was close consultation in regard to the way in which the Grants Commission operated and on input of funds based upon need. Unfortunately, this Government has seen fit to undo practically all of the positive work done then, work which is so essential to a proper relationship between the three arms of government. The national Government has cut itself off from that essential contact which so greatly assists in the designing and implementation of programs that will meet real needs. After all, we are discussing the needs of people.

This Government, in all its philosophical statements, talks of the need for the citizen to have freedom of choice. In so many cases, the citizens of Australia are not consulted at all. They do not enjoy freedom of choice. The choice is made by the captains of industry, the corporate sector, often acting at the behest of Commonwealth or State governments. Thus, in the last few years we have seen the Fraser Government's withdrawal from the responsibility for expenditure in these areas, and a reduction in social services and the provision of social amenities. As a consequence, local government is forced into the position of either allowing services to run down or increasing rates in order to be able to continue to provide them. The problem has reached such dramatic proportions that the Labor Government of New South Wales, as a result of this abdication of responsibility, of the philosophical and ideological position of the Fraser Government, has put a ceiling on the amount of rate increases which local government may impose. The consequence is that local government is labouring under the task of providing an increasing range of services without adequate funds with which to do so. When one looks at what is happening in some of the newly developed areas, one shudders at the way in which citizens of our country are forced to live. Therefore, we are critical of this Government's whole approach to social needs in the majority of local government areas and in regional areas which have become larger and more neglected.

Local government is called upon to meet emergency housing needs, to provide children's services, to care for aged persons and to provide community information services. Hardly a local government authority escapes being called upon to fulfil some of these needs. In the shire in which I live the council is constantly being called upon by its citizens to provide community information services and the wider range of facilities upon which a modern community insists. In a nation that has the reputation of being a lucky country, that is claimed to be one of the richest countries in the world, why is there not a flow-on of these riches down to the grass roots level, so that ordinary people can benefit from the wealth that is being tapped by the corporate sector and especially the multinational companies that are bleeding the country white of the funds that could make possible in every region the provision of adequate community services.

For these reasons, local government authorities must devote a higher proportion of their outlay to the provision of infrastructure associated with resource projects or expanded commercial facilities. A month or six weeks ago, at a seminar conducted in Sydney by the Local Government Association, the problems facing local government, in developing regions in particular, were raised. One could only condemn the spectacle of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) suggesting that local government should tighten its belt and enable funds to be made available to the private sector so that an attractive investment climate could be created. The Treasurer made absolutely no commitment at that important seminar, to the need of local government to become an actual sharing partner in the development of this country.

In recent years we have seen a heavy increase in the borrowing programs of the Federal Government and semi-governmental authorities but in the last few weeks, as honourable senators are aware, the Fraser Government has indicated that the States must cut back on infrastructure borrowing programs which are needed by local government and semi-governmental authorities. The squeeze is now being put on the funds generally available in the country for the provision of these services. I do not believe that this Government really knows where it is going in respect of these matters. A year or two ago it was claiming that Australia was on the verge of a major industrial and economic development of tremendous magnitude. The States took the Prime Minister at his word and began to plan for this great industrial development. But when they reached the stage of beginning to plan, in conjunction with local governments, the provision of the funds needed for the development of the infrastructure for the regions which were such an essential part of the Fraser Government's philosophical position, suddenly we found the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) suggesting-as I understand a submission will be made to the special Premiers Conference of 19 June-that the States should examine the Government's new parameters for infrastructure borrowing with a view to their reducing the amount of borrowing undertaken for that purpose.

If that proposal is to be pursued to the ultimate, as is, I suggest, the policy of the Fraser Government, it will mean that the citizens of newly-developed regions will suffer tremendously from the impact of incorrect policies and will be denied elementary services which they have come to regard as an essential part of the Australian environment. We are being told that borrowings on the domestic capital market have been undertaken in competition with those of larger authorities and corporations. Thus the Government has told State and local governments-which are already experiencing tremendous difficulties-seeking to raise funds in order to carry out works programs, that they should step aside and allow the big corporations to have unlimited access to the domestic capital market.

The high levels of foreign capital inflow in recent times, in the context of the restrictive monetary policy of the Government, have created conditions in the domestic capital market which disadvantage small borrowers, whether home buyers, small businessmen, small farmers or small local government authorities. That may seem to be unusual, but it is not when considered in terms of the Government's basic ideological position. It is always talking about small government but it encourages the development of large corporations. It never talks of small government and small business. Rather, it describes them in contradictory terms.

The smaller local government authorities are experiencing great difficulty in gaining access to finance. The significant aspect of the policies being pursued in Canberra is that the local government authorities are being forced to seek finance at higher interest rates. These are the realities facing local Government authorities throughout our country. But they are realities that this Government either cannot see or chooses to neglect. The economic policies being pursued by this Government are at fault because its whole philosophical and ideological position is untenable from the point of view of the citizens of our cities, regions, shires and municipalities. As much as this legislation seeks to make available a small sum of money, it does nothing more than just maintain the existing sum of money. It does nothing to solve the basic problems facing local government throughout our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill 1981 and the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1981. It has agreed to consider them cognately for the purposes of debate although I understand that questions will be put separately after I have finished my summing up. I wish to respond to some of the points that have been made by honourable senators in the contributions which have been put before the Senate. Over the past five years, the Commonwealth has provided very substantial grants to the States as the figures available in each of the Budget Papers will show. Because of these substantial grants, the Commonwealth has considered it appropriate now to take a far more restrictive approach in 1981-82 to the tax sharing arrangements with the States.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth had wished to discuss this matter with the States at some length. Although the States have argued that there has been insufficient consultation about the arrangements incorporated in the Bill, it is worth noting and putting on the record that a year ago the Commonwealth sought discussions with the States on the arrangements which are being debated today. The States chose, however, to hold their discussions in the absence of the Commonwealth. It was very difficult for the kind of consultation to take place that people say should have occurred. Arising from these discussions, the States presented their views to the Commonwealth in February. The Commonwealth put the view to the States a year ago that it would be more desirable for the Commonwealth to have been present all along but the States chose otherwise. The argument of inadequate consultation is fairly hard to sustain in the light of the events which occurred over the past year or so. Premier Wran rejected the concept of total tax at the Premiers Conference. Most of the other Premiers rejected it also. It could not be denied that in the papers prepared by the States on this matter-the States actually produced some papers-some advantage was seen in the total tax as an aggregate that fluctuated a little less than net personal income tax collections. This matter was considered by the Premiers and had been noted by the Commonwealth.

I think I need to pick up some of the points made by honourable senators. Perhaps I should start with Senator Gietzelt's comments and relate them to the situation facing local government. There is no doubt that, following the program announced, introduced and implemented step by step by this Government, local government in Australia now has a more secure financial base-because of its access to a guaranteed share of personal income tax collections-and is in a more satisfactory position that it has ever been before.

I remind honourable senators of the fairly sharp step by step increase that occurred so that local government now can call upon 2 per cent of personal income tax collections. I make the point that this arrangement has not been disturbed by the new Bills before the Senate. In fact, the continuation of personal income tax collections as the base for local government tax sharing is desirable and, indeed, it should cause no anxiety for a number of reasons. Firstly, our record shows that we have been not only reasonable but also generous in the allocation of funds for local government, especially under those personal income tax sharing arrangements. As I have observed the amount has gone up step by step. It has gone up from 1.52 per cent to 2 per cent and the dollar amount of assistance to local government from the Commonwealth has more than doubled. In 1976-77 it was $140m and it is over $300m in 1980-81.

Secondly, there is evidence to show that, at least in the short term, local government will not be disadvantaged by the arrangements which are proposed and which are continuing. Further to the increases received so far, on the basis of 1980-81 Budget estimates of net personal income tax collections-that, of course, is the basis on which one would try to predict what local government will get next year-it is estimated that the level of Commonwealth tax sharing assistance for local government in the States would increase in the next financial year-that is, 1981-82-by 13.5 per cent to some $341m. Local government faces no disadvantage. While the funding of local government has been a matter of concern for some time to a number of honourable senators, it is in a stronger, more secure, more stable and more satisfactory position now than it has been in the past. This is due to the tax sharing arrangements introduced by the Fraser Government.

Several speakers in this debate have addressed themselves to the new health arrangements. The Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals in Australia found that a major factor behind inefficiencies in State hospitals and related services was the divided responsibility which existed between the Commonwealth and the States. The basis of the new arrangements proposed is that the States will accept their constitutional authority and responsibility for the provision of health services, that they will do this fully and that they will be able to determine their own priorities as to how funds are to be allocated within their global budget and how they are to be allocated between the different parts of the health care system according to the priorities which any State might hold.

If honourable senators accept the Jamison Commission's statement that the way in which we funded the system was one of the reasons for inefficiency, the new proposals can only assist in reducing the level of that inefficiency. Despite what Senator Grimes has said, State Health Ministers did not disagree with the thrust of the new arrangements. The States know full well that the arrangements should provide them with increased resources and increased capacity to make their own Budget decisions. The Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) met with the State Health Ministers on two occasions. The State Health Ministers had every opportunity to express their views. Whilst they were quite vociferous on the question of cash, they did not express an objection to the main thrust of the proposals. The Minister for Health has taken the State Ministers' views back to the Government. Of course, as a result of that, the Government has agreed that a review will be made towards the end of 1981-82 of the assessment of the States' capacity to increase revenue in the light of experience. This again is a reasonable response to doubts which have been expressed by the States. If it is necessary to make any adjustments at that time, it will be possible in the light of experience.

Senator Grimes made an impassioned plea for women's refuges. There is no doubt that they have certainly performed some good work and fulfilled a necessary and previously unfulfilled function. The refuges are part of the health system; they are part of a total system. The States have the responsibility for that system within their own borders. The States will have the capacity to take up that responsibility. Further, the funding of women's refuges is quite considerable. The estimated expenditure in 1980-81 was $5.16m, of which the Commonwealth provided $3.82m and the States provided $1.34m. The Commonwealth's contribution for women's refuges will be included in the total amount of grants to the States for 1981-82 and the calculation for the amount to be allowed for women's refuges will be the 1980-81 figure, escalated by 10 per cent. A very considerable amount of money is being provided to State treasuries in terms of the global allocation. It is up to the States now--

TALK.START.PARA: —What assurance have you that it will be passed on?
—The assurance is that the States themselves have to be answerable for the decisions they make. The amount of money--
—Answerable to whom?

—They have to be answerable to their electors, Senator Georges. The amount of money which was made available this year in relation to women's refuges will be escalated by 10 per cent for 1981-82. It is entirely up to the States whether they choose to allocate more of their own resources to women's refuges. It is entirely up to them to place a priority and to respond to that priority. I say again that the amounts of money provided will be adequate. Because of that-I am just putting the view now so that I will not have to take the time of the Senate later-the amendments proposed to be moved at the Committee stage would defeat the purpose of absorption, which is to enable the States to determine their expenditures as they see fit and to avoid Commonwealth involvement in matters which really are matters for State determination. No specific amount is identified in these Bills for the absorption of women's refuges, but the amount has been included, as I have already pointed out. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate. I indicate that the Government will oppose the amendments to be moved in the Committee stage. I commend the Bills.

—It has been indicated that there is a wish to have the questions in relation to each Bill put separately. Therefore, I now put the question: That the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill 1981 be now read a second time.

The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed, I wish to move an amendment to this legislation. I wish merely to comment on some of the remarks made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) on the general principles behind Part III of the Bill, which has to do with health funding in general, and, in particular, on some of his remarks about the attitude of the States. I merely put on record again, in case Senator Baume did not hear me, the statement of the State Health Ministers which was made on 8 May after the Government had announced its policy. Unanimously they said that they observed that they had never been consulted in the real sense of the word and at no time prior to its recent decision had the Commonwealth indicated any clear intention to the States. Quite apart from that, it is wrong to treat this legislation in isolation from the other health legislation which is to come forward shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: The import of all this legislation is to push people into the private health funds, into private hospitals and into a private hospital scheme. I repeat the Opposition's assertion that there is no way in which that will result in a more efficient use of or reduction in health funds in this country. The Government intends to push people into a fee for service situation. Such a situation exists in the United States, for instance, where health costs as a percentage of gross domestic product are considerably higher than they are in this country. That is the inevitable result of this situation. The States also disagree with the calculations made by the Commonwealth both on base levels and on the amount of money that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) believes will be able to be clawed back under the new fees system.

The Commonwealth claims, through Senator Baume, that it wants to put health back where it should be-back with the States. Yet the Commonwealth is, in fact, directing the States what to charge, where to charge it, how to charge, to put on a means test and how to conduct their health systems. If it were fair dinkum it would just hand the whole thing back to the States, but that is not the situation. I finally say on this matter that we as a party believe that health is a national matter, that the health of the citizens in every corner of this country deserves national attention and that to back away from this situation is quite wrong.

I come to the amendments I will move to clauses 14 and 15 of this legislation which would have the effect of earmarking the amounts paid by the Commonwealth to women's refuges and make sure that they are allocated specifically for that purpose. In this situation we believe there is a special case. Until the period between 1972 and 1975 there were few, if any, women's refuges at all in this country. This Parliament accepted that, in fact, in this situation there was a problem which deserved national attention. There were women in this country who were being forced to stay at home in unsatisfactory environments or who were being forced out of the home into desperate and unsatisfactory situations because of domestic violence and problems in the home. It was not only the Opposition but also people in medical practice and welfare agencies who realised the seriousness of this situation. For that reason funding for women's refuges was introduced.

We are now at the stage where, in fact, some 35,000 women pass through the hundred or so funded refuges in this country. Two-thirds of these women have children. There is no funding to maintain and feed those children. There is a grant from the Office of Child Care to pay in some cases a child care worker some $10,000 a year but, in fact, that funding has remained the same for two years. We have a situation in which certain groups in the community and certain State Governments in the community are extremely hostile on philosophical grounds to the establishment of these refuges. I refer in particular to the Queensland Government which, in the past, has refused to hand on Commonwealth funds and to the Western Australian Government which so restricts any funding it has for these refuges that it makes life very difficult and sometimes impossible for the women who run them.

In spite of the increasing numbers of women's refuges in the community the problems have not diminished. Bashings are increasing. Nine out of 10 women reporting violence claim it is associated with alcohol. Increasing unemployment and increasing economic difficulties in the community all add to the number of problems we have. I repeat that this is recognised by State governments, State government welfare agencies, local government welfare agencies where they exist, and police forces which refer people to the refuges. Because of difficulties in funding in other areas we are getting increasing reports of people referred to the refuges who have, in fact, acute psychiatric problems. Because there is nowhere else for them to go and because they have no families to care for them, people tend to refer these people to refuges which, at the moment, because of their low funding, their inadequate facilities and the strain on the people who are running them, are having difficulties in handling them.

I repeat that I believe almost everyone in this Parliament recognises the work these refuges do. It is important that this Parliament has some national responsibilities for the welfare of women and children in this community. I believe it is quite irresponsible for this Parliament to hand over willy-nilly the funds for women's refuges to State governments-some of whom are hostile to the existence of these refuges-for them to do with it what they will. They need not even hand on the money to refuges. We have a situation in which the Federal Government is the chief money revenue raiser in this community. Yet it will hand over this small, inadequate amount of money to the States without any reasonable control and without any direction as to where these funds will go.

In future years we will find that the same restrictions as have been applied to State funds will apply to the funds for women's refuges, which are one of the success stories-inadequate as the funding is-of Federal initiative in this country. We should not just hand back the matter like this. We must have some national responsibility in this area. I put it to the Minister that this is a particular area which needs assistance. It was a Federal initiative and it should remain a Federal initiative and responsibility. We, as a parliament, who initiated the funding and who have followed up with funding every year, should not just hand over this funding to governments which have demonstrated their hostility in this situation. The amount is the total Federal Budget is, in fact, minuscule. We need to make sure that this one group of people receives our support just as we need to make sure that other disadvantaged groups get the support of the Federal Government. I seek leave to move the two amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 8, clause 14, sub-clause (3), paragraph (b), at end of paragraph add, 'but so that the amounts paid by the Commonwealth in respect of women's refuges are allocated specifically for that purpose'.
Page 8, clause 15, sub-clause (3), at end of sub-clause add, 'but so that the amounts paid by the Commonwealth in respect of women's refuges are allocated specifically for that purpose'.

I move those amendments to ensure, firstly, that every State government fulfils its responsibility and, secondly, to make sure that we fulfil the responsibility we have taken for the last six or seven years for this important group of people in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments moved by my colleague Senator Grimes. In doing so I remind the Senate of a debate that took place in the Senate in May 1979. In that month we on this side proposed an urgency debate on women's shelters, support for women's shelters, the need for them and the need for more of them. On that occasion the Government agreed with us that women's shelters were a very necessary part of our community and that they deserved and should have continuing Federal Government support. I remind the Senate of remarks made by the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: This shows that the Government recognises the need for women's refuges, recognises with alarm-as I think Senator Coleman put it-the increasing need for provision of such refuges in order to help people who are in distress, in danger or in terror, as well as children who are subjected to what is widely-spread abuse. No-one would argue against those propositions and I think the Government has shown its consideration for the program by developing it to the extent that I have mentioned and by providing funds in a way in which it has.
The Government understood in that debate that in two States there was a problem of commitment. Knowing even that, the Minister went on to say:

However, as far as women's refuges are concerned, their increased development and the continuing and growing support that has been given to them by the Federal Government would lead everyone to understand that the Government recognises the need for them and that it must provide substantial funds to continue their existence.
I repeat the last phrase:
. . . and that it must provide substantial funds to continue their existence.

What has happened in the meantime? On 29 May 1979 the Government showed some commitment to the need for womens' refuges and to the role it must play in relation to them; yet here we are in June 1981 and the Government is moving out of all responsibility for women's refuges-leaving them to the States-knowing as it does that some States have no commitment to women's refuges. In fact, some have a less than realistic commitment to women's refuges. It was not just Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle who supported us then. Senator Walters on that day also supported us in our move to have women's refuges and the need for them declared urgent. Senator Walters said:
The need is certainly there. I could not agree more with Senator Melzer.
She went on to say:

I feel that the debate today has been initiated in an attempt to cause concern for the people administering the shelters and that this is completely wrong. This Government has recognised the necessity for shelters. Government funding has increased to the extent that in the 1978-79 Budget nearly $3m was allocated for these shelters. Those people who are administering the shelters should be well satisfied that the Government is now showing some concern for them.

I ask again: What has happened between 29 May 1979 and June 1981? Are women's refuges any less essential now than they were then? Is there any less need for them now than there was then? Suddenly there is no care that refuges be maintained at a time when they are needed more than they have ever been needed previously. Refuges cannot be designated just as a part of the health system. They cannot be left to the whim of the States. They are too important for the mental and physical health of women and children in this country. What will be the outcome of the Government opting out of its direct role in women's refuges? It will mean that if a few dollars are left over in some States, they will go to women's refuges and that in some States no money at all will be put into women's refuges. We all know that. Yet members of the Government sit there calmly and say: 'It is now a matter of the States making up their own minds as to how they spend their money'. The Federal Government is just opting out of any responsibility whatever.

What will be the outcome? We all know what the outcome will be. There will be more injured, hurt women. More women's lives will be ruined, physically and mentally. There will be more injured children. This is happening at a time when there is more unemployment, more poverty and more pressure on people than there has ever been in this country before. With more poverty, more unemployment and more pressure come more problems. Women find themselves in situations that they cannot physically stand up to, that they cannot mentally put up with any more. They have to get out of such situations. Where are they to go now? We know that the States are finding it difficult to balance their Budgets. We know that this Federal Government is forcing the States into a position in which they will not have sufficient funds to carry out all the programs that they know are needed. The Federal Government, knowing that there is a greater need for refuges, knows too that the States will be unable to cope with this problem of providing refuges for women. I feel it is time that this Government showed some real commitment to women's problems and, knowing that the States do not have the same commitment, took the matter into its hands and did something about it.

Some of my colleagues on both sides of the Parliament were shocked that women should demonstrate as they have done in the last two weeks. I put it to honourable senators that women have been put into a position in which they can do very little else. They have been polite. They have handed in petitions, they have written letters, they have gone to see members of parliament and nothing has happened. They have put a case to the Government for refuges. The Government has accepted that there is a case for women's refuges, that they are a necessary part of our lives today. Unpalatable as that fact may be, it has been accepted that they are necessary; yet the Government opts out altogether. Honourable senators opposite are shocked that women should sit out there in King's Hall making a noise, trying to attract people's attention to this very real problem. I suggest that if the Government does not take heed of what has happened up until now, it is likely to have to face up to more demonstrations. People will have to take it more into their own hands to drag this Government, screaming though it may be, to the point where it has to recognise that the money it spends or does not spend on refuges is not its money, but our money. It is money that belongs to the people of this country. The people of this country have demonstrated very forcibly that they believe women's shelters are needed. They have demonstrated that they will demand that governments such as this Federal Government fund refuges.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Ryan. I ask her to ignore the interjections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by my colleague, Senator Grimes, and supported so ably by my colleague, Senator Melzer. At this stage of the debate I simply wish to say that the Federal Government's decision to offload the responsibility for women's refuges-rape crisis centres and women's health centres have already been offloaded to the States-is indefensible in any terms. It is indefensible in terms of cost. As Senator Grimes has said, the cost of funding women's refuges has been absolutely minuscule in terms of the total Federal Government. Last year 96 per cent of Commonwealth funded refuges received between them less than $3m. So the cost saving, if that were to be put forward by the Government and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) as a justification for this abrogation of responsibility, is laughable.

SPEECH.PARA: Cost saving ought not to be put forward as any kind of justification for the decision to rid the Government's area of responsibility of women's refuges. In terms of administrative efficiency-something that the Government thinks it is concerned about and pretends it will achieve through many of the decisions of the razor gang-there is no case to be made. What happens, as honourable senators opposite may not know-I hope they know; I hope they have acquainted themselves with how refuges work-is that an unceasing demand is made by various bureaucracies on the women working within refuges to present their accounts in a certain way, to put in submissions, to adapt submissions and to change submissions. Generally speaking, women who work in refuges, often on a voluntary basis and certainly on an underpaid basis, spend a great deal of their time, instead of counselling, helping and advising the women and children who are the victims of domestic violence, in trying to meet the various bureaucratic demands that are put to them. What will happen as a result of the Federal responsibility going to the States is that women working in refuges will have a whole fresh series of demands placed upon them. There will be a whole new fresh series of bureaucracies that they must satisfy in order to show that the tiny amount of money they are receiving for these essential services is in fact being spent on these services. I believe that the bureaucratic problems will increase and that the administration of refuges will become even more complex. There is no cost saving or administrative efficiency to be achieved.

Why is the Federal Government doing this? In trying to answer that question we must look at the record of the States and the Northern Territory in regard to refuges and other priceless services for women. In the Northern Territory, which I visited in February of this year, there is now no crisis service at all for women. There was a women's health service and a women's refuge in Alice Springs. There was a rape crisis centre in Darwin and some rape crisis counselling was provided in Alice Springs. All of that has gone because the Northern Territory Administration is hostile to the whole aim of women's crisis services. Similarly, in Western Australia and Queensland, ever since the Fraser Government was elected and there was some withdrawal from direct funding of women's crisis services, there has been a battle to maintain services and a number of services have gone under. In the States where there is support for women's refuges and women's crisis services-the States of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania-those States have had to struggle to provide a whole range of health and community services. Women's refuges, women's health centres and rape crisis centres are just not going to able to compete with the much better organised, much larger services that will be struggling for their share of the health services cake.

Undoubtedly the direct result of the Federal Government withdrawing from direct responsibility for women's refuges is that many women's refuges will fail to operate. I do not need to go over the consequences of that for battered women and children because my colleague Senator Melzer has, I think, very adequately described those consequences. But I point to the hypocrisy on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) with regard to the funding of these programs. A women's services delegation saw the Prime Minister last week and proposed the establishment of a new women's services program, administered federally by one department and funded with a special purpose grant. Such a proposal has the support of the Federal Labor Party. The Prime Minister turned down the proposal. Instead he offered to write to the State Premiers supporting women's services programs. Considering Mr Fraser's current disastrous relationships with State governments, this step is unlikely to achieve anything at all for women. I point to the hypocrisy of a Government which on the one hand attempts to attract international kudos by signing the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women overseas, while on the other hand at home cuts back on women's services.

Of course, not only has the Government left women's services in the lurch but also it has abolished all existing women's units in Commonwealth departments. This leaves the one remaining unit concerned with women's affairs-the Office of Women's Affairs-without accurate advice on what Commonwealth Government decisions mean for women. I ask the Minister: Now that the women's unit within the Department of Health and the women's consultative committee within the Department of Social Security have been abolished, how will the Federal Government get information as to what is happening with women's refuges in the States? What direct monitoring will there be of what was a Federal program, as my colleague Senator Grimes described it? How will there be any feedback at all to the Federal Government as to what is happening with women's refuges and what is happening with rape crisis centres and women's health centres? There will be none. Not only has the Federal Government withdrawn from direct funding but also has it disbanded those advisory units, those policy units within its bureaucracy, which may have been in a position to monitor what was happening to women and children and to give this information to the Federal Government. So it is a complete abrogation of responsibility. It is one which, as I have said, is indefensible.

I hope that, at the Committee stage of the debate, it is not too late for senators sitting opposite to give serious consideration to the amendments moved by my colleague, Senator Grimes, and to support him. In doing so, I believe that they will only be making good many promises and many undertakings given to women by the Federal Government. They will only be acting in accordance with their stated policy of equal opportunity for women and special programs for women in need. They will not be doing anything contrary to their stated policy. They will not be doing anything other than supporting the best of causes. They will be doing something to retrieve this Government's appalling reputation with regard to consideration for disadvantaged women and children in this community. I urge that course of action upon senators sitting opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to foreshadow a further amendment. I will not keep the Senate long. I consider that all honourable senators realise that there is a need for the provision of substantial funds for women's refuges. I certainly do. Anyone who is involved in community activity knows that certain situations occur in which women and children are terrified and some refuge for those victims needs to be provided. Equally, it is necessary that the women's refuges deserve, and act in a way so that they can attract, public support. The public needs to be confident that women and their children who, when faced with a crisis and are terrified out of their wits, are given compassionate understanding support and are not subject to political indoctrination. All of us here are grown men and women. We know over a period that circumstances have arisen in certain women's refuges where there is political indoctrination. That is a major facet in some of the refuges.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a question that I asked the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, wherein I mentioned an advertisement which was placed in the 'positions vacant' column in the Age by the Victorian Western Region Women's Refuge. It stated:
The refuge operates as a feminist collective, and the positions involve organising political actions around women's issues, as well as co-ordinating the day-to-day running of the house.

That is the type of thing that I think the public should be assured that women who are in this crisis situation are not subjected to. The last thing that a woman in such a crisis position wants is political indoctrination. I feel that the amendment that I will move-actually, it is an addendum to the Opposition's amendments-gives recognition to the fact that a substantial amount of money needs to be put aside for this purpose but that it should be done so as to attract public support and confidence. As an amendment to Senator Grimes's amendments relating to clause 14 sub-clause (3) and clause 15, sub-clause (3), I move:

At the end of the words proposed to be inserted (in each case), add ', namely women's refuges which cater for women and children in emergency situations and do not subject their occupants to political indoctrination'.
If my amendment is agreed to, the relevant portion of Senator Grimes's amendments will read:

But so that the amounts paid by the Commonwealth in respect of women's refuges are allocated specifically for that purpose, namely, women's refuges which cater for women and children in emergency situations and do not subject their occupants to political indoctrination.

Finally, I believe that that proposition ought to be acceptable all round. I can see the argument which is put forward by the Government that perhaps the States are in closer contact with the situation, for example, people who work in departments of social welfare at State level and in the police departments. I can see their argument that the State governments need to have control over the situation. I can see also the argument that, if there is public support for and confidence in refuges and if the funding of same is in the hands of the State government, there is more direct influence by the people of that State over the State government. I can understand that argument. But I still feel that if the Commonwealth Government sees its way clear to ensure that the payments are made in accordance with the proposition that I am putting forward-it has not up to this point-I think that we should all support the amendment moved by the Opposition with my addendum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek clarification on a procedural matter. In which order will you deal with the amendments?
—I will put Senator Harradine's amendment first. Senator Grimes's amendments are being taken together. Senator Grimes sought and secured leave to have them dealt with together.
—I take it that if Senator Harradine's amendment is agreed to we will then vote on the amendments as a whole?
—Yes.

—I am fascinated by Senator Harradine's suggestion. I wonder whether he can explain to us who would make the decision as to whether there was political indoctrination at the various shelters. It would be a very difficult task, I should imagine, because it would all be in the eye of the beholder. Perhaps what Senator Harradine and I would call political indoctrination would be totally different from what perhaps Senator Grimes would call political indoctrination.
—Or me.

—Or Senator Georges. I would find it extremely difficult to write this into legislation. Perhaps Senator Harradine could explain whether the Department of Health or the Director-General of Health would make such a judgment. I understand what Senator Harradine is getting at because he and I have taken exception to the discriminatory nature of some of the advertisements which have been put forward. Indeed, the then Minister for Health informed one of the shelters that was responsible for putting out these advertisements that if the advertisements were continued there would be no funding for the shelter. I feel that the suggestion has merit but I cannot imagine how it could ever be implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some strange way, I find myself on the side of Senator Walters in respect of this tiny item, but let me say first of all that I share Senator Harradine's view that women who go into shelters are in a vulnerable position and a difficult position and, because they are vulnerable, I believe they should not be subject to proselytising of any kind, whether it is political, religious or whatever. I have always expressed that view. I have expressed that view at Estimates committee hearings in this place. I believe that Senator Harradine is trying to introduce a very dangerous principle into Commonwealth funding. He proposes to insert the words 'namely, women's refuges which cater for women and children in emergency situations'-I suggest they all do that-'and do not subject their occupants to political indoctrination'. Who on earth is to make that sort of judgment? Is it to be the bureaucracy? Is it to be someone in the Department of Health?

SPEECH.PARA: Is it to be the situation that because someone who is deeply involved in a political party is also involved in a refuge that refuge will not be funded, whether the person is in the Australian Labor Party or, as in the north of Tasmania, a prominent member of the Liberal Party? Are we to refuse funding only to those people whose views oppose the views of the government of the day so that we will have musical chairs in the funding of women's refuges over and over again as governments change? What would be the situation if the Queensland Government, for instance, had control of the funding of refuges and it had to make the judgment as to whether a refuge was a politically associated refuge or involved in political indoctrination? What would happen if a staff member of a refuge was working on a booth for a political party or wearing a badge for a political party at election time? I suggest it is a very dangerous principle to introduce into legislation that someone be given the right to make such a judgment about the politics of a refuge. Does it mean that people who run a refuge cannot take political action to try to get governments to increase their funding or the direction of their funding?

I think it is unfortunate that Senator Harradine has introduced this sort of element into amendments which are merely trying to ensure that the national government maintains responsibility for a program it started and that the national government supports a series of organisations which would fulfil a need which obviously was unfulfilled in the past. Only a week or so ago Senator Ryan and I were subjected to some criticism, and pretty trenchant criticism, from women who were demonstrating on behalf of women's refuges. In that situation are we to say that because these people disagree with us politically and because they are taking political action to try to improve the position of their refuges, we should refuse them funding? I do not believe anyone should be given the right to make that sort of judgment and I suspect that people who want the right to make that sort of judgment should be the last ones to be given it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments which have been moved by Senator Grimes. I would like to make the point that if we had women and children who were refugees from a foreign country it would be the Federal Government's responsibility to give them shelter, support services and health services. Yet we have women and children in our own country who are also refugees from violence and the Federal Government says that it does not have that responsibility. In Victoria alone, on average, 15 families are turned away from a shelter every day. We do not know how many there are in other States. It is disgraceful that any woman and her child or children in our country should be turned away from the shelter that she seeks. Many of these women have lived with and known terror and the sheer panic of fear and emotional, physical and mental violence over a long period. It is damaging to their children; it is damaging to themselves. Not only do we need more money for refuges but also we need money to investigate the causes of the breakdowns in families and the causes of the violence. This violence is often the result of financial and social pressures. These pressures are caused by the insecurity which the present Government's policies are producing. I think we must look not only at the fact that shelters must continue but also the fact that they are a federal Government responsibility, as are the causes of the need for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I say to Senator Hearn that already a considerable amount of money is being spent on research in the area of family breakdowns. The honourable senator may not be aware that a program has already been set up.
—It is not sufficient to prevent breakdowns.

—But the honourable senator said that some money ought to be given. A research section attached to the Family Court is already carrying out research into the area of family breakdowns. It has not been established for very long. It was set up only in the past 12 months. It has been established by my Government. It is an area in which I believe a lot of work has already been done and a lot more is yet to be done. In response to the comments made by Senator Hearn is some States things are much worse than they are in other States, I agree with her and I think this is a very good argument for handing this responsibility to the States. The money is being handed across to the States. Let there be no mistake about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: 'That the amendment moved by Senator Harradine to the amendments moved by Senator Grimes be agreed to'.

—Mr Chairman, with your indulgence, I believe that just prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, Senator Walters was making some comments on this issue and I had intended to follow her in the debate.

—Mr Chairman, I had just about completed my comments. I was pointing out that the Institute of Family Studies had been instigated to do research into family breakdowns. I then went on to comment that Senator Hearn, I think it was, had said that the various States needed different emphasis and that different States required various numbers of refuges. It was this point that I was taking up with her. I was saying that that is why I believe that while the Federal Government hands full funding to the States as it has done in the past the States are best able to cope with this matter themselves and to come up with their own priorities.
