They can use as much money as the Federal Government can give them. In fact, they can use more. But that is up to the States. I see no problem and I really do not understand why the shelters should be concerned in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to comment on the amendment moved by Senator Harradine because I am concerned that it says:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the words proposed to be inserted (in each case), add ', namely women's refuges which cater for women and children in emergency situations and do not subject their occupants to political indoctrination'.

The whole amendment appears to be based on an advertisement which was placed, I understand, in one of the Tasmanian newspapers and which talks about an assistant at a refuge who can cater for the needs of the people in the refuge as well as motivating political actions. To my mind, there is a big difference in the meaning of the words 'indoctrination' and 'actions'. I would think that a lot of work being done at refuges would be political. But it does not necessarily apply that it is political indoctrination. For instance, the gaining of legal aid for people in refuges and in the refuge situation could be seen as being a political action, but surely it could not possibly be seen as a political indoctrination. To my mind, getting advice on how to go about getting supporting parent's benefit would be political action; and it would not necessarily be political indoctrination.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would really be social rights action, would it not?

—It certainly would. But the advertisement which is the basis for the amendment which has been moved by Senator Harradine talks about political indoctrination, whereas the advertisement that I saw and which I asked Senator Harradine to show me talks about political actions, political activity. I am just suggesting that a number of situations in a refuge could be considered to be politically active but they may not necessarily amount to political indoctrination.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things which concern me is that in West Australia at the moment about eight refuges are operating. We are turning away about 1,500 women and children each year. I have given the figures in this chamber. I gave them in the urgency motion which I moved in May 1979 and I repeated them some weeks ago. We are turning away more than 1,500 women and children each year. My concern is that if the Government does go ahead and hand over this responsibility to the States and the States do not give it a sufficiently high enough priority, we will not get the necessary extra refuges that we need and we will not get additional funding for the refuges we have already. We have a situation in West Australia which perhaps is unique, which perhaps does not apply in any other State; I do not know. But I am vitally concerned that the women who work those refuges and who see the needs in the community and the people who use the services of the refuges should have their needs satisfied. I have to vote against Senator Harradine's amendment because it talks about political indocrination and, like Senator Grimes, I would not put myself in the position of being a judge of what is political indoctrination and what is not; where we could have this pussy-footing around where a government may fund a refuge one year because it is politically motivated in the same manner as the Government but the refuge is not funded in the next session of Parliament purely and simply because the Government has changed in the meantime.

I support the amendments moved by my colleague Don Grimes because I believe that the funding of refuges is a federal government responsibility. It was introduced as a federal government responsibility. The Federal Government claimed responsibility for it in answering my urgency motion on 29 May 1979. It should not have changed its mind because the situation has not changed. If anything, the situation in each State has become worse. More people are subject to social stress now than there were in 1979. More family units-women with children-require the use of refuges and more refuges and more funds should be made available to them. The amount of money spent last year is trifling if we look at it in the context of the entire Budget. We are talking about less than $3m to fund the 96 refuges already operating. If we were talking about $30m it still would not be a great amount of money if, in fact, that money were being spent on relieving social pressures and on providing people with a service to cater for their needs. We are talking at this point about a very small amount. The Federal Government should not be relinquishing its responsibility in this area. It is the Federal Government's responsibility on a national basis; it is not just something that can be handed over to the Bjelke-Petersens or the Sir Charles Courts of this world.

Direct funding was given by the Federal Government to two Queensland refuges because of the situation that arose in Queensland within perhaps the last three years. That money was allocated to the Queensland Government specifically for two refuges. But it was not given to them. The Queensland Government knows what that money was spent on; I do not know what it was spent on. When Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was Minister for Social Security she made a specific point of giving a direct grant to those refuges to ensure that they were funded. One has to question what will be the situation in Queensland if Mr Bjelke-Petersen is asked to fund the additional refuges which have sprung up over the last few years. Is he then going to say: 'They are of no concern to me'? He was given money in 1978, I believe it was, to fund those refuges but refused to do so. Are we now to ask the women and children in need in the Queensland community to go without the services of a refuge just because the Federal Government does not want to accept the responsibility it should be accepting?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman--
—Mr Chairman--
—I call Senator Georges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should not have intercepted the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume)--
—That is quite okay.

—I would have liked to hear what the Minister had to say. I am speaking to the proposition and in so doing I would like to have heard what the Minister had to say because I believe he would find himself in a very difficult position tonight, considering the position he has taken in the past concerning these refuges and the fact that it is possible that if he were not now so constrained by Cabinet or ministerial solidarity that he would be speaking in defence of the proposition. That is a little unfair, I know, but I am afraid that I have to drive it home.
—Anyone would think that we were withdrawing funding.
—The Government side, with the exception of Senator Walters, has been mute on this.
—Anyone would think that we were withdrawing funding, the way you are carrying on.

—The Government is. In fact what the Government is doing in Queensland is withdrawing funding. It is as simple as that. That is what we are arguing about. This action which places responsibility on the States, as far as Queensland is concerned, puts impossible conditions on the people who organise and run the refuges. The situation in Queensland is that the assistance that the women can give to themselves is limited. It is far more limited than it is in the other States. It is unfortunate that the Queensland Government has applied a condition that the women should raise 12.5 per cent--
—They do in Western Australia, too, senator.
—Well, in Western Australia the situation is the same as that in Queensland so we have two States, which makes the Federal Government doubly at fault.
—They have to raise it before they get the other funds.

—Sure; and they have to raise $1 to get $8. It is practically impossible for these people, in the impoverished conditions in which they find themselves, to raise $1. If these people commit all their time to care for women and children in crisis situations, they will have little time to raise funds which will enable them to get further funds. The raising of $1 in order to receive $8 is an impossible burden.

SPEECH.PARA: We are saying that the Federal Government in this area-we are not arguing about the other areas, although we could put a case-should continue to accept responsibility. I believe that there is more humanity and concern in this place than in the Queensland Parliament. We know the nature, record and background of the Queensland Parliament in this respect. I cannot speak for Western Australia; I am merely speaking for Queensland. It seems to me that by supporting these amendments we can be assured that the Federal Government will have a direct commitment to support these services which are provided by women for themselves in crisis situations. I will not go into the details because Senator Melzer and others have spoken very clearly on this matter.

I recommend that the editorial writer in the Canberra Times on Friday of last week should print the speech Senator Melzer made today. There was far more understanding and sympathy in one phrase of Senator Melzer's speech than in the whole of the editorial which I considered to be very inhuman. It showed no understanding of the problems these women faced. It was more concerned with the respectability of Parliament than it was for the problems of these people. It failed to realise that this Parliament has failed to earn the respect of its constituents especially those from this group. The editorial writer ought to look at the speeches made in this place today. Let me reinforce what others have said. Already an impossible condition is imposed in Queensland. There are limitations as to the type of refuges. The attitude of the Queensland Government is to send these people to institutions which have no proper understanding and cannot properly solve the problems with which this group is very conversant.

In the last few days some of us, by the action of these women, have been fronted with the facts. Fortunately the authority of this place which refused people entry on occasions has been relaxed because of the pressure of members of parliament from both sides. This has enabled some of us to talk, to receive information and to understand. I have had experience, as I have explained before, of the conditions under which people are held in Queensland in watchhouses and in the solitary areas of Boggo Road gaol. I know that the conditions in the watchhouses are bad enough, but two instances which were related to me in the previous week shocked me. Women who had been sexually assaulted were brought under the notice of the police and confined as if they were the criminals. They were held in the watchhouse in conditions which, to say the very least, limit one's feedom considerably. Those people were held and treated as the guilty parties. It seems to me that the need for crisis centres in Queensland is very great. What I have described happened on two occasions last week-not two years ago. These women had nowhere else to go. They had no resort to the assistance that appears to be available in New South Wales.

It seems to me that I have been very remiss in my responsibilities in not knowing that those conditions existed. Because of that I am now eager to redress those shortcomings. I can see that, by this very legislation, any endeavour on my part will fail; I now have to deal with the Queensland Government. My experience of the Queensland Government is that it is not responsive to the needs of these people. I would be wasting my time if I were to make representations, but if I were to go to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) I know I would get a hearing; I know that I would get sympathy-but he would be limited by the fact that he could not fund directly.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have to go to the Minister for Health, not the Minister for Social Security.
—I will go to the Minister for Health.
—That is better; as long as you know where you are going.

—I will go to the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and get a sympathetic hearing. If I put a case I do not doubt that in special circumstances some funding would be made for special refuges. If an emergency arose because of a shortage of funds it would be possible for me to make representations, supported by other colleagues, to get assistance; but under this legislation, if not amended, I have Buckley's chance.
—You underestimate, Senator.

—In Queensland, members of the Opposition have little chance of getting any sympathy or understanding. That is a cold, hard fact of the primitive, provincial and frontier type of politics in Queensland. It is so bad in Queensland that if a person resigns his position as a teacher to face the people as a candidate for the Australian Labor Party he does not get his job back if unsuccessful. There is a person called Bill Wood who I remember in particular--
—And Mal Colston.

—And Mal Colston; but I refer in particular to Bill Wood who stood as a Labor candidate. That was the end of him, economically, in Queensland. We could talk about a person called Sinclair who with the support of others was responsible for saving Fraser Island. That person has been completely disadvantaged. Are honourable senators telling me that I can go to the Queensland Minister for Health and say 'There is an emergency here; further funds need to be provided' and be successful? I would have Buckley's chance. In fact, if I were to make such a representation there would be less chance.
—You are meant to be referring to women's refuges; come on.
—I am talking on the subject of women's refuges. If the Minister wants to take a point of order I will handle that as well.
—The amendment makes representations on behalf of them.

—I am speaking to the amendment which will enable me to make representations to the relevant Federal Minister and Department rather than having to go to the Queensland Government. My experience, on a number of occasions, is that although funds have not been anywhere near sufficient, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, has been sympathetic and a response has been made immediately. Let us accept it. I know what Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's feelings are on this matter. Why does she not accept the amendment? If she cannot accept the amendment, why do we not report progress and she can make representation to the Cabinet, suggesting that there may be some good reason to accept the amendment and for the Government to fund this crisis area directly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Byrne Sen The Hon J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am constrained to enter this debate because I feel that we have reached a new dimension in the need for the basic Christian principle, the morality of comforting the afflicted. We are living at a time when we have developed a certain consciousness that aged people, invalids, quadriplegics, paraplegics and others in the community can accept their case and maintenance as a right. The Commonwealth Government has accepted that responsibility. While we were in government, we saw a growing need to finance refuges for women. I can remember then women had only one place to go, and that was to the wash house or the poor house. Men have always asserted and have been granted superiority in the home. Women had to bear whatever the consequences were in the home because of the risk that if they left they would be seen to be the guilty person. But society has now become brutalised by the selfish, aggressive system under which we live. Everyone gets in for his cut and the devil takes the hindmost. The victim in this society is so often the woman and the mother. It is no great request to ask the Commonwealth Government to continue with the established precedent that has been created whereby it finances this phenomenon of the neglected, the bashed and brutalised wife. Someone has to take up the cudgels and look to this responsibility. The effect of the way in which the new federalism works-it is an entirely different element-is that the meat in the sandwich are these people. The States are being cut to the extent that they cannot afford the growing charges that will arise in this society as a result of the growing need for these services.
—What rot.
—Senator Walters is contorting herself. She knows, as a woman, the need for refuges. She cannot deny it.
—I could not agree with you more.
—How many hundreds are there that one cannot do anything for because there is no room for them?
—I did not know you had so little faith in the Premier of your State.

—Senator Walters is so hard-hearted. She is so privileged that she would not understand what happens in a drunken, brutal home from which a woman is forced. She would not know the first thing about it. She represents people of her own class in Tasmania, and the will vote against this very deep social need. It appals me to think how badly she represents the people of Tasmania when she sits there, says nothing, and does not join in a debate as this to put up a case for this new dimension that I speak about. I will not listen to her because her interjections are inane. People are forced to leave their homes because of brutality, the frustrations of unemployment, the lack of hope for the future of men, the inability of people to cope with the enormous effects of social, political and economic pressures. All these deep psychological side effects are released in the home. As a result, society has to look at this great problem of supplying a refuge for every person in the community who is aflicted by this phenomenon.

SPEECH.PARA: All that this amendment is asking the Government to do is not to pass the buck, as it is doing in so many areas under this airy fairy thing called federalism. It is handing problems back to the States to deal with. It gives the resultant savings to the multinationals. That is what all federalism is about-divide and rule. I assure honourable senators that history will prove that what I am saying is right. The Government is too blind, blinkered or purblind even to understand this, but it is true. This philosophy is a false one. The Friedman-Ayn Rand philosophy is a false philosophy. It is destined to fail. We have to make provision for the victims of this philosophy in the interim until a new system, a new order and a new approach are established and a more sympathetic, benevolent and kindly group of people are running the exchequer. I appeal to the Committee to take this view. It is within our power to tell the Treasury and the bureaucrats that this is not just a run of the mill matter. It is a deep, moral and social problem that has to be treated separately. It is bad enough to have the aged and invalid pensioners on the borderline. This is an area that needs the closest scrutiny to determine how we are to cope with it. It is bigger than people realise. If one has close contact with people who go to the refuges-their last resort-one sees the hopelessness of the situation when they arrive, the rockbottom nature of their depravity of mind and the degradation of human beings.

Here we are arguing about the importance of this matter. I think that the Committee will be judged as recreant if it does not do something about this now. This is not a States matter. The States have never had the responsibility before. The Commonwealth took it up as the situation developed and took on the responsibility of supplying funds for these refuges. We are duty bound and morally bound to continue to pay it. I hope that, as Senator Georges suggested, we report progress and push this matter right back to where it belongs and have a new look at it. The subject is so important that those who follow us will judge us as being callous and indifferent to human needs if we do not do something at this moment. This legislation is about to be dealt with by numbers-the old cynical, hypocritical numbers game that arises at election time and, when one gets the numbers, everyone else can jump in the lake. The appeal that I make at this time is one directed to decency and to morality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of honourable senators have spoken to the amendment. I believe that all have expressed support for the principle of having women's refuges. No section of honourable senators has a monopoly of that concern.
—Why don't you do something about it?

—It is worth noting that this Government has been a major supporter of funding for women's refuges. The subvention by the Commonwealth for that purpose in the last year of the Labor Government's term of office amounted to $678,000. Last year the Commonwealth's subvention amounted to $3.8m.
—The Labor Party started them.

—Senator Grimes says that the Labor Party started the refuges. I acknowledge that it did. I am simply saying that the need for women's refuges, for the provision of refuge for those who are suffering the kinds of conditions that have been decribed by Senator O'Byrne, is recognised on both sides of the chamber. That is not the argument tonight. It is one about where the funding should be administered, where the authority should rest. In winding up the second reading debate I indicated that the Government would not accept the amendments moved by Senator Grimes and I will not repeat the arguments then advanced. I simply assure the Senate that the Government believes that the funding of women's refuges rests properly at State level. I remind the Senate of the report produced by Mr Peter Bailey, I believe, in 1976, in which he drew a distinction between welfare programs having to do with income maintenance and those having to do with the provision of services. The general principle that those which deal with services are better administered closer to the people is being applied here. It is not correct to say that the States have no role, or have had no role, in the funding of women's refuges. They have had an administrative role thoughout. I have before me the annual report of the Commonwealth Director-General of Health for 1979-80, at page 60 of which Dr Howells says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in all States except Western Australia, Commonwealth funding is channelled to women's refuges through the State welfare authorities. Only in Western Australia is the health authority responsible for refuges.

What emerges is that in every State a State instrumentality is responsible for the administration of the funds. I repeat, the amount being provided this year is to be increased by 10 per cent for the purpose of computing the amount next year. That additional return will be included in the money which the States may use. I refer to States such as Tasmania, New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia, indeed to all the States.

On 28 May, following a meeting with representatives of women's refuges, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) communicated with all Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory concerning the continued funding of such refuges.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not worth the paper it is written on, and you know it.
—How about some money?

—I would like to be able to continue my remarks. He sought specifically the co-operation of the States and of the Northern Territory in the allocation of funds by them to ensure that the needs of women's refuges are met. I repeat, the amount that the Government will be providing next financial year will be greater than that provided this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister also informed the Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory of the Commonwealth's intention to review existing programs of crisis accommodation and to consider the possibility of bringing them together under an integrated, flexible program. The Prime Minister sought the co-operation of the States and the Northern Territory in this review, which will include consideration of women's refuges. What we have is simply a clash of two views of government, one which says that things can be done better by central funding and responsibility, and another which says that in this area it can be done better by the States, which are closer to the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has never been shown that they are done better in that way.

—I am trying to make this an argument that is free of passion. I repeat, two sets of values are involved, one which says that State administration is more appropriate and one which says that such services should be centrally funded through the Commonwealth. The Government adheres to its position and therefore is not willing to accept the amendments moved by the Opposition. That leaves for consideration the amendment moved by Senator Harradine, which has been rejected by Senator Grimes and, I believe, Senator Georges. Since we are going to oppose the amendments, it is quite inappropriate for us to support Senator Harradine's wording and, if carried, vote against it when we vote against the Opposition's amendments. It simply would not be a consistent position for the Government to take. Senator Walters has already pointed to some of the practical difficulties involved in Senator Harradine's amendment. I appreciate the point that the honourable senator makes and the difficulties which have arisen in the administration of some of the refuges where an undue amount of propaganda has been present. I am aware that some refuges lost their funding some years ago when certain difficulties arose, but most have done a useful, important and vital job. Most of those refuges with which I have been associated are ones that I would want to see continued. I ask Senator Harradine to accept the Government's assurance that in not supporting his amendment it is not rejecting the concern that he has expressed. Since the Government intends to vote against the Opposition's amendments it would not be appropriate for it to support any of the amendments before the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only to reply on one or two matters which have been raised in respect of the addendum which I have moved to the Opposition's amendments. I emphasise that it is an addendum. There seems to be general acceptance of the view that the last thing persons who seek refuge need is political indoctrination.
—Any indoctrination.

—Senator Grimes says: 'Any indoctrination'. Let me deal with that straight away, for it seems to have been the burden of his argument. I think his words were: 'If not political indoctrination, why not religious or other indoctrination?' Frankly, over a period representations have been made to me on the subject of political indoctrination in refuges. None have been made to me about religious indoctrination, nor have I heard of any taking place. If Senator Grimes has any organisation or refuge in mind it is for him to get up and say so. There are people running refuges who are motivated by the high Christian principles that Senator O'Byrne mentioned-those of compassion and of comforting the afflicted. If any honourable senator is suggesting that any refuge which receives funding from the Commonwealth is imposing sectarian or religious indoctrination he should get up and say so.

SPEECH.PARA: The other argument that was advanced was one advanced in unison, I might say, by Senator Walters and Senator Grimes. That is: Who makes the judgment as to what political indoctrination, political action, means? Let me say to Senator Walters in the gentlest possible way that, although she seems to think that I share her political points of view, we differ rather radically on a number of matters. Further, I would like to suggest equally gently that I do not agree, as apparently Senator Walters does, with the philosophy expressed by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in the first sentence of his address to the Federal Council of the Liberal Party at the Lakeside Hotel in Canberra on 31 May 1981. I wish to quote it because it is a gem. The Prime Minister said: 'Let us never forget that the future of Australia is totally dependent upon the Liberal Party'. It is an extraordinary statement to make and one which I feel at times Senator Walters, though she might wish to do something else, adheres to. Senator Walters asked: 'Who makes the decision?'. The Department of Health and the Minister for Health, of course, make the decision as to what is political action and what is political indoctrination. The Minister makes that decision at the present moment. I am just pointing out that the Minister is responsible to this Parliament for the disbursement of taxpayers' funds. If funds in this particular vote are to be used for refuges, to provide the comfort and the compassion for those who are in need in those refuges, it should not be used for political indoctrination. For Senator Walters's benefit, I should like to refer to the reply of Mr Hunt through Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to a question I asked in 1979. Mr Hunt said quite bluntly that community health program funds are not available for political activities. I mentioned the advertisement for a co-ordinator. Honourable senators will recall that the advertisement stipulated certain things. It said:
The refuge operates as a feminist collective, and the positions involve organising political actions around women's issues, as well as co-ordinating the day-to-day running of the house.
Mr Hunt, through Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, had this to say:

. . . the Victorian welfare authorities, which have the immediate responsibility for the supervision of refuges in that State and through which the Commonwealth funds are channelled, will be requested to obtain from the organisation a firm written undertaking that future advertisements will not contain statements of this type and further that in the course of their employment refuge workers will be engaged fully in the care of refuge residents and not in any other outside activities such as political actions. If such an undertaking is not given or, if given, is not adhered to, immediate consideration will be given to the withdrawal of Commonwealth financial support.

Therefore, it is unreal for Senator Walters to ask me who will make the decision. Of course the Government has already made the decision that that ought not to take place but it has not given effect to it. The final brief point I wish to reassert is that it is important for the future funding of women's refuges, which I strongly support, that they gain the support of the community. The issue of community health program funds being used for political action, for political indoctrination, must be faced at some time or another. The Commonwealth has not faced up to this situation. I believe it has made a statement along those lines. I believe that it ought to have the further opportunity to be able to ensure that its policy is put forward. Therefore, I will be supporting the proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I merely wish to rise because of some of the remarks made by Senator Harradine. I should like to say that in my opening remarks after Senator Harradine had moved his amendment I stated the principle, which I believe, that women in this vulnerable situation, and they are vulnerable and in distress, should not be subject to indoctrination-in fact, I think I used the word 'proselytising'-of any kind, be it political, religious or any other kind of proselytising. I hold to that principle. I did not, as I believe could be inferred from Senator Harradine's remarks, suggest that I was opposed to those refuges which are run by Christians, by people who believe and who are motivated by Christian principles. I did not say that. No one, I suggest, in this debate has suggested that there was any sectarian motive or indoctrination involved in this question. The first person to use the word 'sectarian', I suggest, was Senator Harradine. In establishing that principle, I then went on to say that I disagreed with Senator Harradine's amendment because of its nature and because of the wording when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . do not subject their occupants to political indoctrination.

This opened up the area for governments of any type to withhold funding from refuges because people in those refuges held political views or took part in political actions. I do not approve-I resent Senator Harradine's suggestion that I do-of Commonwealth Government funds which have been given for the care and attention of women and children in distress being used for party political purposes. I do not agree with that and I have never agreed with that. The nature of Senator Harradine's amendment, I suggest, as honourable senators on the other side have suggested, opens the way for political discrimination of the worst type in the funding of women's refuges. Senator Harradine, in his last remarks, went even further. He suggested that women who run refuges-he can correct me if I am wrong; but I am sure this is the purport of what he said-should not take part in political actions outside the running of those refuges.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't. I did not make any such statement.
—The suggestion was that funds should not be given to women who run refuges and who then take part in political actions to increase funds for refuges, to get increased government funding for refuges.
—No, I didn't say that.
—I apologise to Senator Harradine, but I believe that that could be interpreted from his remarks.
—I was quoting Hunt's statement.

—If Mr Hunt said that, I disagree with him. I believe that funds which are voted for by this Parliament for the purpose of caring for women and children in refuges should be used for that purpose. I am not suggesting they should be used for other purposes. But to introduce a political test into funding, I believe, is a dangerous principle. It is a principle, I suggest, that we do not use in other areas of funding. If a political test is to be introduced then we may as well go the whole hog and really turn this country into a mess by introducing religious tests and other tests. That was the only reason I bought up that matter. I do not believe that these vulnerable people should be subject to this kind of proselytising. It is for that reason that I cannot support Senator Harradine's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I support my amendments for the reasons I have previously outlined. Until the time of the Labor Government, the States could not care less about the funding of women's refuges. Since 1975 two States, at least, have been extremely hostile to the funding of women's refuges. This was a Federal program. It has been a successful program despite its meagre funding. I believe it should continue as a Federal funding program and it is no good Senator Baume suggesting that because the States in the past have passed on earmarked funds, specific purpose funds, to the refuges-they had to do that-that in future they will pass on funds that are not so earmarked. I suggest that the history of Queensland and Western Australia suggests that they will not. I suggest that the history of the States in this matter shows that they will not increase the funding even in line with inflation each year. For that reason I prefer my amendment. Because I believe that Senator Harradine's amendment introduces a dangerous principle, I reject his amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to have been a lot of misunderstanding tonight because at no stage did I suggest that Senator Harradine and I had the same political ideas-far from it-in any situation. I thought that Senator Harradine was talking in the broader term.
—I accept that.

—I thank the honourable senator. I imagined that Senator Harradine was speaking in broader terms than in party political terms when he was talking about political actions taken in some of the shelters. I certainly was. We were talking about the advertisement that claimed that one had to be a feminist before one was of any value to the shelter, and it is this area that concerns me.
—It did not say that.
—The advertisement I was referring to did. It asked for a feminist only-nothing else. I took objection to that.
—Did you try to close that refuge down?
—No, I did not try to close it down.
—Yes, you did.

—Senator Chipp, I did not try to close that shelter down. What I successfully did was to set up another shelter so that people would have the option of going to either shelter. At no stage did I close or attempt to close that shelter down. What I did was to successfully--
—That is not what the people of Hobart say.
—I do not care what they say.
—I know you don't.

—I could not care less what they say. If they do not know the facts, they are under a misapprehension. What I did successfully was to open a second shelter in Hobart, and I do not think any woman in Hobart would be upset by having a second shelter provided for them. Any women in Hobart who are abused now have a choice. They have three shelters to go to. They can to to Annie Kenny Shelter, the Hobart shelter or the Salvation Army shelter. I do not think any honourable senator would object to having a choice for the women of his or her State. Would honourable senators really object to their having a choice?
—Where does the funding go?

—The funding is equally divided between the shelters. I have no objection to that. I am sure the women of Hobart have no objection to that. But if honourable senators want all the funding to go to only one shelter and not have a choice, I am certainly not in agreement with them. I think Senator Chipp ought to do his homework a little better and find out the facts rather than accept gossip from around the place, which he was so careful to do.
—I was there and I talked to the women.

—Yes. He really does accept gossip which is acting far less responsibly than he should act. I thought that Senator Harradine was talking in a far broader context. Senator O'Byrne said tonight that I would not have any idea what happens in a home with a history of drunkenness. I think I probably had far more experience in my previous occupation than he would ever have in that area. I have treated in hospitals women who have been abused by their husbands and I think I would have far greater knowledge of that sort of thing than Senator O'Byrne would have in a month of Sundays. Being a man, he would not have a clue what the women have gone through. I really believe that I have far greater understanding than he could ever possibly have in this area. Apart from that, I am very happy to support the Government's recommendation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fairness to Mr Hunt, who was then the Acting Minister for Health, and, I am sure, to Senator Grimes, and to put the whole matter in perspective, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard Mr Hunt's full reply to me of 11 May.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Women's Refuges

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Guilfoyle

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 April 1979, Senator Harradine asked me, as Minister for Social Security, a question without notice (Hansard, page 1274) concerning an advertisement issued by the Western Region Women's Refuge. I undertook to refer the question to the Minister for Health.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Acting Minister for Health has provided the following information:

It is, of course, legitimate for a women's refuge organisation to be concerned with women's welfare and the advancement of the status of women in our society. However, an advertisement in these terms is completely unacceptable in the context of approval of the refuge for the purpose of funding by the Commonwealth. Community Health Program salary funds, in relation to women's refuges, are intended solely for the employment of workers to undertake the care of women and children in refuges, not for 'outside' activities of any kind.

Accordingly, the Victorian welfare authorities (who have the immediate responsibility for supervision of refuges in that State and through whom the Commonwealth funds are chanelled) will be requested to obtain from the organisation a firm written undertaking that future advertisements will not contain statements of this type and, further, that during the course of their employment, refuge workers will be engaged fully in the care of refuge residents and not in any other 'outside' activities such as political actions. If such an undertaking is not given or, if given, is not adhered to, immediate consideration will be given to the withdrawal of Commonwealth financial support.
Senator Harradine's amendment to Senator Grimes's amendments negatived.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Grimes's) be agreed to.
The bells having rung and an incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, will you clear the gallery?
—Order! Clear the gallery.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just one other matter to raise. It is unrelated to the previous matter. I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume): What do the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) mean when they say that the State governments will be required to charge $15 per day per patient service? I think the term used in the other place was 'out-patient occasion'. When individuals in the community pay for this service and claim it from their health funds, will the payment come from their medical insurance or their hospital insurance? Does it mean that it will cost $15 for each individual item of service in an out-patient department, which could be a considerable sum of money for, of course, an uninsured patient, or does it mean just $15 per out-patient visit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable senator has asked several questions. I am informed that it will be a hospital charge and will come from hospital insurance. I am informed that Tasmania and South Australia already impose a charge per occasion and that the payment does come from the hospital side of a patient's insurance. I may not have answered all the questions. I hope I have.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1981
Bill agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a third time.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, would it suit the convenience of the Senate to consider the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1981, the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1981 and the Overseas Telecommunications Amendment Bill 1981 together for the purpose of a cognate debate with the questions being put separately at each stage?
—There being no objection, it is agreed to have a cognate debate on the three Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three Bills are being dealt with in this cognate debate. They are the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill, the Overseas Telecommunications Amendment Bill and the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill. The three Bills all relate basically to the present and future structure of broadcasting in Australia. I should indicate that the Opposition does not oppose the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill or the Overseas Telecommunications Amendment Bill. I say at the beginning, because I want to devote my remarks basically to the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill, that the Overseas Telecommunications Amendment Bill is in some way a sort of machinery Bill which has the effect of making the Overseas Telecommunications Commission the manager and owner of the domestic satellite until such time as a government organised company is established to carry out those two functions. I should state that the position of the Opposition on the satellite has been that the Opposition favours the satellite being in public ownership and, in the context of public ownership, we would have a preference for a closer examination of the common sense and rationality of having Telecom Australia as the owner and controller of that satellite. Nonetheless, the OTC is a body which has built up considerable expertise in recent years in the management of satellites and this function is to be given to it by the Government on an interim basis only. It is on that basis that we accept the intent of this legislation for the time being.

SPEECH.PARA: The Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill in its present form is opposed by the Opposition. I want to spell out that opposition in some detail. We have already had an opportunity, in a sense, to discuss this matter in the Senate. I guess I will repeat some of the things that I said about this legislation several weeks ago because my remarks clearly have not sunk in with a number of Government senators and I feel they should have the opportunity of a second round. Hope springs eternal in the human heart. This Bill has now had a seven months period of gestation since the idea was first conceived by the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). It has come to this chamber in the form of a deformed birth. It is a complex and difficult legislation. It will be a lawyer's dream and a broadcaster's nightmare. The main function of complexity in relation to this Bill is to bamboozle Government senators, Government back bench senators in particular. Tonight I will listen in vain for a contribution from a Government senator which indicates that he or she fully understands the effects of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do, of course.
—I think so. Senator MacGibbon and I can toss for it afterwards, or whatever he likes.
—Should we vote against this, too?

—I think the honourable senator should ask somebody more akin to his own level. He or she will advise him on that matter. The outrage in relation to this legislation is because it has been introduced with such haste at the last moment. If this Bill is passed, I for one will not be trotting around the countryside saying: 'Forgive them for they know not what they do'. No doubt such people as Senator Puplick will be doing that. He was the person who, when this legislation was first being discussed, was going to have it passed over his dead body.
—As of next week it will be.
—I understand that. I did not think that that was what the honourable senator meant when he said that earlier. Maybe that is justification for his change of position as I understand it.
—Can't you get to the substance of the speech and cut out the comedy?

—I would not have thought that Senator MacGibbon could tell the substance from the rest, but if he listens for a minute he might be able to pick it out. Throughout the history of broadcasting legislation in Australia it has been recognised by governments of all political persuasions that broadcasting is an area of special sensitivity and special concern. I just put the situation in these terms: The media defines the agenda of public debate on public issues. The Liberal Party platform recognises that most explicitly. Senator MacGibbon's party's platform states:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that in the interests of objective reporting of news the widest possible spread of ownership of the media is desirable.

That is what Senator MacGibbon believes. That statement from the Liberal Party platform recognises the relationship between ownership and diversity of content in the media. The platform of the Australian Democrats is similiar. I have consulted it with a great deal of interest. The Democrats state:
Undue concentration of ownership and/or control of the media should be avoided.
The Australian Labor Party-needless to say, a party competing for office in a democratic society-has a similar view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not with much luck.

—Not with much luck, but it is still competing, still persisting. It is not for me to argue the philosophical position of the Liberal Party or the Democrats. No doubt we will hear people such as Senator MacGibbon doing that. It will be a fascinating exercise indeed. That is the position of his party's platform. What I am concerned about is our position and the position which this Parliament should adopt. There is, of course, already a heavy concentration of media ownership in Australia, both within the electronic media and in cross ownership. Australia was singled out for a special mention by Lord Annan's committee in Great Britain on the future of broadcasting in that country. Lord Annan's committee gave Australia the following special mention:

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia newspaper interests have gained control of television stations with very strong repercussions upon political expression and news.

That is what Lord Annan's committee said about us. It is not a comment which is differrent from anything which has been said by media commentators in Australia-indeed, by honourable senators on both sides of this chamber. Liberal governments until now have opposed increased concentration of media ownership. The last Minister but one was a man who sought, as he said, to take politics out of broadcasting. This legislation is the most blatant example of putting politics right back into broadcasting and interfering with the broadcasting system. Let me ask one or two rhetorical questions. What are the special reasons why broadcasting should no longer be treated as a special case. What special reasons have emerged as to why broadcasting should no longer be treated as a special case, as it has been treated by Liberal governments since the beginning of the days of Menzies? What are the special reasons which dictate a change now? Secondly, what compelling clamour has there been from the broadcasting industry or the public for these changes to be made? What legions of troops outside will Government senators conjure up in support of the changes that are to be made to this legislation by this Bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the only basis on which you make changes-when legions of troops have materialised to defend you?

—No, not me. I thought it was the basis on which Senator Puplick made changes, because that is the only way he can justify a departure from his own philosophy, stated in this place. When he was no longer a man of straw but a man of substance with preselection assured and a Senate career ahead of him, he screwed his courage to the sticking-plate and said all those things, but not now. I ask again: How will a better system result from these changes? There has not been a word about that from the Minister for Communications in his second reading speech or anywhere else. Again, what was wrong with the system established by this Government in 1977 which makes this legislation urgently necessary now? Where did the Government go wrong in 1977 when it amended the broadcasting legislation, taking broadcasting out of politics? Where did the Fraser Government go wrong then that it demands these important changes now?
—Isn't it the other way round? Didn't we take politics out of broadcasting?

—The honourable senator would not know what he did and I do not think it matters much from the point of view of explaining the point to him. Why has this legislation now to be rushed through to work these changes which were so important and which the Government made in 1977? I guess that there are two clues as to why this legislation has to be rushed through now. Let me give them. The first clue was given by the Minister for Communications on 4 December last year when, in answer to a question in the House of Representatives as to why he was suggesting these legislative changes, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of instances of recent times which have caused the Government to consider the implications of the present provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act. One is the decision by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with respect to Channel 10 in Melbourne.
A month later, as reported in the Journal Australian Business, he said in an interview that one of the reasons for the change was:

. . . that there is an appeal under way before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. If there are to be changes it would be totally inequitable for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal not to know the law as it will operate at the time that it hears the case.

They are the two clues as to why these changes are being made. Since 1965 the law in Australia relating to institutional investors and broadcasting companies in Australia has not needed to be changed. Since 1965 the law in Australia relating to foreign residents and broadcasting proprietors has not been changed. One had to be a resident of Australia to be a broadcasting proprietor. That is now to be changed. I ask just one more question in the light of the Minister's clues. Have we reached the point in government in Australia at which we can now say that what is good for Rupert Murdoch is good for Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly not.

—I am glad to hear it. I am very encouraged. Have we come to that point? The Government may believe that that is so, but I do not. The industry does not believe that that is so; nor does Mr Murdoch. In relation to the clues given by the Minister as to why this legislation is being introduced with such concern, detail and haste, of course, Dr Mark Armstrong in the Australian Financial Review this morning had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the bill would give a gorilla of average intelligence a fair chance of circumventing the Act.

That is right. We have an environmental lobby in this place but I thought the Fraser Government was to be a government for all the people and that did not include gorillas, as I understood it when the statement was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). But this legislation does include gorillas. I have said that the Government may believe that what is good for Mr Murdoch is good for Australia, but Mr Murdoch does not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which gorilla have you in mind when you say that? You seem to be relishing the word.

—Do not tempt me. If the Government believes that, I do not and Mr Murdoch does not either. In 1977, when talking about the broadcasting system in Australia and the role of government, Mr Murdoch said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would be a pity if I grew any bigger in Australia. There are now basically three groups in Australia and that's too few already. If I were to grow bigger and take over one of the other groups-or to be taken over-that would be against the public interest. I'd like there to be six groups. The fewer there are the worse it is.

In a similar passage later on he added much the same thing to those comments. I assert that this legislation will in fact lay the way open for greater concentration of power and ownership in an area which in this Parliament has in the past been singled out for special treatment which has been accorded to it by all sides of politics, that is, in the area of ownership and control of the media. I noted with interest, when Mr Sinclair was asked on the PM program the other night whether it would result in greater concentration of media ownership, he said a few words which seemed fairly unintelligible, but he then said that in his view it would free up market forces. That was the answer to the question. I have grave difficulty in understanding what this Government is about as a matter of political principle of any kind. Need I remind honourable senators of the immortal words, which I am sure will cause a rush of blood to the heads of people such as Senator Martyr and Senator MacGibbon, of the Prime Minister spoken by Senator Chaney in Adelaide on 5 December when there was an extraordinarily abortive attempt to explain the Liberal Party's philosophy-if one can dignify it with that term. On that occasion the Prime Minister said:

Liberalism believes that society is healthier . . . when responsibility, enterprise and power are spread widely throughout the community rather than concentrated in one of a few places. That is the ideal to be aimed at and any deviation from it requires special justification.

What is the special justification in this legislation in an area which has always in the past been singled out for special legislation of a kind different to that applicable to the wider business community? Frankly, is it not time that this Government puts its legislation where its mouth is in relation to these various matters which have been the subject of debate in the Senate in the last week or so? The functions of the States, for example, are said by this Government to be very important in terms of decentralisation of power. We were told that a couple of weeks ago in relation to the razor gang. I quote what was said:
One of the many virtues of the free enterprise system based on the market is that it decentralises influence and control over what is produced to the greatest extent possible.

That was the jurisdiction for the razor gang's action in this area of most critical importance. The exact opposite is happening. It is not just a question of rushing legislation through the Parli- ament. This legislation will come back to haunt this Government. Every time an Australian radio or television station falls into the control of a foreign company it will be reminded about that fact. That will happen after this legislation is passed. Every time it falls into foreign ownership or the hands of an Australian citizen who is not a resident of this country the Government will be reminded about it. Every time there is a further aggregation of power it will be set right back to this legislation which is now before the Senate.

I turn to some of the details of what this Bill does. I will deal briefly with it point by point. Firstly, this Bill introduces supplementary radio licences for FM radio and regional areas particularly one station markets. That particular amendment is uncalled for by the public and is unsatisfactory to the industry body the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters. Most honourable senators will have received a letter bearing, I think, today's date from the Secretary of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, which states:

Federation members generally support the concept, but are dismayed at some of the provisions which seek to give effect to it, and are particularly disturbed at the haste with which the legislation is being handled. No cogent reason has been given for this urgency.

It goes on to urge a course of action in respect of the Bill. I do not want to dwell on the section relating to supplemantary licences because it at least has the virtue of the Minister indicating that it will not be proclaimed for some time. The second thing the legislation does is to change--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The speaker has faded off into insignificance. While it is of no great problem, the stenographer's typing is coming through what is left of the broadcasting system.
—There is no point of order. I presume that the utmost is being done to get the broadcasting system working.
—Mr President, what would you like me to do?
—Please carry on, senator.
—We do have difficulty hearing.
—Yes, I realise that, but every effort is being made to rectify the problem.

—I will continue, Mr President. I am persuaded of the view that in Senator MacGibbon's case, my words probably fall on deaf ears. The second thing which the legislation does is to change the traditional ownership and control provisions of the legislation. Simply stated, it no longer requires prior approval for a takeover of a television or radio company. That is, except in the case of the Herald and Weekly Times. It no longer requires the prior approval of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for a takeover of a radio or television company except in the case of the Herald and Weekly Times, as a result of an amendment rushed into the House of Representatives on Friday of last week. It is very interesting to record that the Herald and Weekly Times amendment-as we might call it; the Thomas Nationwide Transport amendment is another clause in the Bill and there are several other amendments all of which can be attributed to the interests of particular companies-resulted from a deputation to the Prime Minister last Friday week, after the Bill had gone to print. Of course, as a result of that representation this amendment was moved last Friday while the debate was being carried on in the House of Representatives. As I have said, it is fascinating to see the way in which this Government does business on these matters. If the editor of the Woy Woy Gazette turned up tonight, the Bill would be taken out and another amendment would be put in tomorrow to deal with that particular newspaper. It is unlikely though because I do not think the Government believes what it says about concentrations of power. I do not think it is concerned to reflect in this legislation the interests of other than the large corporations.

SPEECH.PARA: The third important point is that as a result of this legislation there is effectively no limitation on the number of licences which can be controlled by any one company for a limited period, say, six months plus three months, depending on the largesse or otherwise of the Broadcasting Tribunal. That provision effectively would allow a takeover to occur and there is no limitation in that period imposed on the number of licences which can be controlled by any one person or company. That lays the way open for potential total domination by major media companies. I would simply put it in these terms. It is open for a major media company in the city to say to a regional television station: 'Just buy our programs on our terms or we will buy you and after six months sell your company to somebody who will take our programs on our conditions'. Under the provisions of this legislation, that quite clearly seems to be open to a large proprietor.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tribunal can stop that under 92M.

—Can we come to that a little later? I have some doubt about that. Of course, that is done in the name of freeing up the market. But it is freeing up the market in a most undesirable way, having regard to the special nature of the market with which we are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The next thing the legislation does is to insert a definition of public interest-a definition which, I might point out, was still being amended on Friday when the matter was in the House of Representatives. That definition now runs right through the legislation-it appears in six places, I think-in place of the discretion previously vested in the Tribunal since the 1977 legislation introduced by this Government. That legislation vested a discretion in the Tribunal. The new definition appears, as I have said, several times in the legislation and essentially it introduces an exhaustive description of what public interest is and leaves no discretion in the Tribunal on a number of important matters. In regional areas the Tribunal will still have regard to local concentration of media ownership but in metropolitan areas where 70 per cent of the Australian population lives it will not have a discretion. In addition, the new criteria are narrow. They include, for example, whether the company or a person is fit and proper to hold a licence; the commercial viability of the applicant; whether the applicant will provide comprehensive programming and so on. Four or five criteria are set out in the second reading speech of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume).

I should just remind the Senate that since 1977 the Tribunal has been developing criteria which included concentration of media ownership in particular areas and in the Channel 10 case in Melbourne even included a reference to cross-ownership between newspapers and the electronic media. Those criteria have been developed in a number of cases which were referred to in debate in the Senate, I think by both me and Senator Missen in discussing the statement of the Minister for Communications of 9 April. All those criteria which had the explicit and implicit approval of the High Court will now, if I might use a colloquialism, go down the chute in favour of the narrow definition of public interest set down in this legislation. Those criteria of the Tribunal were established in the 2HD case and the ATV 10 case in particular.

The next point I would make about the legislation is that it includes provisions for institutional investors in media companies. A register of institutional investors will be prepared. The prescribed interest which an institutional investor can have in a television company has been increased from 5 per cent to 10 per cent. We of the Opposition are not necessarily saying that this is bad in itself. It is an attempt suggested by the Herald and Weekly Times group to resolve a particular problem. But under the scheme of this legislation it will be possible for an institutional investor to have a 10 per cent interest in a large number of metropolitan television stations. I suggest, whilst I say it is not necessarily bad, that it will probably introduce a note of great uncertainty into the industry and place institutional investors in a very strong bargaining position in relation to the industry as a whole across Australia.

The next point I want to make is that the legislation also alters the foreign ownership provisions in relation to Australian media companies. I do not know what member of the Australian public clamoured for this change, what ordinary Australians asked for this to be done; I do not know what television or radio companies asked for this to be done. I just wonder whether the Government in its haste to placate particular interests has thought through the consequences of this change because under the Broadcasting and Television Act it is no longer necessary for a person with a controlling interest in licences to be an Australian resident-a requirement which has existed since the commencement of the Act. One can only speculate about the consequences of that change. Let me just remind the Senate that there are plenty of Australian citizens living overseas in Hong Kong and elsewhere who might have a particular interest in this matter. It goes far wider than the case it has been designed to fix up. There are, I believe, very serious potential ramifications in that change.

The second point on foreign ownership is that the legislation in my view-I emphasise the words 'in my view'-provides a very neat method whereby foreign interests can gain a very substantial control of Australian radio and television companies because the tracing provisions of the Act in relation to foreign companies are to be removed. That simply means that once the Act is amended in this way the National Broadcasting Co. of the United States, for example, will not be able to buy a direct interest in an Australian television company in excess of 20 per cent; that the National Broadcasting Co. of the United States will be able to buy up to a 50 per cent interest in-let us say Thomas Enterprises-in Australia and Thomas Enterprises will be able to buy up to a 50 per cent controlling interest in a broadcasting company. If two companies in the United States want to get into Australian media, they can buy interests-one in Thomas Enterprises and the other in Puplick Pty Ltd and from there they can make raids on television companies in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —They certainly sound like sound investments.

—I think they are; I think that is the point. I think shareholders in many American companies will see this as a very sound investment because Australian television is of course now very profitable and has been for a few years. That is an important fact to remember. I do not think the Australian broadcasting industry, when it stops to think about these proposals which are designed to satisfy Rupert Murdoch on the one hand and Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd on the other hand, will be quite intoxicated with the ramifications of those provisions relating to foreign investment. My God, I tell you, Mr President, the Australian people will not be intoxicated either. Those are matters which I think a careful Senate would consider in great detail because they are matters, I believe, of very great concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned that there is now no requirement for prior approval of the Broadcasting Tribunal of a takeover. The only exception is in relation to the Herald and Weekly Times group and the Daily Mirror group of companies in Britain which are said to be recipients of the benefits of the so-called grandfather clause. Prior approval will be required in relation to those two companies. Looking at the drafting of this legislation and at the proposal in relation to the Herald and Weekly Times, whilst the Goverment may have the best intentions towards complying with the particular vested interests of those companies, I think most lawyers would say that the Government has mucked it up. The Government has gone out of its way to satisfy the Herald and Weekly Times and has messed it up. I am just asserting that. I am not going to tell the Government how it mucked it up but I am sure it has and the Herald and Weekly Times will find out about that in due course.

The provision that the prior approval of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is required has not been a terrible inhibition to Australian companies and those who seek to take over media companies. Mr Holmes a'Court, not, I would think, an unsuccessful businessman in Australia, did not have too much difficulty when he sought to take over the Herald and Weekly Times in obtaining the prior approval of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Sir Peter Abeles said on behalf of TNT in evidence to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that it was not a great problem for that company to make a conditional offer for shares in Ansett Transport Industries subject to the approval of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. He stood in the market-place and made a conditional offer subject to that approval; it was not a great bother to him. I do not know who this particular provision is really concerned to satisfy as a matter of urgency. Those are the principal objections which the Opposition has to this legislation. They are all, in my view, matters of grave concern and matters of substantial principle in relation to this industry and the sorts of developments in this industry which Australians want to see happening.

Since the intention to amend this Bill was first announced, the Minister has invited comment about it from various people and institutions. Many of those who were invited to make comment about it sought a public inquiry on the changes in the ownership and control provisions of the broadcasting legislation. Many of them sought a public inquiry on the broadcasting industry generally. The Minister described those as hare-brained suggestions. Many whose views were sought opposed specific proposals which are now in this legislation. All sorts of proposals which the Minister made last November and which he was still making as at 9 April have been abandoned or changed. Last minute amendments and reprints were going on when the Bill was being debated in the House of Representatives last week. All of these matters amount, if I might summarise, to a saga of incompetence, connivance and persistence, about which the Minister for Communications is to be congratulated. At least he has been persistent about the fundamental purpose of this legislation. Many of the 55 pages of it are really guff designed to confuse.

After all this saga of seven or eight months, all the changes which have been made and the changes which were still being made to the Bill last week, there is still very substantial opposition to this legislation. I mention some of that opposition. Regional Television of Australia-the industry body for regional television-is opposed to this legislation. The Canberra Times, in an editorial this morning, said this:

It is obviously complex and has ambiguities, and some of its provisions are questionable, to say the least. If passed in its present form, as is all too likely, there is little doubt that it will undergo time-consuming and costly testing in the courts.

That is good for the lawyers, not good for broadcasting. The Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters is opposed to the legislation in its present form for specific reasons relating to its interests. Professor Julius Stone has written at length on the need to strengthen the public interest provisions in this legislation. Myles Wright, a former chairman of the Broadcasting Control Board, has expressed concern about the haste with which this legislation has been proceeded and about the changes which it is making. Dr Mark Armstrong, a media law specialist, is reported in today's Australian Financial Review as expressing concern about the provisions of this Bill. Again I mention the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations. I do not know what its position is today but last week it was very concerned about the public interest provisions of this legislation and it was concerned about the desirability of prior approval for all transactions in broadcasting licences. I am sure there will be much more concern if this legislation is passed. The public interest group, Justice in Broadcasting, which has taken a long interest in broadcasting matters-it is not a vested interest group but a public interest group in the true sense because its interest is not in any sense vested but altruistic-is opposed to this legislation. So are bodies like the Victorian Council for Children's Film and Television, the South Australian Council of the same body, the Australian Broadcasting Commission body Aunty's Nieces and Nephews, various social justice groups of the churches and the Rupert Public Interest Movement which I must say is distinct from Rupert private interest which this Bill is designed to serve.

The sad thing, of course, is that no one is prepared to come out and say and no Government senator will come out and tell us tonight how this legislation will improve and benefit the broadcasting system, how it will be justified in terms of the great, long history of broadcasting legislation in Australia. Nobody is really going to tell us why these changes are justified. They are things which are going to be, as it were, swept under the carpet. There has been no great pride in this legislation by any Liberal with whom I have discussed it. They know that it is a sordid little piece of legislation. There will be no crowing from the rooftops by the Liberal Party about what it has done for the broadcasting system in Australia by presenting this Bill to the Senate and to the Parliament as a whole. That is the sad thing about it all. Everybody in this chamber knows why it all happened and the industry knows why it all happened. By the next general election the people will know why it all happened. No one is going to stand up and say that this Government has done great things for Australia by changing this legislation.

Mr President, this Senate over which you preside is said to be a House of review. A former Clerk of the Senate, Mr Odgers, justified the Senate's existence in that immortal phrase that two sieves are better than one. Well, the House of Representatives had two hours to sieve this piece of legislation and, with respect to it, it did not do much of a job. This place will not have much longer at this stage of the year to sieve this piece of legislation. But if the glib words about the Senate being a House of review are to mean anything, this Senate should have a close look at this legislation which has been criticised all over the place, which has not been clamoured for, as I said, by the people of Australia, which was not called for by the broadcasting industry, which was conceived in a sordid moment after the last election and which has been pursued with diligence and persistence. The only virtue that can be associated with the legislation is that at least the Government has been persistent about it and the results which the legislation is designed to achieve. And we all know what those are.

If this Senate is to mean anything as a House of review, it would be derelict in its functions if it failed to review this legislation because of some sort of clamour to go on holidays or something of that kind. That is, as I understand it, what the Senate is all about. I only understand it because I have heard it said time and time again by so many Government senators as we seek to justify our existence in this place. We seek to justify it by saying: 'Look, we are a House of review. No sloppy legislation, no sordid legislation gets past our diligent eyes; not here in the Senate. It is all very thoroughly dealt with, because we are a House of review'. I accordingly move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:

'the Bill be referred to a Select Committee of the Senate for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in August 1981, and that the membership and powers of the Select Committee be contained in a subsequent resolution'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats agree with a great deal of what Senator Button has said. We certainly agree with the content of his amendment, namely, that the matter be referred to a select committee of the Senate. If Senator Button's amendment is defeated by the Senate, I will have the honour to move, pursuant to Standing Order 196A, that the Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in August 1981. The Democrats absolutely agree with Senator Button and the Australian Labor Party that this is a sloppy Bill. It will cause havoc in the broadcasting industry and joy among the legal profession. God knows what it will do to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Let me quote the remarks of someone who is much more learned than I on this matter. I refer to Mr Mark Armstrong, a senior lecturer in law at the University of New South Wales, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal could find itself a statutory company manager, caught in the crossfire between warring factions. But in reality, staff ceilings have been repeatedly lowered. Tribunal offices outside Sydney are likely to close and there is a large backlog of work. The section will probably stand as a lifeless memorial to the sensibilities of the rebel senators whom it was apparently designed to appease.

Without making any cheap political points, I am astonished that of all the legislation that has come with a rush in the latter part of this session there should be such acquiescence on the part of all Liberal senators in this legislation. I do not refer just to points of philosophy. One can understand how they would agree to a package from the Government which stated: 'If you agree to the amendments on the Freedom of Information Bill and the airlines legislation, we will cave in on the Broadcasting and Television Bill'. I am referring to the question of English expression and the kind of morass that this Bill will bring to the industry and all associated with it if it is allowed to pass tonight. That is why we say that the matter should be referred to a committee of the Senate.

I will move my amendment to ward off criticism by honourable senators opposite who say that they will not vote for a select committee to inquire into the matter because they would not have control over its membership or when it reports.
