My amendment seeks to have the matter referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, a committee that already has distinguished itself in many areas in the lifetime of this Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not a fact that two of the members of that Committee will not be members at the end of this month? Would you want the Committee to be reconstituted before the new Senate comes in?

—I do not think that would constitute an insuperable difficulty. I think we have the wit and the talents here, notwithstanding the fact that 13 senators are retiring, to be able to fill the two vacancies on that Committee so that it can look into the question. The time loss would be about two months. My amendment states, as does Senator Button's, that the report must be presented by the first sitting day in August 1981. If my amendment were carried, at least we would have an all party committee of the Senate looking at the legislation to try to tidy it up. If Senator Puplick raises that as an objection, I respect it but do not accept it. I ask him, as a senator who sadly will soon be leaving us, temporarily one would hope, to look at this legislation objectively. Is he happy, in his mind, for this legislation to go on to the statute book? Is he happy for the legislation, as it stands, to be impacted onto the television industry?

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give a brief history of the lead up to this legislation. As soon as Mr Sinclair was appointed Minister for Communications he was issuing statements and having discussions with all sorts of people about changes to the Broadcasting and Television Act. From December statements were coming out fairly regularly, but the definitive one was his statement of 9 April, only two months ago today. That was his first real statement. There have been literally dozens of changes made to this Bill from what was indicated in the original statement of 9 April. This Bill is hardly recognisable as coming from the same family as the parent statement as so many changes have been made. If Senator Puplick were to say that the back benchers were responsible for that, I would commend him. I would say on record: 'Thank goodness a group of senators, including Senator Puplick, was prepared to stand up to Mr Sinclair and say that the legislation was absurd and the group would not have a bar of it'. Let me mention the classic example of Mr Sinclair wanting to put to the Tribunal his view as to what public interest should be. I am glad that Liberals such as Senator Puplick destroyed that outrageous proposition very quickly. Then the proposal for a type of supplementary television licence for regional areas was dropped.

The Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives last Wednesday. The Bill I have in my hand is the Bill that was read a third time in the House of Representatives. It bears almost no resemblance to the Bill that was originally introduced into the House of Representatives last Wednesday, not a week ago. Eight pages of complicated amendments were circulated in the House of Representatives during the two hours provided for debate on this Bill. Although I would love to incorporate the amendments in Hansard I will not do so because I would bore the Senate. If the amendments were incorporated, readers could see the absurdity of the situation concerning the debate tonight on this complex matter which will have so much impact on the industry and Australia. In fact, there were amendments to amendments. Some amendments were wrong because of misprints, bad English or whatever.

It is crystal clear that this Bill has been drafted in great haste and rammed through the House of Representatives. Its present form shows that. Let me give an example of a couple of the absurdities that were contained in the Bill. Senator Puplick could well say that they were in the Bill but they have been taken out. Notwithstanding the keenness of people such as Senator Puplick, I dare say other absurdities are still left in this complicated piece of legislation that he and his colleagues did not pick up. We on this side of the chamber have not had the privilege he has had. We saw the Bill only last Wednesday or Thursday. He and his colleagues apparently have had at least since April to discuss the matter with the Minister.

Let me give an example of something that happened, not a month ago, but last Thursday. I understand that the Broadcasting Tribunal basically has six powers in regard to television licences. It can grant a licence, review a licence, approve the transfer of a licence, approve share transactions with regard to a licence, suspend a licence or revoke a licence. They are its six basic powers over licences. Even as late as last Thursday the following provision at page 11, line 20, was in the section dealing with the renewal of licences. I invite Senator Puplick to listen to this. I am sure he would find it amusing if it were not so sad. Sub-clause (iii), which was still in the Bill last Thursday instructed the Tribunal not to renew the licence:

Where, in the opinion of the Tribunal, in the area to be served in pursuance of the licence, satisfactory reception is being obtained of programs from one or more broadcasting or televisions stations-the need for the commercial viability of that station or those stations.

That was in the Bill last Thursday. Of course, it has been taken out. It was an error. What would it have meant if it had been left in the Bill? This is not a draft, typewritten Bill. This is a printed Bill brought into a House of the Parliament which is being asked to pass it. When say, Channel 9 in Melbourne, was having its application for a renewal of its licence heard, this clause would have instructed the Tribunal to have regard to the commercial viability of that station, Channel 9, or the other stations. Let us assume that when that hearing was underway Channel 7 in Melbourne was having a very bad run, that its ratings were down, that its advertising was down and that it was losing money hand over fist. The Tribunal would have been forced to call Channel 9, Channel 10 and Channel 7 to the hearing and say: 'Look, we are obliged by this Act, before renewing your licence, Channel 9, to have regard to the commercial viability of the other stations'. What would it have done then? Would it have said to Channel 9 and Channel 10: 'You are being far too entertaining for the viewing public. Put some more boring stuff on so that you will lose your ratings and will drag yourself down to the level of Channel 7'.

I have discussed this matter with lawyers, and that is precisely what this provision would have done. I am not blaming officers of the Department of Communications. I am not blaming anybody except the Minister and the Government for saying that this legislation must be rushed through. Thankfully, somebody picked that up. I had a look at it last Thursday and thought it was a little odd, and now it has been taken out altogether. But it was a clear mistake. If a mistake of that magnitude was allowed to creep into the Act, what others are still there which those of us who have had little time to examine the Bill have not found?

Senator Button mentioned that representatives from the Herald and Weekly Times group were in Canberra last week pleading for a certain amendment to the Act. I do not blame them for that. It is their duty to do that. If an amendment to an Act disadvantages any group, of course it is their right. In fact it is their responsibility to their shareholders to come and point it out to the Minister. Senator Button who, sometimes like a more important person, moves in most mysterious ways, did not enlighten us as to how that so-called Herald and Weekly Times amendment would not work, but I take his point. Maybe it will not work. That again will not be the fault of the Department or of the Herald and Weekly Times. It will be the fault of the Government for rushing this matter through. Let me now refer to the supplementary licences for radio. Senator Button said:

In effect, no new FM radio station can be established in a non-metropolitan area unless the existing AM station applies to the Broadcasting Tribunal for a supplementary licence. Only when that happens is the question of whether the markets can sustain a new radio station, and an independent one, up for consideration.

I have had that checked and that basically is the situation. That is outrageous. In a country or regional town if there is one radio station or one commercial radio station-which is almost invariably the case-that has an AM frequency, which it would have, the people in that area cannot have FM radio unless that station applies to the Tribunal for one. There is an exception to that. The Minister has power to ask other people to put in a licence application if he considers it to be in the public interest so to do. I ask the Senate to look at the reality of this. We are talking about broadcasting, an incredibly important part of the fabric of our life. Let us assume, without necessarily impugning anybody in particular, that this is largely a National Country Party town. Let us assume that the radio station in that country town is owned by National Country Party interests, and God knows that applies to about 90 per cent of country radio stations in Australia. Let us further assume that there is a National Country Party Minister and that when he goes to that electorate the radio station management invites him for a drink in the board room and says: 'Look Minister, you are not going to fiddle around with this licence. We are doing very well here with our AM. Our profits are way up. Why should we complicate the business and worry our shareholders by asking for another licence and going to additional expense? The status quo will suit us fine'. It would suit them fine and it would suit the National Country Party Minister fine because it is in his political interest to leave the status quo as it is. But what about the people in the area which that radio station services? Are they not entitled to hear classical music? Are they not entitled to hear some varied programs? I would have thought that there would be some arrangement for citizens' access so that citizens' initiative could have some application in that situation and so that it would not be up to the initiative of either the management of the radio station or the Minister. I suggest that this surely needs a re-think.

Let us now refer to the minimum six-month period of grace after the Tribunal has made a decision that a takeover company has to unload unlawful ownership of excess television stations. I have respect for Senator Puplick and I suggest without impertinence that even he has not caught on to this next thing which I will mention. I would like him to answer when he speaks. I am indebted to Senator Button again for pointing it out. Because of this six-month period of grace after the Tribunal has made a decision it is now open for the major media companies to say, for example, to a regional television station: 'Buy our programs on our terms or we will buy you. After six months we will sell your company to somebody who will take our programs on our conditions'. I say through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, straight to Senator Puplick, the kind of advice I have had and the Australian Democrats have had is that that is absolutely possible as this amendment is redrafted. I shall take Kerry Packer's name in vain, but I do not think he will mind. I have great admiration for him. Kerry Packer could go to the Dubbo television station-I do not think that Kerry Packer would do this; I believe he is an honourable person and I am not impugning him-and he could say: 'Buy my Sixty Minutes for X thousand dollars'-an outrageous price-'and unless you agree to do that, Dubbo'-or whatever the name of the station is-'we will buy you'. There will be a period of grace until the Tribunal considers the application. They have six months to divest themselves of that new station. He could say: 'Then we will sell your company in Dubbo to somebody who will take our programs'. What sort of country television station or regional television station could withstand that kind of standover tactic? Again at the end of the story I apologise to Kerry Packer for taking his name in vain but I did so to make the point more realistic.
In regard to foreign ownership again I ask Senator Puplick, through--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator--
—You, Mr Acting Deputy President--
—I ask you to direct your remarks through the Chair, Senator Chipp.

—I am doing so, Mr Acting Deputy President. Every time I have addressed another honourable senator I have said 'through you' or 'to you' to Senator Puplick. I do not appreciate being interrupted when I am doing the right thing. I ask Senator Puplick, through you Mr Acting Deputy President, to react to a question that I wish to ask him. Legal advice is that with the change in overseas ownership requirements, foreign interests may now own up to 49 per cent of a television station; that a friend could purchase an additional 2 per cent of the shares and, the friend being in the service of the foreign company, such company could control an Australian television station or several stations.

SPEECH.PARA: I use the example of Paramount Pictures, or the National Broadcasting Co., buying, by various methods-I will not bore the Senate with the technicalities-up to a 49 per cent ownership in, say, Channel 10. Then an employee named John Smith, for example, could be financed surreptitiously by Paramount or NBC to buy 2 per cent of the shares in Channel 10. Thus, Paramount or NBC-foreign companies-and John Smith, an Australian citizen, in the pay of one of those foreign companies, could own between them 51 per cent. According to the best legal advice under this amendment that is absolutely possible. That is another reason why the Australian Democrats plead with the Senate and, through you Mr Acting Deputy President, with Liberals like Senator Puplick to say that there is no hurry for this to go through; that we should let it wait until the first sitting in August and in the meantime refer it to either a select or a standing committee.

I wish to refer to some of the areas in respect of which the Australian Democrats might be at variance, in principle, with the Australian Labor Party. We believe that defining the public interest is a good thing. I would agree with that provision of the Bill and would commend those Liberal Party back benchers who have forced the Minister to insert in the measure a definition of public interest. I have always been interested in sport. One of the unbreakable traditions is that the rules are set before the game begins, whether it be cricket, tennis or football, so that the participants will know what they can do and in what circumstances. To have an umpire arbitrate part way through the game and say, 'In my discretion this rule ought to be changed,' or 'that rule added' seems to me to be absurd, unfair and inequitable, especially when it is not a sporting contest but rather an activity in which people have invested millions of dollars. I am referring to a television station or a series of television stations. I believe that their interests ought to be protected so that station managements will know what the rules are.

I might have some quarrel with the way in which public interest has been defined in the measure. In general terms, I have not. It could be argued that the definition is too narrow or too exhaustive, but in general terms I would have no great objection to it, nor would the Australian Democrats. It appals me to leave the definition of public interest to an arbiter, or arbiters, who are not directly responsible to the people. That is why I say, with the greatest respect to the members of the Tribunal, that the task of determining what is or is not in the public interest should never have been allotted to them. Politicians are by far the best people to determine what is in the public interest. We are a much maligned group of people, in some cases properly so, but if in our lifetime of service as politicians we have not learned what is or is not in the public interest, no matter to which party we belong, we have been gross failures. I would not have been averse to the public interest being defined by the Parliament itself but one can understand in a flash the kind of pressures that would be brought to bear on the political party systems. Therefore, I believe that to provide for this in the legislation is wise and I commend the Government for so doing.

I am worried about the future, insofar as television is concerned. Supplementary licences are not dealt with in the legislation, nor are satellites or transponders-whatever they may be. Such matters will present the industry with massive problems in the future. That is what makes it even more vital that this basic legislation should be sound, so that the other aspects may be added in the next year or two.

I still confess to having an open mind on what form of networking should be allowed in Australia. I confess to having an open mind on whether it is necessarily a bad thing for three organisations to own two stations, one each in Melbourne and Sydney. Is that against the public interest? I could make a fairly powerful case that it is in the public interest. Let me be the devil's advocate just for a moment. To begin with, the competition for ratings in Melbourne and Sydney between channels 10, 7 and 9 is as fierce as any champion of private enterprise would want to see anywhere. To that extent, the competition itself would keep the participants honest. Would Mr Packer have been able to produce the magnificent documentary Sixty Minutes unless he owned or controlled two stations? I do not know the answer. I suspect that he could not. His company, and other companies which own two stations, have produced much Australian drama and have given much employment to Australian actors and actresses, whether or not we might agree or disagree with the intellectual or entertainment merits of programs such as Cop Shop or Prisoner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hector Crawford does not necessarily own any stations. He just sells the product.

—I am conceding that and confessing that I do not reach great heights of understanding this technical problem of which form of networking one should have; whether networking necessarily means ownership or whether one can have quality productions without ownership. To respond to Senator Evans's interjection, through you Mr Acting Deputy President, I just wonder whether Hector Crawford would have been as successful as he has been if he could not have gone to a station knowing that it controlled at least two basic outlets--
—Like Channel 7.

—That might well be another alternative, and probably one that in the long run I would prefer. The point is that I do not know. There would be very few members in the Parliament-I have said that politicians are the best ones to define the public interest-who would say at this point that that was the only way, the best way, for Australia. It might well be in the public interests of the advertisers, the actors, the writers, the scripters and so on to have this kind of system. Whichever way it goes, I believe that this is a matter which, as Senator Button has suggested, ought to be referred, if not to a standing committee, to a select committee. Again, why should we not require of the applicant for a television licence that he be both an Australian citizen and an Australian resident. Is there any reason for not requiring that? For these and many other reasons, the Democrats support very strenuously, and commend, the attitude taken by the Labor Party on this Bill in requesting that it be referred to a committee. We join it in pleading that that be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite true to say that this is an extremely difficult and complicated debate and an extremely difficult and complicated piece of legislation. It is equally true to say that the role of broadcasting and of the media generally within Australian social, political and cultural life is one of the principal determinants of what Australian society, in the foreseeable future, is going to be like. To that extent, I think it is incumbent on as many honourable senators as possible to try to get some understanding of the complexities of this legislation. I do not for a moment pretend that I am in a position to explain every clause and sub-clause either of this legislation or, indeed, of the primary Act. I don't know if anyone is. I do believe however that the essence of this amendment Bill can be understood and can be put within its context in terms of developing a more flexible, more open and more modern broadcasting system and legislative framework for broadcasting in Australia than we have at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Three point were directly put to me for some sort of specific answer. Two points were put to me by Senator Chipp and one by Senator Button. One of the points referred to by Senator Chipp was the situation of the Kerry Packer standover tactic, if I might use that shorthand expression. The other referred to foreign ownership provisions. It is certainly my intention in the course of my remarks to come back to both of those two matters which Senator Chipp raised. The third point was put in a more global sense by Senator Button when he asked: 'Can anybody explain why any of the changes in this legislation are necessary or are justified?' Therefore, I will start at that point. I simply wish to indicate some of the things that are in this legislation which I believe are appropriate to this stage of our broadcasting development in Australia. Again, I will come back to nearly all these points in the course of my remarks.

The first point is that I do believe that it is now time for the question of supplementary radio licences to be brought into some sort of legislative framework. I believe that the question of the provision of frequency modulation services into increasing areas in Australia is important. I believe that the regime which is put forward in this piece of legislation, which depends initially on the willingness of the existing amplitude modulation operators to expand their services, is not left in an unqualified situation, and that the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), responding to the sort of public pressure, the sort of public interest groups of which Senator Chipp has very properly mentioned, is himself in a position to initiate these additional expansions of FM radio services in non-metropolitan areas.

Secondly, I think it is quite clear that it is necessary to spell out a more precise position so far as the situation faced by institutional investors is concerned. The ownership, control and the deeming provisions have led to the sorts of situations in which major investors like Australian Mutual Provident Society have found themselves unwittingly in breach of the Act. Clearly it is necessary that this needs to be tidied up. This Bill does that by variations between the 5 per cent and 10 per cent control and limitation of holdings which is to be found in proposed new section 91D.

Thirdly, I think there is a need for clarity in the concept of Australian resident or Australian citizen. I spent a pleasant enough hour and a half, I think, listening to Senator Evans leading for the Australian Labor Party at a hearing of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal at which he had the great joy, which undoubtedly many of his colleagues would give their eye teeth for, of being able to put certain questions to Mr Murdoch under oath and to explore whether in fact Mr Murdoch did live at Cavan, Yass, or whether he lived in some penthouse on Fifth Avenue or wherever it happened to be. He explored at length the question whether he was--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at length. It was only 30 minutes, you may remember.

—No, Senator. I recall it quite clearly. The Chairman said: 'I am going to give you a limit of 30 minutes'. You, Senator Evans, took an hour and a half after producing all the documentary evidence that showed that the Chairman could not do that to you and if he tried to do it to you he would find himself in trouble.
—I was shut up. Your recollection is lousy.

—I cannot imagine you being shut up. If we all had the powers of Mr Gyngell, Senator Evans, it might indeed have saved us a great deal of time. The fourth area in this legislation which I think clearly needs to be tidied up is the question of the meaning of the term 'control'. Confusion has existed between the 15 per cent ownership provision and the control of 50 per cent of the shares and the voting power in particular companies.

SPEECH.PARA: The fifth point that I think needs to be cleared up and which this legislation seeks to clear up is to improve some of the procedures of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal regarding the time of hearings, the expedition of hearings and, indeed, the power of the Tribunal to give certain directions regarding the nature and conditions attached to licences which will be found in proposed new section 92M of the proposed amendments. The sixth point is that there is in this legislation a positive encouragement to localism in terms of programming and in terms of advertising. I refer the Senate to the proposed new sub-section 85 (5) (d) (i) and (ii) of section 83 as set out in clause 13 (d) and proposed new section 105R (3).

Finally, as Senator Chipp has rightly said-I will certainly come back to this-there is a need for clarity in the definition of the public interest criteria. If, indeed, one looks at the report of the Administrative Review Council on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal procedures, one will find at page 33 of that report and following that the weaknesses described by the Administrative Review Council as revealed by experience of the ABT. It mentions lack of inquiry experience, imperfect legislation, insufficiently defined procedures, inadequate definition of issues, over-emphasis on renewal inquiries, unnecessary hearings, unprepared hearings, unclear right of participation and difficulties of investigation. It then goes on to make a series of recommendations, including the recommendation regarding the definition of public interest. I think it clearly indicates that at this stage in the development of our broadcasting legislation that amendments along the lines that this Bill proposes are clearly justified and are clearly necessary.

Therefore, before going on to some other of the major parts of this legislation, I would like to indicate that there are a number of comparatively minor matters raised in this legislation which, nevertheless, are of great significance. For instance, I refer to the decision to institute through proposed new section 91C a system of what are called registered lenders so that people who are seeking funds within this particular area instead of being constrained to go only to trading banks will be able to raise funds from those lenders who are registered for that purpose with the Tribunal. There are certainly, as I have said, the variations on the limits of holdings-the five per cent to 10 per cent rise-and the particular problem confronted by the Australian Mutual Provident Society which section 91D seeks to deal with. There are amendments to the merchandising powers of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. There are a number of other minor amendments. There are the questions of increased penalties, more appropriate penalties for various breaches which will be found in clauses 40 and 46 of this particular piece of legislation relating to proposed new sections 92M and P and section 132 of the primary legislation.

I wish to draw attention again to certain matters which will be found in this legislation that I believe are important and which will add to the diversity and the quality of the nature of broadcasting in Australia. In proposed new section 83 (5) (d) (i) and 83 (5) (d) (ii) one sees that the Tribunal is able to set certain types of standards to ensure that a licensee provides
. . . an adequate and comprehensive service in pursuance of the licence having regard to-
(A) the nature of the community to be served in pursuance of the licence;
(B) the diversity of the interests of that community and;
(C) the nature of the other broadcasting and television services (if any) of which satisfactory reception is obtained by that community; and
(ii) encourage the provision of programs
wholly or substantially produced in Australia and use, and encourage the use of Australian creative resources and in connection with the provision of programs.
There is a positive encouragement in the legislation which will be found in that section. In terms of local advertising, which will be found in section 105R (3), the Bill states:

The holder of a supplementary licence shall, in the broadcasting of advertisements, encourage as far as practicable advertisements that are produced, or relate to businesses, undertakings, activities or other matters, in the area served in pursuance of the licence and of any associated commercial translator licence, and, to the extent of his compliance with this sub-section, that licensee shall not be taken to contravene sub-section 100 (3).
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of proposed new paragraph 92FAA (7) (b), which relates to the early and expeditious hearings of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, is important. Perhaps most important of all is the introduction of proposed new section 92M, which relates specifically to the matter which Senator Chipp raised at an earlier stage about what I called, in my shorthand, the Kerry Packer standover tactic about which he was worried. Proposed new sub-section 92M (1), if I may read it in full, provides:

SPEECH.PARA: At any time after a transaction takes place, being a transaction in relation to which section 90J or 92F applies, the Tribunal may, by notice in writing served on-
(a) a person who is a prescribed party to the transaction within the meaning of that section;
(b) a person, being the company holding the licence to which the transaction relates; or
(c) a person who is in a position to control that company,
give such directions to the person as it thinks fit for the purpose of preventing the person or any servant or agent of the person from doing any act or thing likely to have an adverse effect on-
(d) the ability of the company holding the licence to comply with the conditions of the licence; or

(e) the operations conducted under or by virtue of the licence, the management of the station in respect of which the licence is in force or the selection or provision of the programs to be broadcast or televised by that station.

Quite clearly in that proposed new sub-section there is spelt out the power of the Tribunal to give directions, not at the end of a six-month period but, in the words of the proposed new sub-section, 'at any time after a transaction takes place', to any person who is a prescribed party or to a company which is a prescribed party to such a transaction. It may give such directions as it sees fit dealing with programming, changes to programming, management, and changes to management which in the opinion of the Tribunal should not be undertaken while that matter is still before the Tribunal for its consideration of the eventual approval or non-approval of the transaction in question. I put to the Senate that quite clearly in proposed new section 92M the powers are given to the Tribunal to take account of the particular interference, the particular standover tactic, to which Senator Chipp was alluding when he spoke earlier in the debate. The Bill then goes on to give, in proposed new section 92N, certain powers to the Tribunal to order divestiture and to make those powers enforceable powers in relation to proposed new section 92P regarding the powers of the Federal Court of Australia to give teeth, to give judicial effect, to the decision that the Tribunal has made. So the first of those points raised by Senator Chipp, I believe, can be answered in that fashion.

It is certainly true that a number of matters have fallen to the floor, as it were, between Mr Sinclair's statement of 9 April and the eventual emergence of this piece of legislation. Senator Button has been unkind enough to misquote, as it were, a certain attitude that I took to this matter by saying that things were going to be done over my dead body. On 27 November 1980 I asked a question about the university proposed for Darwin. I asked whether Mr Murdoch had been pressing for amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act 'which, I would add, would be vigorously opposed by some Government senators . . .'. That was as much as I said and the specific thing that was being touted about at that time was the question of whether the action Mr Murdoch had underway could be overtaken by changes to the Act so that, as Senator Chipp said, the rules of the game were altered during the play. I am delighted to say that those Government senators who vigorously opposed that course of action were successful in their vigorous opposition. Senator Button went on to say that I said that only after my preselection was secured and I had no worries, despite the fact that I said it after the Federal election when the result of that election was already known, and he invited me to 'screw my courage to the sticking-place'. I recall what happened to the gentleman who took Lady Macbeth's advice in that quotation and I have absolutely no intention of following him down that primrose path.

The first matter that I said was missing from Mr Sinclair's statement related to the question of supplementary television licences. Representations were made and quite clearly the idea of supplementary television licences was abandoned for the purposes of this legislation, although related specifically to awaiting the result of the investigation that the Broadcasting Tribunal is undertaking into the question of cable television and subscription television. Quite clearly the television stations said that they did not want a system of supplementaries forced on them until they had answers to the STV questions. The Government has clearly said: 'If that is the view of the television stations, we will not force this matter until we have the STV report which we will be able to consider in some depth'. I am sorry for CTC 7 in Canberra, which I think was one of the stations which would have been able-should have been able-to pursue the question of supplementary licences without this being linked to STV. I hope that its problem can be responded to appropriately as soon as the ABT report is to hand.

The second thing which was previously in Mr Sinclair's statement and which no longer is there is the ministerial discretion on the question of public interest-the right of the Minister to give directions to the Tribunal about public interest. I am glad to see that that has been removed. The third thing that has been removed is the transitional provisions. Mr Sinclair, in his statement to the House of Representatives on 9 April, said:

At the same time, there will be appropriate transitional provisions, so that any unresolved application can be treated as a fresh application under the new procedures, unless the applicant wishes to proceed under the old provisions.

That certainly appeared, on the face of it, to be a situation of changing the rules once the game got underway. That has been removed. The transitional provisions have been removed from the Bill. Finally, the unrestrained power of persons involved in a takeover situation to interfere in the programming and management of stations in the six months transitional provision allowed in the legislation before the ABT has to come to a final determination has been altered, as I have previously indicated, by the introduction of proposed new section 92M.

Therefore, I believe the important thing is to move on to the other question that Senator Chipp raised-the question of foreign ownership. This has always been a difficult and complex part of the legislation. Present sections 90G and 92D present difficulties in interpretation. Those difficulties arise, firstly, because 'resident' is not defined in any way and because there is no cross-reference to a definition in any other Act and, secondly, because there is confusion over the meaning of the word 'controlled'. In those sections 'controlled' could mean the 15 per cent shares and/or votes test currently applied under section 92B or it could mean the 50 per cent vote test used under common law. The first interpretation-that is to say, the 15 per cent of shares and/or votes test-would allow non-residents to own directly 84 per cent of the shares in a licensee provided no individual non-resident or company which non-residents were in a position to control, and they are the words of section 92B, held more than 15 per cent of the shares.

The second interpretation-the common law interpretation of 50 per cent-would allow, for example, 100 per cent of the shares in the licensee to be held by a company in which 80 per cent or more of the shares were held by non-residents, provided the non-residents held less than 50 per cent of the voting rights in that company. It has to be acknowledged that the existence of those varying interpretations has led to some confusion. In recent years one would suspect that the Tribunal has inclined to the 50 per cent rule. If one looks at decisions regarding Wollongong and TNT's interest in Channel 10 in Melbourne one can see quite clearly that the Tribunal has tended towards that interpretation, in effect the 50 per cent rule. The redrafted sections apply the current interpretation and strengthen it. Apart from whatever consequences may flow from the alteration of the word 'resident' to 'citizen' it is not true to suggest that proposed new sections 90G and 92D allow a larger proportion of the shares in the licensee to be held by persons who are not citizens than was allowed for non-residents previously.

I turn now to the matter of public interest. I make my own point of view quite clear, as I have throughout this debate. I have not been in favour of making legislative definition of the term 'public interest'. I believe that once one defines terms such as this and Bills of Rights they become limiting. That is why I do not support the general proposition of defining within this piece of legislation or any piece of legislation the term 'public interest'. I want to raise a couple of arguments about the matter which I think needs serious consideration and to which I hope I have given serious consideration. The Administrative Review Council, a body for which I have a great deal of time and respect, looked in some depth at the procedures of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Recommendation 30, which is to be found on page 21 of its report, reads:
The Act should be amended to include clear statements of the policy criteria seen by the Government as relevant to the exercise of the Tribunal's import powers.

That is the point Senator Chipp was making earlier-that it is the responsibility of the Government to define these matters and not the responsibility of the Tribunal. That was clearly stated in a major review of the whole of the procedures of the ABT. It is clear and it is true that the ABT had been developing its own set of guidelines. The first of these, I think, is to be found in the Townsville inquiry of 6 July 1977. The Tribunal, talking about public interest, stated:
The following considerations have therefore been kept in mind:

the extent of local ownership of broadcasting facilities; the extent of concentration of ownership or control of broadcasting interests in an area, i.e., cross-ownership of radio and television interests;
the extent of concentration of ownership or control of mass media generally;
public accountability and public access; capital employed;
program services.

That is to be found reproduced on 2 August 1977 in the Ballarat inquiry. It is to be found reproduced in February 1978 in the 4IP Ipswich licence transfer inquiry. It is to be found spelt out in even more clear and precise terms in the 2HD Newcastle inquiry. The Tribunal, in rejecting the takeover of 2HD, was concerned that:

. . . the real possibility exists for a degree of control and influence by Broadcast Investments Pty Ltd of stations 2KO, NBN-3 and 2 HD that would, in the Tribunal's view, be contrary to the interests of the Newcastle public as they relate to broadcasting services available to them.
Of course, it reached its primary focus in the decision given in the ATV-10 case. On page 64 of the reasons for judgment the Tribunal stated:

The Tribunal is of the view that the concentration of media interests by the News Group resulting from the common ownership of Sydney and Melbourne, will have an adverse effect on the freedom of choice of the other members of the network, and is not in the public interest.

I think one thing has to be laid to rest in the public interest debate and that is, the restriction of this in terms of the criteria laid down in the Act to allow the Tribunal to have regard to the concentration of ownership in non-metropolitan areas. I believe the safeguard exists there because the undue concentration of influence on radio and television is only specified as public interest criteria for non-metropolitan areas, as I have said. This is because the Act already applies much stricter limits on ownership in metropolitan areas than in regional areas. For instance the Act provides:

It is not possible for any individual to hold prescribed interests in more than one . . . radio station in any one State capital city within the overall limit of two television or eight radio stations.
It goes on to state:
. . . it would not be illegal for one person to control up to two television stations and four radio stations in a regional city such as Newcastle.

It is desirable that the Tribunal should be able to continue its application of the public interest test to those areas such as Newcastle where the stricter control of ownership in terms of the number of licences that can be owned is far greater than it is in the metropolitan area. This point is made quite clearly in the second reading speech of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) when he said:
. . . honourable members should be aware that the principal Act already applies much stricter limits on ownership in metropolitan areas than in regional areas.

In discussing public interest matters I come finally to the devil quoting scripture for his own purposes to take cognisance of a speech made by Senator Button to the Australian Communications Law Association which was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 23 March 1981. The Australian Financial Review report states that in Senator Button's address he made some main points. It lists a number of them. The article states:
The main points in his address were that . . . there should be a clearer definition of public interest in the Broadcasting and Television Act.
In other words, Senator Button-I have not seen this refuted or denied-in a speech made to the Australian Communications Law Association said:
There should be a clearer definition of public interest in the Broadcasting and Television Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearer is not the same as narrower.

—I am not saying that it is. The point has been made as to whether there should be any definition of the term 'public interest'. I have put a position in which I have said that I believed there should be no definition in the Act. Senator Button has put a point in which he has said that there should be a clearer definition in the Act.
—Neither of you is satisfied, in that case.

—To that extent Senator Button has got far more of his way than I have. The greatest implication of all of this is clearly what the lack of Tribunal power over the concentration of media in metropolitan areas will mean in terms of government policy on the issue of networking. We are still somewhat in the dark about that. Networking is the inevitable consequence of both technology in terms of the satellite and in terms of cost. It is not a question of whether there should be networking. It is a question of what sort of networking there should be. Time does not permit me this evening to go into the three models which we have available. There is a clear American model of networking, domination of small stations by the largest metropolitan majors, which one would certainly not want to see in Australia under any circumstances. There is the Canadian model of networking which may be a little more acceptable but still has certain problems and there is a British practice of networking which may, in fact, be the general direction in which we should move. Of course, networking is not a new phenomenon. In 1942, in dealing with the matter of radios, the Joint Committee on Wireless Broadcasting presented a report to both Houses of Parliament in which it said:

SPEECH.PARA: Having before us very considerable information as to the position of chain or network broadcasting in the United States of America as disclosed in evidence before the Federal Communications Commission of that country, we feel that, whilst there is nothing inherently wrong with the network system, its future development might well be watched carefully by the proposed Parliamentary Standing Committee.

I think it is absolutely true to say that networking is a sensitive area in which the Parliament must be involved in the determination of policy guidelines. I will conclude on these two brief observations: I regret that Australian broadcasting law has got itself into the situation in which a person who owns interests in a newspaper can own any interests in any broadcasting licence whatsoever. I think the ideal in this country and, indeed, in any parliamentary democracy, would be for these people who own interests in newspapers to be prohibited by law from owning interests in any other form of mass communications. That is an argument that should have been raised in 1935 when the Lyons Government started to grapple with this problem. It was not dealt with at that stage. There was no chance of its being dealt with at that stage. At this stage unscrambling the omelet appears to be all but impossible. One can look at the second report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Broadcasting in June 1943. It warned quite clearly:

For the preservation of democratic principles, it is essential that there should be restraint on efforts to obtain an undue measure of control of the air; otherwise those who succeeded in securing it would have an undemocratic advantage in aligning public opinion in directions they favour. This advantage could be used in many subtle ways not discernible to listeners.
In 1959 the Australian Broadcasting Control Board came back to precisely the same thing. It stated:

The purpose of the legislation is clearly, on the one hand to prevent any trend towards concentration of ownership of stations, and, on the other hand, and as a consequence, to encourage the local ownership of stations.

One can look at the United Kingdom Royal Commission under Lord Annan on the future of broadcasting to see the same thing. One can look at Professor McGregor's 1977 Royal Commission report on the Press. It stated:

We do not recommend that newspaper holdings in television or radio should be prohibited, but believe that the existing policy of ensuring that no broadcasting company is effectively controlled by a newspaper company should be maintained and strengthened to exclude effective control by newspaper companies in combination.

Finally, I think we ought also to understand what the limitations of broadcasting legislation are. All the legislation in the world cannot ensure that good broadcasting services are provided or can be made available. All of the legislation in the world cannot ensure the sort of quality programming that we want. There is a remarkable book written by Anthony Smith titled The Shadow in the Cave. That is an allusion to one of Plato's dialogues in which Smith says, I think rightly:

Broadcasting will inevitably remain in the hands of large and powerful bodies who will continue to act as giant impressarios and considerable employers in the future as in the past. Broadcasting, in all its main streams, will stay in the hands of the tiny unelected elite of professionals whose knowledge and understanding of their mass clientele will be the main mesh through which most of the messages have to pass. There is no way of avoiding this. The real question of 'access' therefore resolves itself into one of access to the interest and good judgment of the professionals who mediate the entire process. It is the broadcasters' minds which have to be opened up, their working practices, their own personal outlooks on life.

Given the fact that the legislation can only achieve so much, given the clear necessity to come to grips with the changes in society, the fact that while he may be dead and largely forgotten, Marshall McLuhan is still a person whose views on the position of broadcasting in the community need to be understood and appreciated, I am prepared to give my support to this legislation. I believe that, as Senator Chipp has said, had the legislation come down based precisely on those immutable principles announced by the Minister on 9 April there would have been great difficulty. People such as Senator Missen and I would certainly not have been able to support a piece of legislation such as that. But as this legislation covers those points which have been raised-the powers of the Tribunal, the new section 92M, the foreign ownership provisions, the need to get our broadcasting legislation back into some shape to meet the technological and social challenges of the future, I am prepared to support it. I hope that it will be passed through the Senate tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick has just put forward what I might call a very faint-hearted defence of the legislation that is before us this evening. Faint-hearted he might indeed be. After all the puffing and blowing and spouting of Liberal philosophy about diversity and choice, about options and opening up the airwaves and, indeed, about opening up broadcasters' minds, he, like his colleagues opposite, has yet again caved into Government pressure. Yet again, he has come in here tonight advocating and demanding that we support legislation which is in its essence anti-Liberal and pro-monopolistic-all the sorts of things about which Senator Puplick has attempted to attract so much kudos to himself.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick did point to some minor provisions of the Bill which are useful and perhaps timely. Of course, the Australian Labor Party is not opposed to every detail of the legislation before us, nor are the Australian Democrats. But it is simply not good enough to deal in this chamber with legislation of enormous consequence in terms of the restructuring of broadcasting in this country, point to a few minor provisions and say: 'They are all right; I have read all about this in the Annan report and in the book by Anthony Smith. There are a few things in this legislation that are all right, therefore it is perfectly all right to support the whole package.' It is not perfectly all right to support the whole package, because the major provisions of this Bill are indefensible.

The major provisions of this Bill destroy the long-standing consensus on broadcasting policy in this country. That consensus, for all its weaknesses and faults, was that the broadcasting legislation was designed to be anti-monopolistic. It was anti-monopolistic in intention and it was to some extent anti-monopolistic in effect. It was legislation introduced by conservative governments. It was supported by governments of different complexions through the last four decades because it reflected what was a consensus in the community about the way in which broadcasting ought to be organised. That consensus was that the air waves were a public utility, that the use of the air waves was to be licensed, regulated by government in the public interest and, as I have said, be anti-monopolistic. All of these things are to be thrown out by the major provisions before us. It is simply not good enough for Senator Puplick to point to a few minor and peripheral aspects of the Bill to which we, generally speaking, have no objection, and say: 'The Bill is something that people who espouse Liberal philosophy can support'. Indeed, he even suggested that it is something which people who generally are interested in broadcasting can support. It is none of those things.

Senator Puplick boasted that there had been many changes. I say that Senator Puplick should hang his head in shame about the changes and the way in which they were introduced-the last minute ad hoc chaotic process by which they have come before us. We wish to see the Senate as a chamber in which legislation can be changed and improved but the episode in which we are now engaged makes a mockery of the rights and responsibilities of the Senate unless Government senators are prepared to support the amendment moved by Senator Button-that is, to refer the whole matter to a select committee of the Senate. That amendment of course, is supported by the Australian Democrats.

The legislation, in the form that is before us tonight, really represents the greatest saga of incompetence and of blatant political partisanship that I have seen since I came into this place. It seems to me that perhaps the incompetence of the way in which the responsible Minister handled the legislation is the outstanding, the most notorious feature of the whole exercise. It seems to honourable senators on this side of the chamber that the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) still does not understand the Act which he is now seeking to amend in this place. That is a disgraceful state of affairs, but I am afraid that it is the state of affairs that we are faced with.

The saga of the drafting of this Bill involved a litany of Government ad hockery in decision and compromise. In trying to be all things to all media moguls, the Government lost any semblance of coherence of consistency. It has come up with a piece of legislation which is as complicated and chaotic as the process which produced it. There have been changes about which Senator Puplick thinks we ought to be pleased but the point that I wish to make is that the changes which are before us mean that the legislation will differ significantly from that foreshadowed by the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, in his speech to the House on 9 April. As if that were not enough, to demonstrate the Government's vacillation and lack of a policy, the Government itself introduced some major amendments to the legislation when it was debated in the House on Friday. For example, in his 9 April statement the Minister said that the legislation would provide for ministerial discretion in prescribing the public interest and that the transitional provisions would allow current inquiries-for example, the Murdoch appeal-to elect to be heard under the new legislation. These two undertakings were dropped in the Bill introduced into the House on 5 June. That Bill was amended after its introduction into the House to provide a grandfather clause protection for the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd. Prior Australian Broadcasting Tribunal approval is now not required for the purchase of shares in any television or broadcasting company except the Herald and Weekly Times. These are the sorts of changes about which Senator Puplick has boasted.

As I have said, the major effect and the worst effect of this Bill is that a longstanding and bi-partisan policy of avoiding undue concentration of power or control in the media industry has been abandoned. We have to look at the reasons for amending the Broadcasting and Television Act in this way. Obviously, as has been stated very effectively and very conclusively in the debate on this matter in the House of Representatives, the original aim was to get Mr Murdoch off the hook. He failed to get approval for his takeover of Channel 10 in Melbourne. Mr Murdoch was unhappy about that. The Government was prepared to go to inordinate lengths to solve Mr Murdoch's problem. Later, under pressure from other large, influential corporations, Mr Murdoch took second place. The current Bill does as much to satisfy the wishes of the Herald and the Weekly Times group and the Australian Mutual Provident Society as Mr Murdoch, although he does not lose out by any means. He can now sell his interests in ATV 10 to a nominee or Shell company and they buy it back after the Bill is passed and the public interest provisions on which the ABT found against him are no longer available. To furnish proof of the Government's lack of a media policy and its Sale of the Century attitude towards formulating media legislation, Mr Sinclair's fall-back positions on this legislation have come to light. I seek leave to table to telex from Australian Associated Press which gives details of those fall-back positions which were available to Mr Sinclair.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Apparently Mr Sinclair went to the back bench communications committee and the Government party members equipped, as was Mr Fraser at the last Premiers Conference, with fall-back positions. Firstly, he was prepared to leave the Tribunal's broad discretion on public interest as it was, with one exception. It would be written into the Bill that the holding of two metropolitan television licences would not, in itself, be against the public interest. Secondly, Mr Sinclair would have been prepared to retain the prior approval requirements for share transactions. Both are changes which would have improved the Bill and both are changes which, I hope, Government senators will now demand. I believe the information that I just put forward to the Senate puts beyond doubt the fact that the legislation is simply a result of external and internal pressures on the Government. What does the legislation now do? The amendments remove discretion by the Tribunal; they spell out public interest in a way that is exhaustive; they acknowlege the fact that the concentration of ownership and control are important factors to be considered in regional areas but not in metropolitan areas. This piece of double think is a transparent example of trying to pork barrel two conflicting interest groups at once; that is, to keep the regional television lobby happy by protecting it from takeovers by media giants and to keep the major metropolitan conglomerates happy by allowing them scope to expand in the very profitable metropolitan areas.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as institutional investors are concerned, the increased limit on shareholdings from 5 per cent to 10 per cent is designed specifically to counter the problems experienced by the AMP Society. Then there is the provision for the criterion for foreign ownership to be Australian citizenship rather than residence. My colleague, Senator Button, has said a great deal about this but I point out again that this is of direct benefit to Mr Murdoch who was accused at the ATV 10 hearing of not complying with the residency criteria. It seems to us that this provision is inconsistent with the provisions of the Foreign Takeovers Act. In any case, as has been pointed out by Labor Party spokespeople, this certainly reduces the Australian control of what is happening to our media industry because there are various ways in which citizenship but not residence will be used to increase foreign control of our media operations.

Of course controls on foreign ownership are loosened. By loosening the tracing provisions of the foreign ownership clause and allowing 50 per cent foreign ownership in parent companies, the Bill puts, for example, Sir Peter Abeles's Thomas Nationwide Transport group out of danger. There is now no prior Tribunal approval required for takeovers except, as I said, for the Herald and Weekly Times group which are covered by a grandfather clause. All of these moves are against the most fundamental principles on which a democratic media policy ought to be based and indeed on which the Labor Party bases our media policy.

I will go over some of these principles because it seems to me that the debate can very easily degenerate into arguments about particular points whereas, in fact, the principle of how broadcasting is organised and controlled in a democratic society is the central issue that we ought to be addressing in the second reading debate. The principles that we espouse are these. The boardcasting system belongs to the Australian people-not to any sectional interests-and should be used only under licence and in the public interest. The monopoly ownership of mass communications resources is inconsistent with the aims of freedom and diversity in the communications system. I do not think that any Liberal in this place tonight could argue against that principle, although clearly honourable senators opposite are prepared to support legislation which violates it.

Another important principle is that the aims of freedom and diversity must be accompanied by the fostering of an independent, national identity and culture, something which will not be assisted by allowing increased foreign control of Australia's media. I believe that the question of an Australian identity in our media is one that is becoming increasingly of concern to the Australian people. I believe that Australian people are sick and tired of seeking Australian resources-be they mineral resources, media resources or the film industry-sold out to foreign interests. We are sick of being tacked on first of all to the British Empire and then to the empire of the United Statles of America. It is not the desire of the Australian people to form simply a small part of the multinational English speaking market in any area of activity and certinly not in the area of broadcasting. The actions of the Government in this legisliation make it increasingly possible that this will ultimately become the case.

The Labor Party believes that it is the responsibility of the Australian Parliament to determine and provide guidelines for the maintenance and development of a communications system in the interests of a community as a whole. Of course, in the way that the legislation is being formulated and presented, the Parliament is not being permitted to do this. The Fraser Government has failed to develop a media policy which is in the interests of the community as a whole. In fact, as demonstrated by this mish mash piece of legislation, it has failed to develop any consistent media policy. This Government's method of developing broadcasting legislation has been to barter favours with the media corporations and some lobby groups until it has come up with something which pleases the most influential of these groups and does not make the others too unhappy. The people not consulted in this exercise are, of course, the general public, the media audience, the product sold by the media proprietors to their advertisers.

Where the Government failed to develop a media policy, the Australian Labor Party took action through the only means available to it-the Broadcasting Tribunal and the courts. The Tribunal found in favour of the arguments put forward by the Labor Party and acted in the public interest to stop the takeover of ATV 10. But this amendment is designed to prevent any recurrence of such action. The Tribunal will now be compelled to consider, in isolation, the restricted question of whether each applicant, taken out of context, is a fit and proper person to hold a licence. In this morning's Australian Financial Review, Mark Armstrong, senior lecturer in Law at the University of New South Wales and one time Department of Post and Telecommunications legal expert, points out:
Many of the other revolutionary changes in the Bill have their seeds in the unsuccessful arguments of the News counsel in the inquiries and litigation about the 0-10 network takeovers.
Mr Armstrong continues:
. . . it will be difficult to refuse to allow any group from taking control of one Television station in each of Sydney and Melbourne.

Once a group controls Sydney and Melbourne, it is in the cockpit of a national network. And that offers a dominanant satellite position, even apart from the prospects for video tex services and cable-perhaps even a large piece of a dismembered Telecom.
Mr Armstrong goes on to conclude:

It has always been said that the purpose of the ownership and control laws is to encourage the maximum number of locally based competitive groups in an industry unique for its effect on freedom of speech. That purpose is obviously less likely to survive under the Bill.

At this stage I can only endorse the remarks of Mr Armstrong. In this Senate, on previous occasions, we have had very informed debates about broadcasting matters. We have seen government senators take principled stands on broadcasting questions. I hope that it is not too late to see such a thing again. After all, by moving an amendment that the whole matter be referred to a Senate select committee, we are only seeking to do what many Government senators have said is the proper role of the Senate, and that is scrutinise and examine thoroughly controversial legislation. If ever there has been controversial legislation in this Parliament it is the broadcasting and television amendments we are concerned with tonight. They have been extraordinarily controversial, and properly so, since they affect every citizen of this country and, as I think Senator Puplick pointed out, they affect them in a way that determines the political, social and economic structure of this country. This is extraordinarily important legislation. It is clear that the legislation has been prepared in a fragmentary, incoherent and chaotic way. In the interests of the Australian public, in the interests of trying to attain a democratic, properly structured broadcasting policy, I urge Government senators to do the sensible and rational thing tonight, that is, support the amendment moved by Senator Button, which seeks to refer the whole of the matter to a Senate select committee for further investigation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to a question that I asked Senator Baume, the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, on 29 May 1981. I regard the failure of the Government to respond adequately to that question as an indication of its total disregard for the attitudes of the people of Australia as expressed through that question. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Does the Minister representing the Minister for Communications agree that the observance of common standards of decency and good taste by broadcasting and television stations, including the Australian Broadcasting Commission, is the matter of most concern to the listening and viewing public? Is the Minister aware that virtually no monitoring of television programs is now taking place and that in the last three years no enforcement directives have been made under section 99 of the Broadcasting and Television Act as to program standards? Why has the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal cut by 86 per cent its program of research to ascertain what the public expects from television and broadcasting? In view of these facts and the Government's intention to axe the Broadcasting Information Office, will the Government give a firm assurance that by legislative and administrative action it will ensure that appropriate broadcasting and television standards are maintained and enforced, which it will need to do if it expects public respect for its forthcoming legislation?
Senator Baume answered as follows:

I am sure that all honourable senators would agree with Senator Harradine that the observance of common standards of decency, and proper standards on electronic media, are important in any country. They are important in Australia. Whether or not they are the matter of most concern in Australia, as the honourable senator suggested-
I did not suggest that-

is unimportant. The fact is that they are matters of concern and importance. I have no difficulty at all in endorsing his view to that extent. I am unable to give the honourable senator specific information in relation to his question as to whether there has been little or no enforcement-as he set out-and whether a particular budget has been cut. I am unable to tell him but I will try to obtain these facts for him. I see benefits flowing to the Australian public from the maintenance of a system of broadcasting and television viewing which endorses and sets out standards, particularly for those in their formative years who are impressionable. I recall that a question was asked yesterday, I think concerning the Broadcasting Information Office, and I gave some information. It is not that that office has been abolished, but simply that we have not proceeded to establish it. This was one of the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. In relation to the other question the honourable senator asked about what we intend to do to ensure that adequate standards are maintained, I will refer that to my colleague and try to obtain extra information for Senator Harradine.

It was made perfectly clear, both publicly and privately, to the Government that my attitude to this piece of legislation would be formed having regard to information to be supplied to me by the Government as to its intention to ensure excellence and proper standards on the electronic media throughout Australia. That information has not been supplied to me. I have been totally ignored in respect of this matter. It has been virtually impossible for me and probably other honourable senators to catch up with the welter of amendments that have come through on this piece of legislation. Even tonight I received on my desk a page that deals with the leaving out of clauses. I and many other people in Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —From the Government?

—Yes, from the Government, precisely. I am concerned and many other people in Australia are concerned not so much as to who controls the media but what types of programs come across, the excellence of those programs and whether they meet standards of common decency and good taste. The situation in Australia is that in fact section 99 of the Broadcasting and Television Act provides the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with clear powers to set and enforce program standards in commercial television. The same Act gives the Minister for Communications powers of censorship independent of that Tribunal. The Green report in 1976 recommended that complaints from the public should be handled by industry associations and that regular monitoring of programs should cease. But a second report in 1977 recommended that a Broadcasting Information Office should be established which would, amongst other things, register complaints from the public. A director of the Broadcasting Information Office was in fact appointed in 1980 but the Office has never reached operational status.

SPEECH.PARA: In the pre-tribunal days, as honourable senators will recall, the Australian Broadcasting Control Board maintained a staff in its State offices sufficient to enable it to carry out full time monitoring of all programs broadcast on radio and television. By 1979-80 the Board had reached a stage of decline where no items under the heading 'Televising of Objectionable Matter' were included in its annual report. No directives were issued to stations under section 99 of the Act. Its successor-the Tribunal-does not engage in full time monitoring of programs but 'spot monitoring' is carried out in selected areas. The spot monitoring is determined by complaints from the public. For a time the Tribunal did carry on the functions of the Board and the Board's research into what the public wanted in broadcasting and television. However, as a result of the 1980-81 Budget, the Tribunal was obliged to cut is research budget by 86 per cent, and that was one of the points I raised in my question which has not been properly and adequately answered. Meanwhile, the Broadcasting Information Office, which was to assume the role of receiving, registering and investigating complaints from the public, is due for the chop; it has not got off the ground.

So we have a situation in which virtually no monitoring at all is done of the excellence of programs or their standards of decency or good taste. That is the matter of greatest issue and greatest concern to the viewing and listening public of Australia. Yet we have a situation whereby a question was asked by me on this matter in which the Government was given an indication very clearly as to what my attitude on the matter would be and I am totally ignored on this particular point. I believe that I have the right to express the viewpoint of the electors of my State to the Government by way of questions. The Government can be cavalier to me as much as it likes but it does not have the right to be cavalier towards the bulk of the Australian public who regard this issue as one of the most important issues so far as broadcasting and television is concerned.

This issue does not go only to the question of commercial television and broadcasting stations; it also goes to the Australian Broadcasting Commission as well. What is the Government doing about the question of excellence and standards of decency and good taste in the ABC? Only recently an elector, quite an intelligent level-headed sort of a bloke, came to my office and said that while he and his family were viewing, I think the seven o'clock news on the ABC, without any warning whatsoever on to the television screen came the sight of a soldier in Northern Ireland being incinerated and the sounds of his anguished cries for help and pity. Let us compare that with the same ABC news service approximately three months beforehand which showed sheep, which had been burnt in a bushfire in, I think, Western Australia, being shot. Before that particular clip a warning was given. I wonder whether the ABC has more respect for the life of a sheep than it does for the life of a human being. That possibly is all right; it was an isolated instance. But I believe I have a responsibility and a duty to express the feeling which is widespread throughout the community that it wants something done about the monitoring of standards of excellence and standards of decency and good taste in regard to television and broadcasting in Australia. It is not being done.

Unlike other changes by this Government which are often accompanied by a fanfare of publicity, I believe that successive governments have deliberately allowed the question of the monitoring of television standards to be pushed into the background. I guarantee that before a number of people hear what I have to say and before a number of people wake up to what is happening and how this matter is being pushed into the background, they were not aware for about the last five years that they themselves, namely, the public of Australia, have had to shoulder the responsibility of monitoring television and broadcasting programs. They are not, of course, equipped to do that. Unless viewers complain, it is automatically assumed that everything is unobjectionable. Is that a proper way in which to maintain standards of broadcasting and television in this country? It certainly is not good enough. If the Government wants the public to support this Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill, it should earn that support by demonstrating a genuine concern about program standards. If it wants my support on the legislation it ought to start by answering the questions I have put down in this Senate on this important aspect. Until such time as it does so, it cannot have my support on this particular legislation. I will support the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on these proposed amendments has ranged over the major issues. The basis of this proposal goes back to a statement which the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, made soon after his appointment to the portfolio of communications. I think it was early in December last year when the Government proposed to have an inquiry into the way in which the Broadcasting and Television Act was operating in certain respects. It called for submissions and many were received and considered and over a period of months of this year until the introduction of this Bill, there was a great deal of consideration of the views which were put to the Government. There was consultation with interested parties and a statement was made by the Minister on 9 April as to what the Government's views then were as to the proposals it had in mind, the comments it had received and the decisions which had been made. Again, since April there has been a great number of further submissions and a great deal of further consideration. The final result of that was that legislation was introduced last week. I appreciate that this is a complicated area. The Act itself is very complicated and the amendments to it naturally appear to be complicated. In fairness to honourable senators I say that the amendments are complicated. Nevertheless, the issues which are presented by this Bill appear to be clearly understood by those honourable senators who have taken part in this debate. I am not aware of there being any issues that have been overlooked. Generally speaking, I think that the matters that are before the Senate and on which we have to vote have been clearly drawn out. They are matters of controversy on which the Opposition has taken, as it may be expected to take, a different view from that of the Governmet. But certainly it does not appear to me that there is any need for further delay to enable those issues to be more clearly identified and for decisions to be made about them.
—You might have some more amendments.
—Senator Button has made his views very clearly known.
—Have you any more amendments at this stage?
—As a matter of fact, one of your amendments has raised a problem.
—A drafting problem?

—It has raised a purely technical drafting problem, which I am prepared to recognise. So the Opposition's efforts in this chamber are not altogether in vain despite the way in which Opposition senators constantly complain about the way in which they are ignored. In summing up, I do not propose to deal at length with those matters which have been at issue here. I say that, not only because of the lateness of the hour, but also because Senator Puplick has said virtually everything that I would wish to say on behalf of the Government in responding to this debate. He dealt with all the issues that have been raised by this legislation in this debate and put very clearly the views of the Government. I would only be repeating what he said if I were to go over the same ground.
