I was very pleased to find that Senator Chipp, despite his desire to refer this Bill to a Senate standing committee, does support one of the major proposals contained in this Bill, namely, to give a clear definition of the concept of public interest.
—I didn't say 'clear'-some definition.

—Senator Chipp is saying that public interest ought to have some definition. The definition given may involve an area of controversy. The Government has included its views as to what the public interest should contain. The concept of giving definition to public interest is one of the major areas of controversy between the Government and the Opposition. The Opposition has taken the view, as I understand it, that there should not be that definition, but that--
—There should be a different definition-different and open-ended.
—It may be only an issue of a different definition. I understand the Opposition to have the view that the public interest would be better left in broad terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this legislation is to deal with a number of difficulties which the Government has identified in the operation of the existing legislation. The Opposition has endeavoured in this debate to make a case that the Government was somehow overturning its own policies on broadcasting and television and the basic provisions of the existing legislation. That is not the case at all. The Government has brought forward proposals to deal, as I have said, with the definition of public interest which has not been defined. We believe it ought to be defined. As I said, I am glad that apparently the Opposition, as well as Senator Chipp, now agree with that even though there naturally may be differences about the extent of the definition of public interest. The Government found difficulties in some respects with the provisions of the Act dealing with the obtaining of approval by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to transactions in purchasing interests and has come up with what I believe are much clearer provisions in that regard. At the same time, it is protecting the licences if there are major changes in ownership as a result of transactions in the stock market. It has also identified the anomalies that occurred with what we might call the Australian Mutual Provident Society situation. It has dealt with proposals for ownership by registered investors of up to 10 per cent of companies which have licences.

Difficulties also arose in the interpretation of the existing foreign ownership provisions. The Opposition, quite wrongly, has made great play of this circumstance. The legislation is giving effect only to what has been adopted by the Tribunal as its understanding of these provisions. There may be some controversy about what they are, but in fact the provisions of the Bill dealing with foreign ownership are giving effect only to what, as I have said, has been the position taken by the Tribunal on these matters. We believe that the changes proposed in this legislation are important but are not of the far-reaching and revolutionary kind which the Opposition would have us believe. As I have said, issues have been clearly identified in this debate and the Government believes therefore that the Senate should proceed to deal with this legislation and to give a decision on it. I hope it will give it a speedy passage.

There have been, of course, other representations. There may be many other desirable changes in relation to this legislation which ought to be considered for the future. One such representation has been made recently by the Federation of Australian Commerical Television Stations in relation to undertakings which are required to be given by a licensee in regard to the performance of those undertakings at a renewal hearing. The Government believes that questions of this kind are ones that should be considered in the light of consideration of the report it has received from the Administrative Review Council in regard to the procedures of the Broadcasting Tribunal. Those are further decisions which will need to be made and given effect to at a future date. At this stage, without ruling out any other questions of amendment to this important Act in the immediate future, we believe that the changes now proposed are ones which are called for. They clarify matters, many of which are now in doubt. We believe they will improve the workings of this Act. We believe and hope that the Senate will support them.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Button's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (The President-Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Standing Order 196A, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in August 1981.
For the reasons that I gave in my speech at the second reading stage, I do not propose to speak to the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Mason

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 12-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 13 (Consideration of applications by Tribunal).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 10, clause 13, paragraph (d), proposed new sub-section 83 (6), paragraph (c), lines 39 and 40, leave out 'having regard only to the following matters or circumstances', insert 'having regard to the following matters or circumstances, and any other matters and circumstances which it considers appropriate'.
(2) Page 10, clause 13, paragraph (d), proposed new sub-section 83 (6), paragraph (c), line 41, after 'person:', insert the following new sub-paragraph:
'(i) (A) the extent of local ownership of broadcasting facilities;
(B) the extent of cross-ownership of radio and television interests;
(C) the extent of concentration of ownership or control of mass media generally; and
(D) public accountability and public access;'.
(3) Page 11, clause 13, paragraph (d), proposed new sub-section 83 (6), paragraph (c), after sub-paragraph (ii), insert the following sub-paragraph:

'(iia) where the licence is for a regional broadcasting or television station-the degree of control and influence in the media in the particular region concerned and whether the granting of the licence would be in the interests of the public in that region as they relate to the broadcasting and television services available to them;'.

(4) Page 12, clause 13, paragraph (d), proposed new sub-section 83 (9), line 17, after 'applicant', insert ', so long as that is not against the public interest, having regard to any or all of the matters and circumstances referred to in paragraph 83 (6) (c) including any such additional matters and circumstances as the Tribunal considers appropriate'.

Because of the late hour and the undoubted hunger and thirst that honourable senators have at this time I will not seek a division in respect of these amendments. However, the Opposition is unanimous in its support of these amendments. I would like that fact recorded in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we had another three divisions we would have them. They are dropping off every division.

—The interjection might be right but I am reminded of the Duke of Wellington's comments about his troops when they marched into the battle of Waterloo. The purpose of these amendments is to ensure that the public interest criteria laid down in the Bill are not exhaustive. There has been a long period of public and quasi-public debate as to whether there should be an attempt in the legislation to define the public interest. In this legislation the Government has put forward a definition of public interest which in our view is an extremely narrow one. The first limb of that definition is whether an applicant or person seeking control of the television licence or seeking renewal of it is a fit and proper person to hold such a licence.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be appropriate when mentioning that criterion in relation to this matter to refer the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to clause 38 on page 41 of the Bill. The clause is headed 'Approval of transactions'. As a matter of interest I as the Minister-this is a matter about which he might wish to receive some instructions-whether clause 92FAA as included means, as I would argue that it means, that in the future in determining whether a person is a fit and proper person the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will not be able to go behind the applicant; that is to say, it will have to look at the application company to determine whether it is fit and proper and it will not be able to go behind the corporate veil, to use Lord Denning's expression. That is an expression taken up by the High Court in Hardiman's case in which it was laid down that it was the duty of the Tribunal to look behind the actual applicant to see who was behind it. In this case the question involves the term 'fit and proper person'.

I raise this matter, of course, at this stage because it is quite fundamental to the first criterion of public interest. To put it simply, I think it means that a company which has, if I may use a non-company law expression, a cleanskin character about it, can apply for a licence or, in particular, apply for a transfer of a licence. The Tribunal will be entitled to look at whether that company is a fit and proper person in law. It will not be able to look at who is behind the application. If that view is correct, in a sense, it is the most radical departure from the traditional view of the Broadcasting and Television Act, with its tracing provisions. It is concerned to see exactly what is in fact happening in the transaction and not what merely appears to be happening on the surface. I draw the attention of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to the Hardiman case and to the following passage in the High Court judgment:

To discharge its duty the Tribunal must in an appropriate case investigate for itself the possibility of contravention, even in circumstances where there is no party before the Tribunal willing, anxious or able to pursue the issue.
That appears at page 321 of the judgment. The headnote of another part of the judgment of the High Court states:

Although under sub-s. (4A) of s. 92 of the Tribunal was bound not to refuse to grant approval in certain circumstances, the boundaries of the Tribunal's inquiry were not necessarily to be governed or circumscribed by such circumstances, while in any event the language of sub-s. (4A) with its reference, inter alia, to 'public interest', showed that a contravention of s. 92 (1) (a) on the part of a person other than the applicant might have an obvious relevance to the maintenance of such indirect ownership and control of the company holding the licence as would best accord with the public interest.

I think that the appropriate clause of the Bill is, in effect, fundamental to the fit and proper person criterion referred to in amendments Nos 1 to 4 moved by the Opposition. The other purpose of the Opposition's amendments Nos 1 to 4 is, first of all, to say that the public interest criteria should not be exhaustive, that there should be a general discretion in a body such as the Tribunal to deal with matters not prescribed in the narrow definition of public interest as it appears.

I draw the Committee's attention to the fact that the Government's amendments introduced on Friday-the Herald and the Weekly Times Ltd clause as I called it-ensure that the criteria in this Bill are quite exclusive and puts it beyond doubt. In other amendments introduced on Friday in the House of Representatives there were drafting errors in the six definitions of public interest. In all those clauses now it has made it quite clear, by insertion of the word 'only' in every one of them, that they are the only circumstances to be taken into account by the Tribunal. The other thing which the amendments do is to insert into the public interest criteria, criteria regarding the concentration of ownership which, in our view, ought to exist in any democratic country. It has been a matter of great concern by Liberal statesmen from Postmaster-General Davidson when television was first introduced in this country in 1956 right down to Minister Staley in 1979-80 that the question of concentration of ownership should be considered. We want to insert in the definition the criteria laid down in the case law by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in the Townsville case, the 2HD case and, to a lesser extent, to the Hardiman case. I make the point that the wording of the proposed amendment is taken directly from the first hearing of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in the Townsville inquiry. We also seek to include the same criteria in relation to regional public interest, and there the wording is based on the 2HD case. That is the purpose of the amendments. We draw them to the attention of the Committee in some detail on this occasion, but at a later stage we can perhaps handle the matter in another way.
Wednesday, 10 June 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The public interest issue is perhaps the central one in this whole debate. It is for that reason that I do propose to spend some little time in discussing the arguments. For those who might be minded to be a little intolerant about this, given the lateness of the hour, might I simply remind them and the Committee that I did not trespass on anyone's patience at all during the second reading debate and I do not propose to do so again during the Committee debate. I do believe the public interest issue needs a lengthier canvassing than it has been able to get so far in either house of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me begin by saying that of all the things that are wrong with the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill-there are many, including its allowing of unconditional takeovers without prior approval and with later approvals by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which is necessarily reduced to an empty cypher; its making of citizenship rather than residence the test of local control to bail out, as has been said, Rupert Murdoch; its opening of the door to foreign control by stipulating 50 per cent rather than 15 per cent as the cut-off point when overseas capital is involved; its failure entirely to tackle the issues of share warehousing and discretionary trusts and the other kinds of familiar devices which, as Mark Armstrong said in the Australian Financial Review this morning and which has already been cited, would give a gorilla of average intelligence a fair chance of circumventing the Act; its effective removal of the constraints governing network arrangements which have, of course, concerned the Tribunal in the past, especially in the Murdoch-Channel ATV 10 case; the encouragement it gives in various ways to the creation of three monolithic Sydney-Melbourne based television networks; the cosy arrangements it creates for the granting and renewal of supplementary radio licences and the tortuous, appalling incomprehensibility of its drafting, which is bad enough in any Bill but quite indefensible in a Bill supposedly meant to be used in the public interest by individuals and community groups-undoubtedly the worst single aspect of it, symbolising and summarising in itself just everything that is wrong with it, is its treatment of the public interest question.

The present Act is certainly somewhat less than satisfactory in its explicit treatment of this issue. One of the objects of the Opposition's amendments is to remedy that situation in the present Act. The expression 'public interest' does not explicitly appear at all in the provisions governing licence grants. When it does appear in other contexts-for example, in the share transfer provisions which are contained in section 92F (4) (a)-then it is hedged about in various ways. Nonetheless, the High Court of Australia made it perfectly clear, in the 2HD case in 1979 and again, although less directly, in the Hardiman case in 1980 arising out of the ATV 10 hearings that the concept of public interest is a relevant factor in the exercise of discretionary powers by the Tribunal even if it is not explicitly so stated in legislation. As has been said, the Tribunal, since the Ballarat and Townsville inquiries back in 1977-there are a number of subsequent cases-has been evolving its own detailed criteria to give force, effect and application to the notion of public interest in the broadcasting context. In relation to the Ballarat case, at page 5 the Tribunal said, as has been repeated on a number of subsequent occasions:
The following considerations have been kept in mind in relation to public interest criteria:
The extent of local ownership of broadcasting facilities;
the extent of concentration of ownership or control of broadcasting interests in an area, i.e. cross ownership of radio and television interests;
the extent of concentration of ownership or control of mass media generally;
public accountability; public access; program services.

Those, of course, as Senator Button has said, are the propositions which it is now sought to incorporate specifically in the language of the Act. It has to be appreciated that it was no mere paper tiger which was thus developed and articulated by the Tribunal in those earlier cases because concentration considerations, which were held to be wrapped up in the public interest criteria thus articulated, were, of course, crucial in the 2HD case when the High Court upheld the Tribunal's finding that the Act, although it set a maximum of stations, nonetheless could be construed as allowing and, indeed, requiring the Tribunal to take into account concentrations within that particular ceiling if there were special features about the local circumstances which rendered that concentration contrary to the public interest. Now in this Bill, of course, as it has been brought forward by the Government, we find that not only is there no general or residual public interest criterion expressly provided for but also most of the criteria which have already been laid down by the Tribunal in its evolving jurisprudence have been expressly excluded. There are a number of criteria which are explicitly contained in the Bill and which recur, with minor variations depending on the context, in the provisions governing grants, renewals, suspensions and revocations, transfers and share approvals. But in each case when that list of criteria recurs, as has been pointed out, it is preceded by the word 'only', making it perfectly clear that the Tribunal cannot go beyond the expressly laid out criteria. The criteria in question have been conveniently summarised in the explanatory memorandum as follows:
compliance with the conditions of a licence;
whether the applicant will provide an adequate and comprehensive service in pursuance of the licence, having regard to:
the nature of the community to be served;
the diversity of the interests of that community; and
the nature of other radio/television services in the area;
whether the applicant will encourage the provision of Australian produced programs and the use of Australian creative resources;
whether a person or company is fit and proper to hold an interest in a licence;
the financial, technical and management capabilities to undertake the operations of a licence;
in non-metropolitan areas (i.e. outside the six State capitals) the degree of concentration of influence of-
It is not clear whether the right word is 'of' or 'on', and that is one of the numerous drafting difficulties we have with this Bill--
radio or television stations; and
commercial viability of stations in the area;

TALK.START.PARA: —That omits the encouragement of Australian produced programs.

—I thought I had made reference to that criterion of whether the applicant will encourage the provision of Australian produced programs and the use of Australian creative resources. If I left that out of the litany, I apologise for doing so. I had no intention other than to set out the provisions which are in the Bill because the point I want to make is that when one lays out the provisions in that way there are some conspicuous omissions. The most conspicuous omissions from the list are those very criteria which have been articulated by the Tribunal in those earlier Ballarat, Townsville and subsequent cases and which are contained in the various provisions throughout the Opposition's amendments which we seek to write into the legislation, namely, the criteria of the extent of local ownership of broadcasting facilities, the extent of cross-ownership of radio and television interests, the extent of concentration of ownership or control of mass media generally and public accountability and access. Those are the specific matters which have been identified by a number of tribunals in the past as being implicit in the loose public interest language of the Act, as it stands at the moment. But they are criteria which not only are not expressly included in the Government's Bill but which also are expressly excluded from the Tribunal's consideration. I note that there is an explicit provision-for example, the proposed new section 83 (6) (c) (ii) (B) with respect to non-metropolitan commercial licences, which does refer to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the need to avoid undue concentration of influence, whether direct or indirect, on the person--
That is, the person applying-
and on the company or companies holding the other licence or licences;

There are a couple of points to be made about that. The first is that it is, again, rather extraordinarily impenetrable language which does not make it all clear whether cross-ownership of media interests generally is meant to be subsumed or whether it is just the influence exercised by the holding of radio and television licences alone that is contemplated. There is also a linguistic problem about the word 'on' as distinct from the word 'of' which appears in the explanatory memorandum. That just serves to throw the whole meaning of this clause into something close to total confusion. The other point about this clause is the obvious one that, even if it does have some coherent meaning as a vehicle for knocking out, in the public interest, concentrations in the non-metropolitan area, it has no application in the metropolitan area. Senator Puplick made the obvious point that the ceilings are lower to start with in the metropolitan area, but that does not answer the basic contention of the Opposition that just because a maximum is prescribed for particular ownership interests that should not be regarded as amounting to the norm and that there ought to be room for manoeuvre in determining whether concentrations falling short of the maximum are nonetheless against the public interest.

This late in the day, knowing what we do about the existing pattern of concentration of ownership and the likely future developments in this respect, it might be thought that it is hardly necessary to argue why it is that public interest questions are involved here. For the Government to bring forward this Bill in the way it has, with the criteria that are now built into it, and for Government senators to accept the Bill in this form, seems to indicate that it is necessary to restate briefly, because of time constraints, some of the basic arguments that underlie our concern with there being a viable public interest criterion. I think we need to re-examine why it is that, as Senator Ryan has said, there has been a consensus for so many years about the necessity for anti-monopolistic, anti-concentration public interest provisions in this legislation. We need to examine why it is that that consensus is breaking down and more particularly why it ought to be recreated.

The background against which this consideration is made ought to be well enough known; namely, that three basic commercial enterprises-the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd, the Murdoch organisation and the Packer organisation-will have, if the present application succeeds, wrapped up the Sydney and Melbourne television accesses between them. In conjunction with the Fairfax organisation, these four media organisations have just about sewn up the electronic media in every major city in the country. At the same time, these are the organisations which exercise the dominant role in the print media-the Herald and Weekly Times having 52 per cent of circulation, News Ltd, which is the Murdoch group, 24.7 per cent, and the Fairfax group 22.6 per cent. Together with Consolidated Press Holdings Ltd, the Packer organisation, these are the same interests which control radio and television stations as well as magazines and suburban papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you jump very quickly from Sydney and Melbourne, which I concede, to your next statement of tying up every television outlet in the country? It seems a big jump.

—The evidence about who owns what other media outlets indicates a quite remarkable incidence of extended ownership by those organisations and others, and others in which they have an interest, of non-metropolitan regional channels as well. It needs more argument than we have time for to make this point. I am really saying that in terms of the major cities, not just Sydney and Melbourne but also Brisbane and Adelaide, and when we take into account the Channel 7 interests in those two cities as well--
—Not in terms of ownership.
—I am running out of time. Perhaps the honourable senator would care to contribute briefly for a minute or two on that theme and allow me, accordingly, to eke out the remainder of my time.

—I apologise for interjecting on Senator Evans, but I was very interested in the contribution he was making, which I commend. I think the exchange Senator Evans and I have just had illustrates once again the necessity for further investigation into this whole question and, I think, lends some support to the amendments that Senator Button and I moved earlier. The amendments stated that these matters really ought to be referred to either a select committee of the Senate or a standing committee of the Senate so that they can be properly debated and properly understood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Chipp for concentrating my mind on one of the key issues which I think the Senate needs to resolve in this respect. I think that, while there is a case for actually incorporating in Hansard an up to date table as to who owns what in terms of the major print media organisations, one matter to which I can refer Senator Chipp and the Senate, although it is now three or four years out of date, is the table about the electronic media ownership interests of the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd, John Fairfax Ltd, News Ltd and Australian Consolidated Press Ltd that appears in Trevor Barr's book entitled Reflections of Reality: the Media in Australia which is one of the more convenient and useful texts to emerge in recent years about the media in Australia. It is from that book that I want to read further now, incidentally, because I think it quite neatly and succinctly sets out what really are the two basic arguments about excessive concentration of media ownership generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The arguments can be very succinctly stated. It is just a pity that they need to be restated because they seem to have been forgotten by the Government and Government senators. Really the arguments are of two kinds. In the first place there is the matter of power and accountability. Barr states:

Control of the media in the hands of a few groups is undesirable and potentially dangerous. If we assume that the media is influential in shaping our attitudes, then those who own the communication channels possess great potential power to influence the public in ways they choose. They can and do strongly support or oppose governments and political parties. The press is less accountable than most other institutions in our society. Unlike political leaders those who own the press are not, and never have been elected.

That passage states obvious truths but states them, I think, succinctly. The other point that is made-and it is a distinct argument which ought not to be confused with that first argument about power and accountability-is in terms of diversity of views. Barr states the argument in a short passage which reads:

It is a democratic right for individuals to receive a free flow of information. Monopoly controls reduce variety; the more forms of ownership the greater the chances are of receiving diverse views, opinions, attitudes on a wide range of subjects. The possibility for suppressing particular views is greatest when there are only a few owners.

I believe those propositions are self-evident and would be accepted by honourable senators opposite. I just wish they would accept the implications of those sorts of arguments in the context of this Bill. What all these arguments involve in one way or another is this central core notion of the public interest.

I think one of the best short statements linking those sorts of arguments with the focal point with which we are concerned now is a letter to the Press-in this case, the Melbourne Age-on Wednesday, 22 April from Professor Julius Stone of the Faculty of Law of the University of New South Wales who is, of course, one of Australia's most internationally distinguished jurists. In the interests of brevity and given the lateness of the hour, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard that letter.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
'PUBLIC INTEREST' DEMANDS STRONGER POWERS FOR BROADCASTING TRIBUNAL
from Professor J. Stone, Faculty of Law, University of New South Wales
The notion that monopolistic or oligopolistic control of the media in Australia (especially the electronic media) does not involve 'the public interest' is a startling one.

In democratic politics which seek to hold power responsive to the citizenry, the claims of free belief, opinion, expression and access to the means of expression, approach nearer to absolutes than perhaps any other.

The goals of such a society involve providing for the maximum satisfaction of human demands. These goals are frustrated not only by direct physical suppression of belief and opinion, but by arbitrary control by a few individuals of access to the means of expression.
The fact that radio and television, no less than the Press, require capital commitments of a scale which tends to concentrate more and more power in a few hands, makes this truth more urgent.

To bar the Broadcasting Tribunal from considering such concentration of power in determining 'the public interest' for metropolitan radio and television is, therefore, to trivialise both the tribunal and whatever we mean by 'the public interest'. How can it not concern ''the public interest'' how few people are in key positions for influencing the opinions and beliefs of the community and for controlling their expressions and access to them?

It is no comfort to be told that matters of concentration of media control will henceforth be left to Ministerial guidelines, or even to the Parliament. The threat to democracy comes from concentration in few hands, whether these hands be 'private' or 'public'.
The manipulation of citizen opinion through the media to support political power is as repugnant to our political institutions as is its manipulation by private monopoly or oligopoly.

Both are forbidden by 'the public interest'. Whatever the scope of this slippery notion, it must include the best adjustment available when all competing demands are brought to conscientious judgment by impartial communtiy authority. If, as many believe, there are deficiencies in the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, the remedies lie rather in strengthening than in emasculating its authority and its capacities.
JULIUS STONE Kensington (NSW).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party's amendments with respect to the public interest issues have been moved firstly in the context of the grant of licence, but exactly the same amendments are proposed for all those relevant later parts of the Bill which deal with revocation of licences and approval of share transactions and so on. The principles are the same, but in each case the amendments try to do two quite different things. It seems that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), who is in charge of this Bill, quite failed to appreciate what we are on about in this respect. In the first place we are seeking by these amendments to articulate as clearly as possible some of the specific additional public interest criteria which have already been developed and applied by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, and which are now being abandoned. The first part of our amendment seeks simply to add to the list of specific considerations which the Tribunal should be obliged to have regard to and to take into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect of the amendment is to open out the different public interest criterion by allowing the Tribunal to have regard not 'only' to the matters which are specifically set out but also 'to any other matter and circumstance which it considers appropriate'. What, in effect, the amendment is trying to do-I think the Attorney and Senator Puplick both tended to confuse the issue in the way they approached what they assumed would be the Labor Party amendments in the earlier stages of the debate-is basically to create a general public interest criterion which the Tribunal can apply and have regard to in matters or circumstances which it regards as going to the question of public interest. In particular, it should be obliged to have regard to a whole series of specific matters. Many of them are set out in the Government's amendment. We do not contest them in any way, but we think a number of other more specific criteria of this kind ought to be added and directly drawn to the Tribunal's attention rather than being left to chance.

As to the general part of what we are about-the opening out of the public interest criteria, giving the Tribunal a general residual discretion-this is the last matter I want to advert to-there has been a reluctance in a number of quarters to concede the appropriateness of courts or quasi-judicial tribunals being given open ended public interest criteria of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Right.

—I know that Senator Chipp in particular has expressed his concern. On the other side of the chamber Senator Puplick expressed the opposite view about that. It is a real argument and one to which this chamber needs to address itself. In a sense what the Opposition is trying to do by its amendment is to have it both ways. It wants to have both a set of explicit criteria to which the Tribunal can have specific regard to ensure that those matters are not forgotten altogether; but, in addition, it wants to allow the Tribunal a general open ended discretion.
—My quarrel with you is that you are not being specific enough.

—Let me quickly try to deal with the justification-this will be my final comment-for having an open ended public interest criterion, rather than trying to go all the way down the line and articulate every conceivable ground of public interest that might come into play. There is a very substantial body of thought and argument supporting the view that rather than leaving any open ended discretion we ought to have an extended list, that the Parliament ought to get it right and that responsibility ought to be the Parliament's, not the court's or that of any other quasi-judicial tribunal. Let me say to Senator Chipp and others who share that view that this is something with which I have wrestled, not so much in this context but in the context of the freedom of information legislation where it was a very live issue as to whether there should be a general public criterion governing the release of documents or whether there should be explicit criteria articulating what in essence the public interest considerations are.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the way I personally resolved this dilemma and the way the bipartisan Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs resolved it in the context of freedom of information might help resolve it for Senator Chipp and others. I refer him to that part of the Committee's report on freedom of information-pages 64 to 67-which deals with the question of public interest criteria. In particular I refer to paragraphs 5.25 and 5.29 which make the points most specifically of all. I will read quickly the relevant sections into the record to make it clear. The reference follows a discussion of the Sankey and Whitlam case in 1978 which had extensive regard to the public interest criteria. The discussion in Sankey and Whitlam and the conclusions drawn from it as to the utility of public interest considerations are in my mind, much reinforced by the decision of Mr Justice Mason in the defence papers case involving the Commonwealth and Fairfax at the end of last year which, again, was an admirable demonstration of the way in which courts and tribunals of this kind can effectively and sensibly use open ended public interest criteria. I will quote a couple of sentences from paragraphs 5.25 and 5.29 of the report. Paragraph 5.25 states:
To our mind, this analysis by the court--
This relates to the Sankey case-

indicates that 'public interest' is a convenient and useful concept for aggregating any number of interests that may bear upon a disputed question that is of general-as opposed to merely private-concern. Although in that case--
Again the report refers to the Sankey case-

the starting point was the nebulous interest of 'due administration of justice' and 'proper functioning of the public service', the court broke these down to practical, recognisable considerations that were capable of being weighed, one against the other. The 'public interest' which has been described as an amorphous concept, incapable of useful definition, proved to be a viable concept enabling all relevant considerations to be brought to bear.
In paragraph 5.29, in reference to a number of other cases, it stated:

These cases demonstrate that the relevant public interest factors may vary from case to case-or in the oft-quoted dictum of Lord Hailsham of Marylebone 'The categories of public interest are not closed'. It is essential therefore that wherever the phrase is used the Bill should provide scope for adequate argument as to what result the public interest may require. This scope may only exist if the Tribunal is empowered to adjudicate on the question. 'Public interest' is not a balancing test that is customarily applied by administrators.
Or by executive governments. It continued:
It is a test that must be weighed by an adjudicator who has no interest in the outcome of the proceeding and who is skilled by professional experience in weighing factors one against the other.

It seems to me, and I take it that it seems to Senator Puplick, who has supported this point of view, that there is some real utility in having open-ended discretions of this kind. Indeed, the Tribunal was demonstrating the utility of that kind of language in the earlier Ballarat and Townsville cases. The option to evolve further detailed criteria ought to be allowed to the Tribunal in the view of the Labor Party. So there it is. The new provisions ignore in their terms the cross-media ownership question. They ignore connections at a national and State media level. They not only ignore them; they in fact exclude them from the Tribunal's consideration. The Bill that we now have before us completely emasculates the current pro-competitive provisions of the Act. The purpose of these amendments, to provisions which recur over and over again throughout the Bill, is to perform the necessary restorative surgery following that emasculation and also to inject some hormones into the potential operation of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

I commend the report to the honourable senator for light reading, albeit inadequate material as it is.

I ask the Attorney-General whether he agrees with the view that they are merely guidelines or whether he thinks that they are in fact quite prescriptive. Secondly, I genuinely seek his assistance in relation to proposed new section 82A (6) (c) (ii). I ask the Attorney-General whether he can explain to the Committee the meaning of the following words:
the need to avoid undue concentration of influence, whether direct or indirect, on the person and on the company or companies holding the other licence or licences . . .
It would be helpful if the Attorney-General could enlighten the Committee on that provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters have been raised by these amendments. First of all, let me say that the policy behind the amendments has been to provide a strict, exclusive and prescribed-or however one might like to describe it-consideration for public interest. In other words, they are designed to restrict the consideration of the public interest to the matters raised in the Bill and not to go outside the Bill. Senator Button wanted me to confirm that point although I understood him to accept that as being the intention of the provisions of the Bill. The Government's policy on that matter has already been discussed. We have formed the view that the provision is appropriate. I understood Senator Chipp to be also saying that he wanted the rules to be defined and not be able to be changed.
—Or subject to mass interpret- ation, varying interpretations.

—I suppose one can always get some variations in interpretations, even with matters set out in an Act, but we tried to minimise that as much as possible. That was the thinking behind this legislation. As I understand it, the Administrative Review Council also indicated in its report that it believed that public interest should be defined. One other matter Senator Button raised was the meaning of a fit and proper person and he referred to the fact that the granting of a licence may be refused if it is decided that a person is not a fit and proper person to hold a licence. Of course, that is a question of fact, and I would have thought that a very wide inquiry would be available to the Tribunal in determining that question. I am absolutely sure that I understood the full ambit of Senator Button's query, but certainly we would expect that that inquiry would be a wide one. I cannot see why it could not go behind the actual corporate veil-I think that was the word he used-to see who has control of a company, if that could be established. I do not know of any reason why that should not be possible. Of course, in relation to having a prescribed interest, ownership of shares and so on, there are very wide provisions in the Act in other respects for tracing those interests. In this case it is not set out, but I would have thought that it was open to the Tribunal, in satisfying itself on that matter, to have a very wide inquiry. The other matter in relation to these amendments is one that has been emphasised by Senator Evans. As he said, the Opposition wants, in a sense, to have the best of both worlds. It wants to have reasonable guidelines indicating what the Parliament believes should be taken into account, but it thinks the Tribunal should be able to range as widely as it likes.
—That is not an uncommon drafting technique.

—No, it may be appropriate in some cases if the Parliament cannot give a clear definition as to what its policy on public interest is. However, I think it is desirable that the Parliament should endeavour to do that. I am pleased to say that it has agreed in relation to the freedom of information legislation as well. We have tried to eliminate as far as possible vague concepts of public interest from that piece of legislation. There may be a difference of view between Senator Evans and myself on both this and other matters. The question arises as to what are the appropriate matters to be specified, and whether they are exclusive of non-exclusive. Senator Evans concentrated his remarks very much on the question of the media generally. I think Senator Puplick dealt with that matter rather effectively when he said it was a little late in the day to be raising the question of whether people who own newspapers should or should not have interests in television and radio. It has been with us for a long time, and the major structures in this area presents a feature of such cross-ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: The Broadcasting and Television Act has contained very clear policies for many years, and the Government is certainly supporting and making no attempt to change them. I refer to the basic provisions of limiting ownership and control in the television and radio area. We believe that that is the right way. Parliament may believe that it is too heavy a concentration for a person to hold a prescribed interest in two television stations and eight radio stations. The numbers are limited in any one capital city. We believe that that is the right approach. The Act makes those provisions. The Tribunal should not be able to restrict them. If Parliament believes the provision is not restrictive enough it ought to make special provision.

The only other point that I have to deal with is the point raised by Senator Button concerning page 11 of the Bill and the restriction on concentration of influence in regard to commercial licences outside the metropolitan area. This may be rather a drafting type question, but I am advised that the language is designed to indentify any situation in which there is an undue concentration of interest, whether direct or indirect, from whatever quarter in respect of the applicant and the existing licensees-both radio and television. Linguistically the word 'on' instead of 'of' is the correct usage. I take it that that was the concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one of the concerns.
—I thought that that was the concern; it was my concern when I looked at the Bill. I think what is intended is clear enough; no doubt there are different ways of expressing it.
—Is it intended to include print media influence as well as other electronic media influence? Is it intended to apply to cross-media ownership type influence in this area?
—The provision relates to the persons or companies holding the other licence or licences under the Act, so it does not include media interests other than broadcasting and television.
—Does not?
—It does not; that is certainly the intention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the point that I directed to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) regarding proposed new section 92FAA which is mentioned on page 41 of the Bill. Perhaps the Attorney cannot provide an answer to my question tonight. The proposed new section states that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal shall, by notice in writing served on the applicant, approve a transaction insofar as it affects the applicant. That provision is subject to proposed new sub-section (2). Proposed new sub-paragraph (2) (c) (ii) states:

SPEECH.PARA: if the applicant is a prescribed party, within the meaning of section 92F, to the transaction-the Tribunal is satisfied that approval of the transaction should be refused in whole or in part in so far as it affects the applicant by reason that the applicant-
(A) is not a fit and proper person-

I was concerned to find out whether the involvement of a nominee company in this situation would avoid the whole purpose of this provision as it was explained by the Attorney. Would it not avoid becoming a prescribed party within these provisions? The consequence of that, I think-I would be very pleased to know whether this is the Government's intention-is that in that situation it would not be possible for the Tribunal to look behind the applicant, that is, to look behind the corporate veil. If that is the intention of the legislation I understand that as being quite specific in terms of the original purpose of the legislation and why it was conceived. If that is not the intention of the legislation I would be happy to have clarification of that from the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that I take notice of that question and endeavour to deal with it by the time we get to that clause as we are going through the Bill. I am not sure what the honourable senator meant in relation to 'a fit and proper person'.

'(iii) where the licence is for a regional broadcasting or television station-whether, having regard to the degree of control and influence in the media in the particular region concerned, the granting of the licence would not be in the interests of the public in that region as they relate to the broadcasting and television services available to them; or'.

The effect of amendment No. 13 is to remove a provision which will, if passed, be used to increase control of broadcasting and television stations. At present a prescribed interest in a television station is limited to 5 per cent and no one can have more than two prescribed interests in a television station. In the view of the Opposition the proposed new section would permit the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to disregard those limitations if it is not the person coming before the Tribunal who has acquired a prescribed interest. The intention of this provision in the Bill is to let off the institutional investors, so-called, from an inadvertent breach charge. What we of the Opposition argue is that the amended legislation will permit someone to acquire control up to a 15 per cent interest in a television station by way of a nominee company without section 92, which is referred to in clause 19 (1E), disqualifying the applicant as having a prescribed interest in too many stations. We seek to delete this because in our view it creates an anomoly in that someone can set up a nominee company to which these words in the clause which we seek to have deleted would apply. That is the purpose of our amendment because the clause simply permits an evasion of the intention of the legislation by the establishment of a nominee company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we on the Government side understand it, the purpose of the amending clause is to deny the Broadcasting Tribunal the power to transfer a licence in the face of the contravention when that would result in any person having an interest less than a controlling interest even though it is clear that all reasonable steps are being taken to bring that contravention to an end, and we think that is perfectly reasonable.

The amendments which I have moved have the consequence of reinstating the requirement of prior notice of transactions. Some of the reasons for these amendments were hinted at during the second reading debate and were discussed. In summary terms, they simply point out that broadcasting is not like any other industry and from a social and political point of view it should not be regarded as being like any other industry. We are also concerned at this farce of the six months' grace period. Both Senator Chipp and I commented on that in the course of the second reading debate. That is the purpose of those amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney a hypothetical question. I know that it is a little late at night for hypothetical questions, but I raised this matter in the second reading debate. I asked: Is it possible for a person who now owns a television station-I gave, with due apologies, the example of Kerry Packer who now owns a television station-and a commodity like 60 Minutes to threaten a regional station? Could that person say: 'You buy my 60 Minutes program at an outrageous price or I will buy you out'? If that person then buys out that regional station, he has a period of grace up to the time of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's hearing and then six months after that. Then, if the Tribunal makes him divest himself of his shares he could say: 'I will sell them to our friends who will take our 60 Minutes program at the outrageous price we offered'. Again, I apologise to Kerry Packer. I used the name simply because it suits the purpose of the hypothetical question. I ask the Attorney: Is it possible, under this legislation for someone in that situation to bully the management or the owners of a regional station to do what he wanted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether that specific situation is catered for in this legislation. New provision 92M as set out on page 46 of the Bill deals with the situation where a person has, without prior approval, gone in and obtained control of a company with a licence. If that person then was seeking to take action which would affect the licence, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal may, as this provision provides, give directions as it thinks fit for the purpose of preventing the person from doing an act or thing which would have an adverse effect on the ability of a company to comply with the conditions of a licence or the operations conducted under the licence. The idea of that provision is to enable the Tribunal to keep control over management which may be taking action which would jeopardise the licence. I think that proposed new section would contain a fair bit of power to stop that sort of thing happening.
—Provided they could prove it.
—One can go to the Tribunal under this provision. Presumably it would have the complaint before it and could establish the facts.
—Not a standover threat on a telephone.
—One might have that sort of problem in proving any facts in any circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of amendments to clause 26-amendments Nos (17), (18) and (19)-which all deal with the question of foreign interests in radio and television. I should point out that Opposition amendment No. (17) deals with what we consider to be a possible ambiguity in proposed new section 90G (2) as to whether the 20 per cent limit on foreign ownership applies separately to foreign ownership acquired before and foreign ownership acquired after the commencement of the Act. I ask the Attorney to have a look at this amendment because I am not sure what his intentions are. We think there is an ambiguity. We believe that the amendment would clarify the ambiguity and aggregate all foreign interests, whether acquired before or after the commencement of this legislation. I would have thought that it was the intention that they should be so aggregated. But under the existing clause in the Bill it is not in our view clear that they are. That is the purport of amendment No. (17) which is the first of our amendments relating to clause 26. Perhaps it is a matter on which some advice could be obtained from the Attorney-General's Department.

SPEECH.PARA: The second amendment-amendment No. (18)-involves leaving out the word 'citizen' where it appears in proposed new section 90G (3) and reinserting the word 'resident'. I do not know whether Government senators who are dozing in their places really want the Australian broadcasting system to be controlled by Australian citizens living in Hong Kong, Macao or somewhere else. If they do they will support the legislation. I do not know whether they are concerned about that possiblity. I see that Senator Bjelke-Peterson is. She would be concerned about a Victorian company, let alone a Chinese one, controlling a Queensland company. That is what this amendment is about. It seeks to restore the definition of 'resident'. The resident requirements in the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act, if this legislation is passed, will be quite different from those in the foreign investment legislation. For that reason we move that the word be changed back to 'resident', so that to be in a position of control one has to be a resident of this country.

The third amendment, which is amendment No. (19), tightens the tracing provisions for foreign ownership to the same degree as exists elsewhere in the principal Act. We see every reason why foreign ownership tracing provisions should be at least as strong if not stronger than the other tracing provisions in the legislation. They will not be if this amending legislation is passed. I seek leave to move together those three amendments which deal with the question of foreign interests in Australian radio and television companies.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Page 23, clause 26, proposed new section 90G, line 10 at end of sub-section (2), insert the following new sub-section:

'(2A) For the purposes of this section holdings acquired by foreign persons before the commencement of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1981 shall be aggregated with those holdings acquired by foreign persons after its enactment.'.
(18) Page 23, clause 26, proposed new sub-section 90G (3), paragraph (a), line 13, leave out 'citizen', insert 'resident'.

We find it rather quaint that the Government wants to put 'resident' in and the Opposition wants to put 'citizen' in. The Democrats ask: Why has the Government not put both in so that the clause refers to a natural person who is not an Australian citizen and resident? Is there any reason why the two cannot go in?

It is the intention that they should be aggregated. My advice is that that is the effect of the clause. Therefore, we do not believe that that amendment is necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: The other amendments raise the major issues as to foreign ownership. They have been canvassed in the debate and I do not propose to go over that ground again. Senator Chipp has asked why we cannot have a test requiring that a person be both a citizen and a resident. Of course that would make the legislation more restrictive than it is now. At present the requirement is that a person be a resident. In fact an Australian resident who is not a citizen has a licence in Australia. If one were to make it both 'citizen' and 'resident' of course that would be more restrictive than the present provision. It really is a matter of choice as to what is the more appropriate test in this situation. The Government believes that Australian citizenship is the appropriate test rather than residency in these circumstances. Residence in Australia may be quite an impermanent situation. There are difficulties about determining whether a person is resident. That certainly has been clarified by the experience with the test. On the other hand the test of citizenship is a much more definite one. It seems rather strange to impose the idea that an Australian citizen should not be entitled to acquire interests under this Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister that Australian citizenship really is pretty easy to obtain if one knows the ropes. I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the scenario which has been postulated-if I may use those two dreadful words 'scenario' and 'postulated'-by Senator Chipp, for example, in regard to amendment No. (19). That scenario is simply that any Hong Kong investor can acquire now a 49 per cent interest, or up to a 50 per cent interest, in an Australian investment company. That investment company can then obtain 50 per cent interest in an Australian television licence and that investment company is not deemed to be a foreign company for the purposes of this legislation. I ask the Attorney-General whether it is also a fact that the scenario can be double headed, that is, two Hong Kong companies could each acquire up to a 50 per cent interest in separate Australian investment companies-say, company Durack and company Bonner-and those two companies then buy between them what is effectively a 100 per cent interest in an Australian television licence, and neither of those investment companies will be deemed to be foreign companies for the purpose of this legislation, once it is amended. I ask the Attorney-General whether he agrees with that. I am not asking whether he agrees with it as a matter of principle but whether he agrees with that interpretation.

—As far as the first scenario is concerned, the answer is yes, that would be the effect of the provision. I have difficulty in understanding how the second one could apply, because the requirement is to exercise control of more than 50 per cent.
—It is done by adding one and one, which makes two.

—I understand now what the honourable senator means. You mean two 50s. I will have to consider that. Let me deal with the first question. The way in which the legislation has been drafted is in accordance with the way in which the existing Act has been interpreted. It is a new provision as far as the Act is concerned, but it is not a new provision. That was certainly the decision in the Thomas Nationwide Transport Pty Ltd case in which, although it was not a holding of actually 50 per cent, it was a very high percentage. I do not know what it was. The decision was based on the interpretation of the existing Act to which this new provision gives effect. There is no doubt about it. That is the intention and it is based upon existing practice.
—That is the only time you look at a decision in this Bill and base your drafting on the existing practice, is it not?

—The purpose was not so much to give effect to existing practice as to clarify the doubt that there was in the old Act and make it perfectly clear that that was what the old Act meant. In fact, that has been the interpretation that has been adopted by the Tribunal.

—What you are saying is this Bill now makes it perfectly clear that two overseas companies could in fact take over totally ownership of an Australian television company? That is what you are saying, is it not?
—The purpose was, as I said, to give effect to the interpretation being placed on the existing Act.
—But it does not do that. It goes much further than that, and you know that.

—The question is whether the actual situation that Senator Chipp raises could arise. I suppose it may well be possible. But there are other questions that the Tribunal would address in relation to whether a licence would be given to a company in that situation.
—Such as whether the application is by a fit and proper person?
—That would be one example. Therefore, there is power in the Tribunal to cope with the situation if it should actually arise in that way.

—Why does the Government propose to give the Tribunal power to act in that way in relation to the potential control of Australian television stations by foreign companies and, elsewhere in the legislation, to deny the Tribunal power, for example, to exercise a discretion as to what is in the public interest in relation to Australian television companies and investment companies? Is that not a double standard? The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in answering my question has intimated that the legislation would allow the Tribunal power and discretion in relation to whether foreign interests could control foreign television stations, but apparently would not allow it to determine what is in the public interest insofar as Australian companies are concerned. I ask the Attorney-General whether that is the position.
