INTERJECT.PARA: The speech read as follows-

The Bill now before the Senate represents the results of much careful and difficult work carried out to establish appropriate provisions to deal in a general way with the sort of artificial schemes of tax avoidance with which of recent times we have become only too familiar. In short, this Bill proposes new general anti-avoidance measures to replace section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

As I shall explain in more detail later, the measures in the Bill are designed to operate against avoidance schemes of a blatant, artificial or contrived kind and to have an impact in respect of both domestic and international transactions.

In the international area, however, even more is needed by way of a general legislative response to problems of avoidance of Australian tax and, as announced by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in introducing this Bill in the House of Representatives, the Government will be proposing changes to section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act which is, of course, the provision dealing generally with avoidance in international business and transactions.

Honourable senators will be aware that for some time now the Government has been actively carrying through processes to design provisions to overcome the limitations on the scope of section 260 that have been revealed by a series of court decisions.

In view of the special nature of this task, the processes have not been confined to the work carried out by officials, but have extended to taking advice from senior private counsel and from the Taxation Advisory Committee.

This external advice along with contributions from the Government Members' Taxation Committee have played a significant part in determining the final form of the Bill. The Government is appreciative of the contributions that have been made.
And it is appropriate on this occasion to say that the Bill substantially accords with advice coming to the Government from both official and non-official sources.
Mr President, it is the belief of the Government that there is a wide community consensus that Australia must have an effective general anti-avoidance provision.
There is widespread abhorrence of blatant tax avoidance of the kind that we have recently experienced.
It distorts in a most unacceptable way the relative burdens of tax that are borne by different sectors of the community.
In pursuing the Government's firm resolve to counter this kind of activity we have, over the past 3 years or so, introduced a series of specific, yet complex, anti-avoidance measures.

That has been a necessary response in the circumstances, but unless something is done along general lines there is a very real danger that our income tax legislation will become so volumin- ous and so complicated as to be virtually incomprehensible.
I do not say that the measures in this Bill will provide a cure-all in respect of all future avoidance arrangements.

The problems inherent in expressing solutions in a general, but controlled, way may mean that there will be tax avoidance arrangements contrived in the future that escape being struck down by the new measures.
As to that, let me say simply that the Government will, where necessary, follow up this measure with whatever further action may be appropriate in the circumstances.
What is it that general anti-avoidance provisions should aim to achieve? Few people have faced up squarely to that question.
This Government has faced up to it, and also to the probably even more difficult problem of finding the legal language in which to express the conclusions reached about desired policy objectives.
We are acutely aware that the term 'tax avoidance' means different things to different people.

Reasonable men and women are bound to differ on this crucial question and on the subsidiary matter of the appropriate tests for determining what behavior a general anti-avoidance provision ought to proscribe.

The proposed provisions-embodied in a new Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act-seek to give effect to a policy that such measures ought to strike down blatant, artificial or contrived arrangements, but not cast unnecessary inhibitions on normal commercial transactions by which taxpayers legitimately take advantage of opportunities available for the arrangement of their affairs.
For example, a husband and wife who choose to run a business as partners will need have no fear of having their arrangements affected by Part IVA.
There will be no question, either, of the new provisions impeding a parent who wishes to pass to a spouse or to children the use and enjoyment of some income-producing assets.
Some writers on the subject suggest that tax avoidance involves conduct entered into for the sole or dominant purpose of obtaining a particular tax advantage.

That description could be expected to cover the types of tax avoidance that, again using the language of social or political debate, are blatant, artificial or contrived, and which are indeed intended to be covered by this Bill.

But it is also apt to describe other arrangements, including some family arrangements, which are beyond the appropriate scope of general anti-avoidance measures and ought, if need be, to be dealt with by specific measures.

In order to confine the scope of the proposed provisions to schemes of the 'blatant' or 'paper' variety, the measures in this Bill are expressed so as to render ineffective a scheme whereby a tax benefit is obtained and an objective examination, having regard to the scheme itself and to its surrounding circumstances and practical results, leads to the conclusion that the scheme was entered into for the sole or dominant purpose of obtaining a tax benefit.
Certainly, different approaches might have been taken.
The Government tried many of them in the course of developing this Bill.

One possibility considered was to adopt the language of the Privy Council in the well-known decision in Newton's case, and, positive tests of inclusion having been expressed, make the new provisions inapplicable to schemes entered into in the course of 'ordinary business or family dealing'. It has been decided, however, that the better test of what is 'blatant', 'contrived' or 'artificial' is the positive one that has been adopted.

That test seems best to capture the essence of the views expressed by the Privy Council which, in fact, characterised an 'ordinary business or family dealing' as representing a situation other than one of which it can be predicated that it was implemented in the particular way so as to avoid tax.
I have already said that one of the conditions for the application of the new Part IVA is to be that a taxpayer has obtained what the Bill terms a 'tax benefit'.

Such a benefit will have been obtained if, after all other provisions of the income tax law have been applied, an amount is not included in a taxpayer's assessable income that might reasonably be expected to have been included if the scheme had not been entered into.

The other form of tax benefit covered by the Bill concerns an amount that, again after all other provisions have been applied, is an allowable deduction to a taxpayer, but is one the whole or a part of which might reasonably be expected not to have been allowable if the scheme had not been entered into.

This approach-of specifying in the new provisions what constitutes a tax benefit and that the relevant purpose for application of the provisions is one of obtaining such a benefit-should help to eliminate some of the uncertainties associated with the use in section 260 of less precise expressions.
That section uses phrases that speak of 'altering the incidence of any income tax' and 'defeating, evading or avoiding any duty or liability imposed on any person by this Act.'

These very wide, but uncertain, expressions appear to have been at the root of the development by the courts of the so-called 'choice principle', a rule of interpretation which, together with other established defects, has greatly limited the scope of section 260.
There are two other significant limitations on the effectiveness of section 260 which the new part can be expected to remove.
The present section does not permit the purposes of the persons entering into an arrangement to be enquired into, except by reference to the effect of the arrangement itself.
Moreover, it does not provide a power or procedure, once an arrangement is struck down, to reconstruct a taxable situation.
As to these points, I have already mentioned that, under the provisions of this Bill, an inquiry must be made, on objective grounds, into the purpose of a person who entered into the arrangement.
The 'reconstruction' problem is to be overcome by an express provision for the cancellation of a tax benefit obtained under a scheme to which the Part applies.
Authority will be given to the Commissioner of Taxation to eliminate the benefit in an appropriate way.
In other words, the Commissioner will be specifically authorised to disallow the whole or an appropriate part of a deduction or to include in assessable income an omitted amount.
This method of eliminating the sought-after benefit, or part of it, is designed also to remove another uncertainty which surrounded the application of section 260.
It was unclear whether an arrangement to which that section applied had to be treated as wholly void or could be treated as only partly void as against the Commissioner.

I draw to the attention of honourable senators that Part IVA contains a supplementary code applicable to schemes that are commonly called dividend stripping-and to similar schemes-under which shareholders in effect receive company profits in a tax-free form, in substitution for taxable dividends.

The reason for such specially-tailored provisions within the new general measures is to be found in particular features of such schemes when viewed in the context of the structure it has been necessary to give to the basic provisions of Part IVA.
It is this.

When profits have been accumulating in a company, possibly for extended periods, there will be no clear answer to the question whether those profits might reasonably be expected to have been distributed as dividends if the scheme had not been entered into.
As often as not, that expectation could not be established to exist.
Where this is so-and despite the fact that the company had been stripped of profits-the result under the basic provisions would be that there is technically no 'tax benefit' obtained.
Dividend stripping cannot be allowed to escape the new provisions on a technicality of this kind.

In the simpler schemes of dividend stripping, assets of a company are generally converted into cash, the shareholders sell their shares for a capital sum and the purchaser arranges for the profits of the company to be stripped by way of a tax-free dividend or other payment from the company.
The purchaser is thus reimbursed for the price of the shares, while the former owners have effectively obtained the accumulated profits of the company in a tax-free form.
Other schemes of a dividend stripping kind involve the sale of shares in 'current year profit' companies.
Both kinds of scheme are within the supplementary code.

The dividend stripping provisions will treat a shareholder who disposes of his or her shares in the context of one of these schemes as having obtained a tax benefit of the amount which he or she would have derived as a dividend if the profits stripped under the scheme had been paid as a dividend.
A tax benefit so obtained will be subject to the new general provisions for cancellation of tax benefits that I have described.

Where a tax benefit has been cancelled under Part IVA, the Commissioner of Taxation will be empowered to effect corresponding adjustments to reduce the tax liability of others affected by the arrangements, if it is fair and reasonable in the circumstances to do so.
Another key part of the legislation covers the imposition of statutory additional tax on taxpayers whose future schemes are struck down by Part IVA.

Bearing in mind that the Part is concerned with blatant, contrived and artificial schemes, the Government has concluded that taxpayers who, in the face of it, wish to persist with such schemes should be exposed to something more than only the tax they seek to avoid.

We have seen it as highly relevant that a taxpayer who omits assessable income from a return, or who claims deductions in excess of expenditure actually incurred, is liable to statutory additional tax of twice the tax avoided.
Accordingly, a taxpayer to whom the new Part applies will be liable by statute to pay an amount of additional tax equal to double the tax sought to be avoided.

As under the existing provisions, however, that amount will be subject to remission by the Commissioner of Taxation and his decision will similarly, on objection by the taxpayer, be open to review by one of the independent taxation boards of review.

I add the observation that, in the absence of these penalty provisions, taxpayers would have the 'odds to nothing' in participating in future avoidance schemes and in risking the application of Part IVA.

The provisions of Part IVA as a whole will operate with paramount force in the income tax law, but only in relation to schemes entered into after 27 May 1981, the date of introduction of the Bill into the Parliament.

However, in line with settled policy in relation to anti-avoidance legislation, carry-forward losses resulting from schemes that had already been entered into will not be available for deduction against income of the 1980-81 or any later year.
In harmony with the rules for application of Part IVA, section 260 is being made inapplicable to arrangements entered into after 27 May.

There are, of course, other things of note about the Bill but these are covered by the comprehensive explanatory memorandum available to honourable senators and I think it is not necessary for me to speak about them at this stage.
I do, however, want to touch on just one point.

This is that the Bill indicates specifically that a tax benefit cannot arise in respect of the deduction available for deposits made under the income equalisation deposits scheme, and that the mere making of an election or the giving of a notice specifically provided for in the Act will not be affected by Part IVA.

I note these things as a prelude to my response to concern that I can foresee being expressed in some quarters that taxpayers who simply take advantage of certain incentives in the law will find themselves at risk under Part IVA.

Other critics of the Bill will, no doubt, say that arrangements that survive the application of specific anti-avoidance provisions inserted to support particular provisions are in double jeopardy in then having to face and survive the paramount general provisions.
I made no apology for the approach adopted in the Bill.
But I do assert that taxpayers who simply take advantage of concessions for the purposes for which they were put in the law cannot and will not be affected by the new provisions.

Specifically, for example, Part IVA will not deny to people who simply respond to our concessions for investment in Australian films the benefit of the tax advantages that are part of those concessions.
But I think it incontrovertible that blatant misuse of those and other 'incentive' concessions ought to be within the scope of Part IVA.

A general anti-avoidance provision would be of little worth if it could not be used to prevent the unintended exploitation of such concessions in the law, or to operate as a back-up to a specific anti-avoidance provision in circumstances where a taxpayer has tailored arrangements so that the provision is circumvented in form, but not in substance.
Mr President, the measures contained in this Bill together with the proposed changes to section 136 that have been outlined by the Treasurer are, by any test, significant ones.
Leaving aside those with an axe to grind, some people may be concerned about the breadth of the measures.
We will probably hear a lot about their 'uncertainty'.
To that I say that any problems of that kind are an inevitable outcome of the approach of tackling a widespread and intricate problem by provisions of a general kind.
I believe that the measures represent a sober, and appropriately restrained, response to a difficult problem and will be welcomed by all responsible members of the community.
I warmly commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill contains measures to give effect to the income tax concessions for investors in Australian films that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) first outlined in the policy speech for the election last October.
A joint statement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment on 18 December last set out details of the concession in a comprehensive way.
In those circumstances, I think it is sufficient in this introductory speech to draw attention to the key points of the legislation now brought forward.
The Bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide a deduction equal to 150 per cent of capital expenditure on the acquisition of the initial copyright in a new Australian film.
Also to be provided by the Bill is a tax exemption for an investor's net earnings from such a film.
The maximum exemption is an amount equal to 50 per cent of the capital expenditure that qualifies for the 150 per cent deduction.

To be entitled to the deduction, an investor must become the first owner, or one of the first owners, of the copyright in a film that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment certifies to be an eligible Australian film.
The Bill contains extensive guidelines that the Minister is required to have regard to in deciding whether or not to certify a film as eligible.
Primarily, a film must have an appropriate Australian content.
Tests in existing legislation authorising a deduction over two years for investment in films will be used for that purpose.
The Minister's function will, however, go further than the process of certification of Australian content.
As set out in the Bill he will also have the responsibility of determining whether a particular film is one produced for exhibition to the public cinemas or by way of television broadcasting.
To qualify, a film must be a feature film, a documentary or a mini-series of television drama.
Day-to-day productions, such as commercials, variety programs and films of sporting or other public events will not be eligible.
I turn now to the classes of expenditure that will be eligible for the special deductions and the time at which the deductions will be available.
Only expenditure under contracts entered into on or after 1 October 1980 will qualify.
The legislation will, of course, express the deductions to be available to companies and individuals who incur eligible expenditure.
Partnerships are, however, a common vehicle for film production arrangements and the legislation therefore contains some special provisions in this respect.
The Bill provides that each partner is to be taken to have personally incurred his or her share of expenditure incurred by the partnership.
As is usual in the tax context, expenditure will qualify only if incurred with a view to production of assessable income.

Only expenditure outlaid directly in the production of a film will qualify, but the legislation is framed so that, again taking into account practices in the film industry, individuals or partners whose expenditure is in the form of a contribution to a production account will enjoy the deduction to the extent that the moneys contributed are so outlaid.

Among safeguards necessary to protect these generous concessions from unintended exploitation are measures to counter inflation of film production costs above the levels which persons dealing at arm's length would pay.

Another key provision is based on the concept that, if taxpayers are to enjoy a deduction of 150 per cent of their outlays, they should only do so for moneys in respect of which they are at risk of a true economic loss.
The 'at-risk' requirement in the legislation will limit the special deduction to expenditure that is not greater in amount than that for which the person is at risk of loss in relation to the film.

To illustrate, if a person is protected against loss because the financier who has supplied moneys to expend on the film has recourse only against the film, or income from it, that person will not be at risk.

Nor will a partner in a limited partnership be regarded under the legislation as at risk for a share of expenditure out of borrowed funds which, because it exceeds capital personally contributed, represents money for which, under the rules of such partnerships, the partner is not liable.
People whose risk of loss is removed or abated simply because they are able, before the film is made, to find a market for it will not run foul of the at-risk test.
However, a person who, under one and the same arrangement, borrows money to expend on a film and is guaranteed a flow of income from the film is in a different situation.
To the extent of the guaranteed income the investment of the borrowed funds is in no way at risk.
In these cases, the special deduction will not be available for any amount not really at risk.
I come now to the question of when the special deduction is to be available.

When details of the concession were announced last December it was indicated that the deduction would be available in the year of income in which the investor expends capital moneys in or towards the production of the film.

Measures of a safeguarding kind that were foreshadowed then were to operate so that deductions were, however, not allowable if the film was not completed and marketed to produce a yield for investors.

The Government has since concluded that it would be appropriate to vary these rules, but I stress that only a change in the time for taking deductions under the scheme is involved in the variation that is reflected in the Bill before the Senate.
I note that there has been very strong response to the Government's initiative.
To the end of May, application for certification as Australian films had been made in respect of 200 films and the total budgeted cost for them is some $145m.
Unhappily, there has also been noted some intervention by elements whose only concern appears to be exploitation of the concession in unacceptable ways.
Responsible film authorities have registered their concern about that.
The safeguarding measures I referred to a moment ago would not have been completely effective in closing off avenues for exploitation and would have significantly further complicated the legislation.
Accordingly, the Government decided that, fundamentally, deductions should not be available until the relevant film has both been completed and used to produce income.

However, in the light of representations received since the Bill was brought before the House of Representatives, the deduction is to be allowed on the originally-announced basis for expenditure under contracts entered into on or before 27 May 1981.

Mr President, I note that representations have been made to the Government that the effect of the modifications to the December Statement will be to direct investment away from quality productions which may take some time to reach the market place.
The Government has examined these comments carefully but does not consider that, with the exception of pre-28 May contracts, they should lead to any departure from the approach taken in the bill.

It should be remembered that even with the change in the timing of deductions-and I stress again that the modification means no more than that-the concession remains extremely generous and is unparalled in our taxation law.

The taxation benefits conferred by the Scheme, plus the ordinary economic incentive to obtain a maximum return on any investment, should result in moneys being attracted to quality productions having the potential for significant box-office success.

This incentive towards quality is in fact reinforced by the second limb of the concessions, the income exemption, which in itself is a strong incentive to investment in films with potential for success.
Nevertheless, the operation of the scheme will be carefully monitored over the next six to 12 months and, if the need is demonstrated, appropriate action will be taken.

I also observe that a misconception seems to have arisen as to how the modification will apply in circumstances where a qualifying film is produced and televised in parts, for example, as a mini-series of television drama.

In relation to such productions a separate copyright exists in each complete part, with the result that expenditure in the production of a particular part will qualify for deduction when that part is completed and used in the production of income.

Turning now in detail to the exempt income side of the new concessions, a person eligible for the deduction will be exempt from tax on proceeds from the film, with an exemption limit of 50 per cent of the qualifying amount expended in producing the film.
Reflecting this, there are in the Bill previously foreshadowed measures that set out what are to be regarded as proceeds from a film for this purpose.

In brief, all proceeds-whether technically of a capital or income kind-are to be taken into account, as well as foreign-source income, otherwise exempt from tax, that does not flow from the overseas country in which the film is exhibited.
These rules are, of course, of an anti-avoidance kind.

Related and previously foreshadowed provisions of the Bill require that expenditure of a revenue nature be set off only against film income and that film losses arising in one year be carried forward only for deduction against film income.
Mr President, I do not think that I need say more at this stage.

A memorandum has been prepared to explain the detailed provisions of the Bill, and is being circulated to honourable senators. Also being circulated is a supplementary memorandum which explains the amendments made in the House of Representatives to give effect to the Government's decisions on the timing of the new deduction.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on this Bill was adjourned on 4 June I had started to speak on the media. I repeat what I said at the time. This is not intended to be an exercise of bashing the media; rather it is a plea to the media for a better, more responsible and, if at all possible, a restrained presentation of the news and reports of events in Australia and overseas. The column 'On the other hand', until recently was written by Mr Guy Harriott, a prominent journalist who unfortunately passed away only a few days ago. Under the heading 'Press made the scapegoat for bungling politicians', when referring to the Press, he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The manner in which it performs this function can be the subject of legitimate criticism;-

I have a criticism of the Press in relation to its handling of my contribution to the debate on the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill on 13 May 1981. When I spoke previously, I quoted from the Hansard of that date. To save time I will not repeat what I quoted from the Hansard but only what the Age reported on 14 May. It stated:

Senator Lajovic (Liberal, New South Wales) asked for an explanation of why the provision was necessary. He recalled that he came from a country with a communist regime (Yugoslavia) and did not want to see anything similar here.

At that point the debate was adjourned. If anybody can find any similarity between my speech in the Senate and the report in the Age under the heading: 'Three disputes add to Government's troubles' by Stephen Mills, it would be a strange coincidence. It is quite possible that Mr Mills was not able to understand what I said. On the other hand, he may be a new man in a new job. There is also the possibility that he is an aspiring fiction writer, as it is quite obvious that he used a lot of imagination to write what he wrote. I have never asked the Minister 'for an explanation of why the provision was necessary'. I have never 'recalled that I came from a country with a communist regime (Yugoslavia)'. I have never said that 'I did not want to see anything similar here'. (Quorum formed). The fact is that in the seven lines he wrote about me the only true information given was my name, my party and the State I represent. I repeat that Guy Harriott stated:
The manner in which it-
that is the Press-
performs this function can be the subject of legitimate criticism;-

One of its functions is to report what is happening in the national Parliament. I now ask: Who was bungling in this instance? It was certainly not a politician, but a journalist whose report appears in a major daily newspaper which is supposedly ranked among the best in this country. How can anyone believe anything he or she reads in the Press when such sloppy reporting is allowed and tolerated by the people responsible for the printing of such irresponsible reports? This is only one instance that I am citing as it concerns me directly. How often does it occur in the thousands and thousands of reports and articles which are published in the Press.

There are many cases in which I was able to observe, to be kind to the journalists the same cavalier treatment of facts concerning events, in our Parliament. Unfortunately it is a fact also that the media tends to exaggerate. Certainly, this is their way of achieving bigger sales or higher ratings. But the effect that this kind of treatment of facts has had on the reader is another matter. I have many examples of the points I make. I have selected only a few which came to my notice recently. The Sydney Morning Herald of 27 April 1981 published an article under the title 'The sorry tale of a reporter who lied', showing the lack of responsibility in the journalists' ranks not only at the reporters' level but also in the supervisory capacity. That article states:
The Washington Post, which should know, has described it as 'the most far-ranging debate in a decade on how newspapers do their jobs'.

Certainly the sad, sordid story of 'Jimmy's world'-the fabricated article about an eight-year-old heroin addict that won Washington Post reporter Janet Cooke a Pulitzer prize which has since been withdrawn-has created unparalleled turmoil within the American newspaper industry.

No wonder if it appeared in a newspaper with such a reputation. It is interesting to note what Bob Woodward of Watergate fame-now the Post's Assistant Managing Editor for metropolitan news-recalled later. He said:
'This story-
He was referring to the story by Janet Cooke-
was so well written and tied together so well that my alarm bells simply didn't go off. My scepticism left me. I was personally negligent'.
But even stranger is what this article says later on.

The Post stuck by its story and insisted on its right or protest it reporter's sources. In spite of scepticism among many Post reporters, and even some executives, the 'Jimmy' hoax might never have been exposed had it not been nominted by the Post's senior editors for a Pulitzer.

This brings the following question to my mind: How often do we read so-called authentic stories which could quite easily be a fraud when even a paper like the Washington Post can fall for a cleverly imaginative reporter hiding behind so-called rights to protect reporters' sources. I was suprised when I read that a man as eminent as Mr Justice Kirby was recently quoted in the Daily Telegraph of 29 May as predicting:
Changes in the law to protect individual privacy and to give journalists the privilege not to disclose sources of information could be on the way.

Would that change of law give a protection to any reporter to hide behind such a law and write a story which would be nothing but a figment of his imagination? The same thing happened to New York Daily News columnist Michael Daly, as reported in the Australian of 16 May 1981 under the title 'Media Snipers take Aim at another phoney'. That article states:
New York Daily News columnist Michael Daly has not been so lucky resigning from the paper after a story he wrote about Northern Ireland was challenged as a 'pack of lies' by the London Daily Mail.

Mr Daly quoted a British soldier named Christopher Spell saying: 'Go for their heads', and 'If I'm lucky, the little Fenian will die' during a shooting incident between soldiers and a group of Irish youths in Belfast.
Announcing Mr Daly's resignation, new editor, Michael O'Neill, said Daly had admitted inventing the name Christopher Spell, and that he was 'unable to substantiate the story'.
The writer never signalled the reader it was an anonymous source.

What worried me even more was the report in the Australian of 17 May 1981 under the title 'Hungry for war the world's press urges Ireland on'. The article relates the facts which, to me, represent the greatest lack of responsibility which can be found and which show exploitation of the tragic situation in Ireland. The article states:
Have correspondents of the world's press based in Northern Ireland been reporting riots or inciting them?

'For the first time in 12 years of covering the world's conflicts and especially the troubles in Northern Ireland', said British news photographer Tony McGrath, 'I have felt sufficiently angry and disturbed to question seriously the objectivity of some of my colleagues'.
One American newspaperman resigned after his graphic description of Belfast rioting was exposed as a fabrication.
American television crewmen and photographers from other nations have been accused, MaGrath said, of 'paying young thugs to throw rocks and bottles at passing army vehicles'.

There is no doubt some newsmen desperate to provide hungry audiences with colorful words and dramatic film-helped fuel the fire and perhaps unwittingly, spread propaganda pleasing to many factions of the republican cause, most notably the main IRA groups.
Further, the same reporter said:

British news photographer Brian Harris said he heard an American photographer shout to a child: 'Can you do that again? I didn't get you throwing that rock'. Harris said: 'I saw kids standing with bottles in their hands, holding them up to the cameras and saying: 'Over here, I've got one'. That was when I left.

Is there no decency in today's journalistic world? Is there no self-restraint imposed by the profession to regulate and discipline such irresponsible people? Is it any wonder that we have more and more crime and cruelty in our society when our media focuses its attention on and gives front page headlines and prominence to rioters and those who break the law and constantly emphasises in big 10 centimetre headlines, words such as: 'revolt', 'crisis', 'butchery', and all possible superlatives? (Quorum formed) When our media constantly emphasises in big 10 centimetre headlines words such as: 'revolt', 'crisis', 'butchery', and all possible superlatives describing the lowest instincts and actions of human beings, I ask: What can we expect from our young people when they are fed daily the headlines such as 'scandal', 'murder' and 'treason'? Do we really have to suffer this kind of journalism? Is there no way to influence or to convince those who are responsible for the media that what we need is a decent, proper, responsible way of journalism, not the kind that we are getting now. There is, I believe, an Australian Press Council under the chairmanship of Sir Frank Kitto. The Council has a lot of prestige but, unfortunately, no teeth. I believe newspapers are not obliged to do what the Council asks or recommends them to do. What has to be done to correct this sad state of affairs? Should we recommend something similar to that which is proposed by John Basten who is a senior lecturer in law at the University of New South Wales? He wrote in the Australian Quarterly, Summer 1980, issue under the heading 'Judicial accountability: a proposal for a Judicial Commission':

In this paper I propose the establishment of a Judicial Commission to bear responsibility for selecting judges, for providing training for them and for investigating complaints about them. The Commission should also have disciplinary powers to cope with misconduct and disabilities not warranting impeachment by parliament.

A few years ago such a suggestion would have been dis- missed in many circles. Nowadays, for better or worse, many of the old traditions surrounding the judiciary are disappearing. . . . These examples also indicate that the traditional belief that judges stand outside the political arena is increasingly being called into question. Much lip-service is paid to the concept of 'independence' of the judiciary and in particular the necessity of keeping judges independent of government and party-political pressures. Unfortunately little attention has traditionally been paid to the ambiguity of this concept. . . . A more open and realistic attitude towards the political nature of the judicial function calls for new mechanisms to protect the valuable aspects of independence.

To solve our problems would we have to substitute the judges and judiciary with journalists? If anybody can suggest seriously the establishment of a judicial commission which questions the integrity of our judges, what would be more proper and even more necessary would be a body to question the competence, responsibility, decency and integrity of those who are responsible for the formation of our public opinion, those who interpret for us the events from all parts of the world and those who have in their hands one of the most powerful weapons in today's society - the communications industry. I must admit that there are many responsible journalists and contributors to the newspapers who see the dangers of the facts as I mentioned them today. The Age published an article which is entitled 'Media spreads the vision of violence'. It reads:
Television makes us all, willy-nilly, voyeurs of public violence these days.

* * * * There is, however, one new element in all these situations: the vast contemporary international communications machine, which often seems to be actively crying out for new blood, as when foreign television crews in Belfast bribe local teenagers with money, or just with publicity, for 'action shots' to make vivid the evening television news in Amsterdam or Frankfurt.

Moreover, publicity is the chief end to which much violence (including the self-destroying violence of the hunger striker) is the strategy. In measure as the means of publicity (the media) have expanded, so has the rationale for violence.

* * * * Even quite sober 'investigative journalism', in print or television, unfortunately operates not only to magnify the visibility of violence, but to provide a sort of short course on how to do likewise, for those who feel they have reason to follow in the footsteps of earlier insurgents.
The article finally states:

One has sometimes the feeling that the 20th century has created, in the great international communications machine, a sort of Frankenstein's monster that will stalk and bring down many political personages, and assorted celebrities, and even Governments, before we learn to cope with it.
That should be a sobering thought, especially for those of us who work in the media.

I would like to congratulate that writer, Dr Bell. I only hope that an article like the one I have quoted will have an impact on his colleagues in the media. I would like to say that most probably if my speech is noted at all, which I doubt very much, there will be somebody somewhere who will talk about censorship and the freedom of the media; but the fact is that as far as we can see there is only one censorship and that is exercised totally and completely by the media itself. It is the media's decision what it prints, says or shows. It is its decision and nobody else's how it presents certain actions or happenings. It is its personal view which we have to believe or not to believe.

Again I emphasise that this is not a bashing the journalists exercise. It is a serious and honest plea to all those who are in a position to influence their colleagues in the media for the sake of a better society and, in particular, for the new generation to change its attitude to reporting. What we need today and tomorrow in the media from those who work in it is facts, not fiction, and even more importantly that the facts be presented with moderation and not exaggeration.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted
The speech read as follows-

This bill, together with its companion Bill, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1981-82, seeks interim appropriations for the services of the Government for the period 1 July 1981 to 30 November 1981, by which date it is expected that the Appropriation Bills (Nos 1 and 2), forming part of the Budget for 1981-82, will have been enacted. Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $4,363m for the ordinary annual services of the Government. This is $116m, or 3 per cent greater than the amounts provided in the Supply Act (No. 1) 1980-81. The provisions made in this Bill take account of the new health funding arrangements announced by the Government and of other decisions arising from the review of Commonwealth functions.

In particular, I mention that no provision is made in these Supply Bills for payments to the States for hospital cost sharing, the school dental scheme or the community health program. Interim funding of these programs will be sought in new States grants (income tax sharing) legislation to be introduced shortly, pending their absorption in general tax sharing grants. That legislation will also provide a standing appropriation for payments to South Australia and Tasmania under the existing hospital cost sharing agreements, pending advice from those States on whether they wish the agreements to continue or for the program to be absorbed in tax sharing grants. Except to the extent already indicated, the Supply Bills do not anticipate decisions yet to be taken in the 1981-82 Budget context. The Bill includes $100m for the advance to the Minister for Finance, which is the same amount as has been provided in Supply Act (No. 1) in each of the last several years. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, at 12 minutes past two I want to place on record again the boundless hypocrisy of the Liberal and Country parties, which have treated the Parliament in the last two weeks as if it were the parliament of a banana republic, which I suppose, given the fact that they are currently in government, is not in one sense too harsh a judgment to pass. The people who have made a mockery of the proceedings in the Senate this week and last week are the ones who talk outside this place, whenever it suits their perceived political advantages, of the Senate being a House of review. It is always amazing how efficiently this so-called House of review manages to review legislation in the last few days of a session. As an amendment to the motion that this Bill be now read a second time, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate notes with alarm the increasing commitment of the Government to monetarist policies, which policies have, wherever fully implemented, resulted in low economic growth, high unemployment, soaring interest rates, increased inequality and widespread poverty, and therefore calls on the Government to abandon these damaging and divisive policies.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—I will truncate the speech that I had intended to deliver. I will shortly be seeking leave to incorporate in Hansard four tables, which I now make available to the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to examine before I seek leave. Those tables reveal the dismal economic record of the Fraser Government compared with the situation in Australia on most economic indices prior to this Government gaining office and, even more importantly, the dismal economic record of the Fraser Government compared with the average for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, and in particular the countries of Austria, Japan, Germany, Norway and Sweden which I have selected. There is a reason for the selection of those countries which I will explain in a minute. Because of the difficulties in obtaining up to date data for all the countries, the tables terminate in 1979, but the picture revealed by those tables has not changed since.

SPEECH.PARA: That dismal economic record is no accident. It is on the record because the Government's economic policies, to the extent that they are thought through or are coherent at all, are built upon a multiplicity of fallacies which constitute a dogma that is credible only to those who are conditioned to filtering out so much of reality as is in conflict with that dogma. I will enumerate about ten of those fallacies. (Quorum formed). The first of the fallacies is this: The sole cause of inflation is money supply growth. When people who assert that refer to money supply, what they really mean is the money value, the money total, of all transactions. They ignore the fact that the number of transactions as well as their price are variable. Less money, as the Thatcher Government has convincingly, albeit tragically, demonstrated in the United Kingdom, does not necessarily mean lower prices. In that case and in many other cases it has been transformed into lower output and higher unemployment.

The second fallacy is that Budget deficits increase the money supply. Budget deficits funded by borrowings from the public have a neutral effect on the money supply. Those first two fallacies are supposed to be understood by any first year student of economics. The fact that they can be mouthed in public by the Secretary to the Treasury says a great deal about the contempt which the Secretary to the Treasury has for the Australian public. The third fallacy is that inflation is tied to Budget deficits and, in particular, that deficits caused inflation to rise in the early 1970s. In fact, up until September 1974 the Australian domestic budget was in surplus. By that time the quarterly inflation rate had reached 5.1 per cent, which incidentally was the highest for all of the 1970s and the highest since the days of the Menzies Government in 1951, which of course recorded the highest rate of inflation ever. In 1975, when the domestic deficit was very much larger, inflation fell by more than 3 per cent from the previous year's peak. In contrast, sharply falling deficits in the last two years have been accompanied by rising inflation, and there is a common cause for that. The common cause of both the rising inflation and the falling deficit is the enormous increase in the crude oil levy.

The fourth fallacy is that Australia's inflation in the 1970s was cause by the wages explosion of 1974. To believe that, it is necessary to believe in retrospective causation. The biggest increase in inflation was in 1973, before the so-called explosion. This explosion did of course help sustain inflation at high rates in the succeeding years. The fifth fallacy is that full wage indexation will perpetuate existing inflation rates. This was one of the most cherished Treasury myths mouthed ad infinitum in 1975 and 1976. On purely theoretical grounds that assertion ignores both the possibility of productivity increases and the possibility of changes in the relative shares of income to labour and capital. For those who are not impressed by such theoretical possibilities the empirical evidence shows that 100 per cent indexation was instituted in mid-1975 and lasted through to mid-1976. In the period from June 1975 to June 1976 the annual inflation rate fell by 3.7 per cent. I stress that this occurred throughout a period when 100 per cent wage indexation was prevailing.

Gross domestic product from the December quarter 1975 to the December quarter 1976 went up by 6.2 per cent which incidentally is the highest growth in GDP for any year since 1973. For the whole calendar year of 1976 the GDP growth of 4.2 per cent was also the highest since 1973, including 1980. These things were happening at a time when the Prime Minister and Treasury were ranting about 100 per cent wage indexation locking in the inflation rate and stultifying growth. One hundred per cent wage indexation was in fact accompanied by a 3.7 per cent fall in the inflation rate and the highest growth rate that has been recorded in any year since the Fraser Government has been in power. This was, incidentally, accompanied also by a large domestic deficit. All of those things, according to the dogma of the Treasury and the Government, could not happen. Treasury's inflationary expectation theory is not rescued by the fact that inflation was falling from mid-1975 to mid-1976. The Treasury might say that growth was high in that year because inflationary expectations were falling, and in fact inflation did fall in the end. But expectations are, by definition, expectations about the future. In fact throughout late 1975 and early 1976 Mr Fraser, both as Leader of the Opposition and as Prime Minister, and the Treasury were pontificating that wage indexation at 100 per cent as it prevailed would lock in forever the existing rate of inflation.

The sixth fallacy is that a large public sector stultifies growth and causes inflation-the so-called crowding-out effect. In the 1970s Norway, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands, West Germany and Austria all had larger public sectors than Australia but lower inflation and unemployment rates and higher rates of GDP growth. The seventh fallacy is that the 1974-75 and the 1975-76 deficits were irresponsibly large and economically disastrous. The Australian deficit in the calendar year 1975-and this can be verified in the tables-was 4.3 per cent of GDP which was the same as Japan's deficit in that same year and considerably lower than West Germany's which stood at 5.8 per cent of GDP in 1975. Economic growth in West Germany in 1976 was 5.2 per cent, which was high by historical standards. In Australia, as I have already mentioned, it was 4.2 per cent-that was taking the four quarters of 1976 over the four quarters of 1975-which is the highest rate of economic growth recorded in any year since the Fraser Government came to office. Japan also recorded an economic growth rate of 5.2 per cent in 1976 compared with a negative growth of one per cent in the preceding year. (Quorum formed). Both in Germany and in Japan these large deficits in 1975 were followed by high growth rates and falling inflation. Japan, incidentally, during the rest of the 1970s continued to run large deficits which were accompanied by falling inflation. The Minister has had a chance to look at my tables showing unemployment rates, real GDP growth, consumer price index figures and deficits in the countries named and also the OECD average. I seek leave to have those four tables incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of brief comments about those tables. Only in Australia has there been a significant increase in unemployment since 1975 and 1976. The averages for unemployment in Australia for 1974 to 1976, which were the years which were affected most by the economic policies of the Labor Government, show that unemployment rates were below the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. For the subsequent years up to the end of 1979 they are significantly above the OECD average. They are well above the rates for all of the other countries listed. Australia's GDP growth in 1974, 1975 and 1976 was well above the OECD average. For the succeeding years it has been well below the average of all but one of the other countries listed. Only in regard to the consumer price index, loosely called inflation, is Australia's performance better than the OECD average. Even at the end of 1975 Australia's inflation rate was above the OECD average and falling. By the end of 1979 it was slightly below the OECD average and rising. The only moderate and valid claim to success which the Fraser Government has is having achieved, relative to the past and relative to the rest of the OECD countries, a moderate reduction in the rate of inflation purchased at extrenely high cost, compared with those other countries and compared with the pre-1976 period, in terms of economic growth and unemployment rates. What should be noted about the countries which have, by Australia's standards, brilliant records in economic management, on inflation control, on GDP growth and on low rates of unemployment, countries such as Austria, Norway, West Germany and Japan-although in a slightly more paternalistic way-is that all those other countries have incomes policies which are effective

SPEECH.PARA: The eighth fallacy is that interest rates are determined by the size of the deficit. In other words, there is a positive and inexorable correlation between the size of the deficit and the interest rates. This year the deficit is the lowest since 1973. Interest rates went up another 2 per cent to the highest rates ever. In 1977-78 there was a big domestic deficit, almost $2.5 billion which was substantially higher than that in the preceding year, accompanying a fall in interest rates of around 2 per cent. The recent variant of the fallacy that deficits determine the level of interest rates is that the prevailing high interest rates have been caused by the voracious borrowing demands of the public sector, which is equally fallacious. In 1977-78 public sector borrowing requirements were 5.6 per cent of gross domestic product. They have fallen to 5.4 per cent and then to 3.6 per cent this year. The Public Service borrowing requirement as a proportion of gross domestic product has been falling ever since 1978-79, and throughout that period interest rates have risen. It would be foolish to argue the the size of the public sector borrowing requirement has no influence on interest rates, but it is only one of many factors affecting interest rates, frequently not the most important.

I turn to the ninth fallacy. A positive correlation exists between changes in inflation and the household savings ratio, therefore higher inflation equals lower household consumption and falling business investment. According to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasury, that too is an inexorable economic law. Australian evidence on this pont is mixed, but in 1979 and 1980 rising inflation was accompanied by a falling household savings ratio and rising business investments. The Government simultaneously boasts of that empirical result and ignores the fact that the result defies its own dogma-it contradicts its own dogma.

The tenth fallacy is that real wage overhang in 1974 and onwards caused unemployment because of the substitution of capital for labour. That fallacy ignored the fact that was deducible at that time even, namely that capital equipment prices were in fact rising faster than wages, although since the stupid investment allowance of 1976, the stupid 40 per cent investment allowance, that market reality was somewhat distorted by inept government interference. But apart from that which was empirically observable at the time, subsequent evidence also contradicted the dogma and showed it to be a fallacy. If labour had been displaced at above normal rates by capital equipment, productivity would have also increased at above normal rates. In fact, from 1974-75 to 1978-1979 productivity increased at an average rate of 2.9 per cent compared with the higher rate of 3.3 per cent in the previous seven years.

Fallacy number 11, the most important of all, is that incomes policies cannot controlinflation and will increase unemployment. That of course is contradicted by the evidence in the tables from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development as a whole, in particular from the OECD countries in which effective incomes policies are in operation and have been in operation throughout the 1970s. That incomes policies cannot control inflation is not the most obviously fallacious of those that I have cited, it is probably the most damaging. In Sweden, Norway and Japan, full employment is alive and well and has been throughout the seventies. All those countries have had lower inflation rates and, except for Japan, where the population is static, better rates of economic growth and larger public sectors. I should add that the Japanese incomes policy is not so much a deliberate policy of the Govenment as one that is associated with the general paternalistic economic policies of that country, as of course are Japan's social services.

All those countries have effective wages policies. Their record economic performance confounds and contradicts what in Australia is asserted to be ubiquitous economic verity. By any objective assessment it must be concluded that an effective wages policy is the key to economic success. Whether it would work in Australia may legitimatley be questioned. It certainly is unrealistic to expect an effective wages policy to be implemented in Australia under the present Government which has broken faith with almost every group in the nation except a group of tax dodgers, which apparently it feels obliged in isolation to maintain its promises to. The Government has imposed a number of taxes which have changed significantly the distribution of income in a regressive way and which generally have the distrust not only of the Labour movement but of a much wider section of the population. However, it seems highly unlikely that Australia can regain, under any Government, full employment with acceptable stability of prices and rates of economic growth without an effective wages policy. Above all, the management of the economy is much more complicated than the vulgar simplifications and misrepresentations of the Prime Minister.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Senate Estimates Committees-Sitting of the Senate-Minister for Industry and Commerce

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel like a batsman in 1946 after Barnes and Bradman put on 400 runs. I have been sitting here for a long time waiting to get an innings. I simply want to make a request to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick. He has been alerted to it. In 48 hours or less the Senate will adjourn for the winter recess. I would like to receive some clear cut statement on the Government's attitude to the future operation of Senate committees after the Senate resumes in August. I know that two ideas have been touted. One concerned whether the work of Estimates committees would be ongoing and the other was whether their functions would be taken on board by legislative and standing committees. One-fifth or thereabouts of the members of the Senate will be leaving us. We know that they would be rated as very excellent parliamentary artifices. There is no question about that. I think that when the Government and the Opposition are assessing their replacement members on Senate committees the matter will need a certain amount of advance planning. I have a personal interest in this. As Senator Carrick knows, I have had a request on the Notice Paper for a Senate select committee on immigration to be established. I have had informal talks with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) who has said to me: 'You get a pretty fair opportunity when Estimates committees meet twice a year'. The Government Whip in the Senate, who is Chairman of Estimates Committee D, was reported by Laurie Oakes as saying that he believes the work of Senate Estimates Committees ought to be ongoing. So do I. A lot of things happen in between the times and Estimates committee meets twice a year. As I am mindful of the time, I simply say-I think that Senator Carrick will agree with me-that we should be informed by tomorrow night as to the Government's intentions in regard to Estimates committees. I ask whether they will be ongoing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two matters. Firstly, I point out that whoever scheduled these meetings of the Senate to end at quarter to three or later must be crazy and needs his head read. Most of us have been here since 8.30 yesterday morning. To go through until 2.45 a.m. is absolutely ridiculous. People who represent the States in this place cannot possibly legislate in a proper manner when the Senate sits for so long. I would just like to make my protest because I am sure there will be a few more protests before we finish.

I do not think Senator Carrick realised, when I asked that question, that I asked it in what I thought was a quite proper manner. I thought I asked it in a responsible manner, having heard stories about the matter from professional employment officers. Senator Carrick, in answer to a supplementary question, said that he would check the information for me. I ask Senator Carrick at this stage whether he has any information on that question that I asked last Wednesday. If he has not, could he get the information before the Senate rises or perhaps even before Senator Carrick leaves, as I believe he is leaving before the Senate rises for the winter recess?

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tax Assessable Income: Verification of Returns

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does section 26(e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act require that the tax assessable income of a taxpayer shall include the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, gratuities, compensations, benefits, bonuses and premiums allowed, given or granted in money, goods, land, meals, sustenance, the use of premises or quarters or otherwise.
(2) To what extent do taxpayers comply with the requirements of this section in their income tax returns.
(3) To what extent does the Commissioner of Taxation seek to verify the returns in this regard, and to what extent is he able to carry out verification processes.
(4) What is the estimate of additional income tax revenue if there was a full and strict compliance with and enforcement of s. 26(e).
(5) Are there any categories of fringe benefits which, on a cost-benefit analysis basis, it would not be worth bringing within the reach of a full and strict enforcement of s. 26(e).

(6) Can the Treasurer provide information on the facilities of the Commissioner of Taxation to enforce section 26(e), or can he advise when the Commissioner will be provided with the necessary facilities for such an enforcement.
(7) If the process of enforcement is inhibited by weaknesses or lack of clarity in the law, does the Government intend to amend the law appropriately.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Insufficient information is available to answer this question.
(3) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that action is taken to verify returns in this respect as far as is reasonably practicable having regard to the many exigencies of tax administration.
(4) This information is not available.

(5) The Commissioner of Taxation has pointed out that it must always be a matter of administrative judgment how enforcement resources can be used most effectively from time to time, but that the fact that a category of assessable income may generally accrue to individual taxpayers in relatively small amounts does not necessarily mean that enforcement procedures in respect of it would not be cost-effective, particularly as a means of encouraging wider general compliance with the law.

(6) The provision of facilities for the enforcement of section 26 (e), or any other provision, is a matter for decision by the Commissioner of Taxation, having regard to his other responsibilities in the administration of the taxation laws.

(7) This aspect of income tax law, in Australia and elsewhere, involves special difficulties which are not caused by deficient or unclear legislation but by the need to convert a large variety of benefits in kind given to taxpayers into appropriate money values in their hands. The Government has looked at this part of the law from time to time but has not concluded that a different approach is warranted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Department of Social Security responsible for appointing doctors to Social Security Appeals Tribunals.
(2) Is this always done on recommendation from the Department of Health; if not, what is the procedure for appointing the doctors.
(3) Is there any policy on using former Commonealth Medical Officers who may have proviously rejected an appellant's claim.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Minister for Social Security appoints doctors to the Social Security Appeals Tribunals.

(2) No. There is no set procedure for appointing doctors to the Tribunals. Appointments to date have been made following the receipt of nominations from the Director-General of Health and the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

(3) The policy in relation to the appointment of any medical practitioner to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal is to consider each such appointment on an individual basis. Regard is had in each case to the qualifications, the length and nature of experience and the relevance of full or part-time appointments. Because of the wide diversity of duties which may have been performed by any particular former Commonwealth Medical Officer, it is considered that that factor alone should neither preclude, nor be a necessary precondition for, appointment to the Tribunal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Where an injury to an employee results in the employee being totally incapacitated for work, the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 provides that, for the first twenty-six weeks of incapacity, compensation is payable at a rate equivalent to full-pay sick leave entitlement. After that period the weekly rate of compensation payable is $105 in respect of the injured employee. An additional allowance of $27.50 p.w. is payable in respect of a prescribed person (normally a spouse) wholly or mainly dependent upon the employee. For each child wholly or mainly dependent a further $13.10 per week is payable.

The adult minimum wage (Six State Capital Cities) at 9 January 1981 was calculated to be $139.90. The maximum weekly compensation payable for a single employee represents 75.1 per cent of that figure. For an employee with a dependent spouse the maximum weekly compensation payable represents 94.7 per cent of that figure. For an employee with a dependent spouse and one child the maximum weekly compensation payable represents 104.1 per cent of that figure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any way and, if so, in what ways was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action will any information which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that information, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee.
(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having the services of the Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee available to the Government and the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The functions of the Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee are set out in its Terms of Reference:
'Within the responsibilities of the Commonwealth Government to advise the Minister for Social Security on:
(i) issues relating to the special welfare needs of women arising from the structure and delivery of Commonwealth social security and welfare programs; and
(ii) any matters which the Minister refers to the Committee.'

(3)-(7), (9) I am most grateful to WWICC for the very competent way in which it has carried out its duties. However, by incorporating the Committee's functions with those of the National Consultative Council on Social Welfare there will be a closer integration of advice on women's welfare issues. There will be no reduction in availability of information or advice on these matters, as I propose to establish a Standing Committee on Women's Issues within the National Consultative Council on Social Welfare. These arrangements will more effectively utilise existing mechanisms and at the same time ensure that women's issues are effectively taken into account in the policy-making process.
(8) The estimated saving in abolishing the Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee is $39,000 in 1981-82.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March 1981 (Hansard, page 319), Senator Elstob asked the Minister for National Development and Energy the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Recently the Farmers and Stockowners Association of South Australia expressed a real concern over the purchase of rural land by foreign investors. The members believe that a situation may develop whereby it will be impossible for young Australian nationals to become established on land in their own right. Will the Minister consider introducing legislation similar to that of New Zealand where it is stipulated that foreigners must live in the country for at least two years before purchasing rural land, or to the legislation of the United States where foreigners are prevented from owning more than 0.405 hectares of land.
Senator Carrick undertook to refer the question to the Treasurer, who has provided the following answer:
Proposals for foreign interests to acquire Australian rural land are subject to examination under the Foreign Takeovers Act and other foreign investment policy criteria.

Rural land is treated with special attention in the Government's policy on foreign investment and the Government is concerned to ensure that foreign interests should not engage in specultative land acquisitions of the kind intended purely for capital gain without accompanying benefits to Australia. Approval for the sale of rural land to a foreign investor would normally only be given after careful consideration of the proposal by the Foreign Investment Review Board and where the Government is satisfied that the sale would offer net benefits to the Australian economy and that Australians had been given adequate opportunity to buy the land.

From information available to the Foreign Investment Review Board, it would appear, contrary to the views of concern expressed by the Farmers and Stockowners Association, that there has been little interest shown by foreigners in purchasing rural land in South Australia. I am forwarding to the honourable senator a paper on foreign investment in rural land which outlines in some detail the Government's policy and provides detailed statistics.
The honourable senator's understanding of policies in New Zealand and the United States of America differs from the information available to the Government which is as follows:
New Zealand-

Under the Land Settlement Promotion and Land Acquisition Act 1952, as amended, foreign interests are restricted from acquiring rural land, offshore islands and any land required for public use. The legislation aims to restrict absentee foreign ownership of certain types of land in New Zealand.

For the purposes of the Act a person ordinarily resident in New Zealand is required to have resided there for not less than 2 1/2 years of a 3 year period immediately preceding the purchase of the land, and that person must intend to continue to reside there permanently.

Restriction of foreign ownership applies to any land of two hectares (five acres) or over an area which is zoned for rural purposes, or is so zoned that farming of any kind is a predominant or conditional use in that zone.
However, acquisition of land by a foreign interest may be permitted if:
the acquisition is for experimental and research purposes which would benefit New Zealand; or
intended uses of the land, other than for agriculture, clearly show significant benefits to New Zealand and thus are in the national interest; or
an individual alien permanently resident in New Zealand farms the land exclusively for his own use and benefit and has the ability and means to achieve these purposes.

If land is part of the assets of a business, and where the consideration involved exceeds $NZ100,000, a non-resident has to notify full details to the Overseas Investment Commission of any proposal that would lead to the non-resident interests controlling 25 per cent or more of the voting rights of the business. Each proposal is considered by the Commission on its merits.
The United States-

Under the Agricultural Foreign Investment Disclosure Act 1978, all foreign interests who own or acquire United States agricultural land are required to report their holdings with the United States Department of Agriculture. This legislation is not intended to restrict or regulate land purchases or sales by foreign interests. It is aimed primarily at strengthening the efforts to monitor foreign investment in United States agricultural land.

The American States generally have no restrictions on ownership of land by resident aliens. However, nine States have laws that generally prohibit or restrict in a major way, non-resident aliens from owning real estate. Some of these States also have restrictions on ownership of land by resident aliens. An additional four States have laws that limit the total acreage that aliens can acquire or hold and the limites range from 5 acres to 500,000 acres. Six States, five of which are included in the nine States mentioned above, have laws that permit aliens to hold land for a limited duration or require aliens to dispose of all or part of their holdings within specified time periods if they do not become United States citizens or residents of the State.

The policies of these countries are of course related to their particular circumstances just as the Australian policy which I have briefly explained above is aimed at meeting Australia's needs. This Government's policy and the way in which it is administered provide a reasonable basis for exercising supervision and, where necessary, restraint of excessive foreign investment in Australian land.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1387), Senator MacGibbon asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware of concern, particularly in Queensland, at the growing level of foreign ownership of real estate and property in both urban and rural areas? Recognising that the Commonwealth has no constitutional responsibility in this field, will the Government consider recommending to the State and Territory governments that a register be maintained listing all beneficial owners of property-not nominees-together with their residency and nationality status?
Senator Carrick undertook to bring the question to the attention of the Treasurer, who has provided the following answer:

Yes, I am aware that some organisations have expressed concern about foreign ownership of Australian rural and urban real estate. The Government respects such views and through its policy on foreign investment looks very closely at proposed acquisitions of real estate by foreign interests. Before any approval is given, other than in cases where the purchasers are Australian citizens resident abroad or genuinely intending immigrants, the parties must demonstrate that there will be benefits through development of the real estate or otherwise to Australia from the investment and, in the case of rural land, that Australians have been given adequate prior opportunity to purchase the land if they wished to do so.

I have noted the honourable senator's question concerning the maintenance by the State and Territory governments of registers of property ownership. The practice of the Foreign Investment Review Board is to consult the appropriate State and Territory government authorities in the examination of important cases and on certain other foreign investment matters. I have asked the Board to consult these authorities on the proposal which the honourable senator has raised.
