QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government review the plight of disabled persons in isolated areas during the Year of the Disabled Person.
(2) Are there many persons who are resigned to wheelchairs, particularly in Aboriginal communities, and has it been proven that the ordinary wheelchair is not suitable for outback conditions.
(3) Will the Government give consideration to possible alternative wheelchair designs which would be suitable for outback conditions and able to traverse sand and dirt paths with relative ease.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is concerned about disabled people in remote areas and initiatives have been taken to help them. For example, the Isolated Patients' Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme (IPTAAS), administered by my colleague the Minister for Health, provides financial help to persons residing in isolated areas who are referred by a medical practitioner for specialist treatment and who need to travel more than 200 kilometres from their home to obtain such treatment. In addition, the IYDP National Committee of Non-Government Organisations, which is responsible for promoting the aims of IYDP through the voluntary sector, has as its Northern Territory representative a disabled person from Alice Springs who speaks for disabled people in remote areas on that Committee.

The needs of disabled Aboriginals in remote areas are also being investigated by the Government. My colleague, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, has set aside funds to employ Mr Kevin Coombs to co-ordinate the involvement of Aboriginals in the IYDP throughout Australia. Mr Coombs is also a member of the IYDP National Committee and in that capacity is personally visiting remote Aboriginal communities in each State and Territory to gain first hand information on the problems faced by the disabled. The matter is being further investigated by individual committees advising my State Ministerial colleagues and by representatives of my Department and the Departments of Aboriginal Affairs and Health who are liaising with Mr Coombs. The National Advisory Committee on the Handicapped and the Standing Inter-Departmental Committee on Rehabilitation are also considering the special needs of handicapped Aboriginals at the request of my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

Finally, on 19 August 1980, the Minister for Health announced details of a new Commonwealth program under which a range of aids to daily living, such as wheelchairs, walking aids, splints, calipers, braces and personal aids, are to be provided to disabled people not eligible for assistance under existing assistance programs. Assistance under this new Program of Aids for Disabled People, which is expected to commence in the near future, will be available to disabled people throughout Australia, including disabled people residing in isolated areas. The new program is a Commonwealth initiative for the International Year of Disabled Persons.

(2) In am not aware of any figures showing the number of persons in isolated areas who require wheelchairs, nor has the Government specifically investigated the suitability of ordinary wheelchairs in outback conditions.

(3) My colleague, the Minister for Science and Technology, has indicated that his Department is currently looking at providing financial assistance for the development of a wheelchair invention which could be used over the terrain mentioned by the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What staffing instructions and circulars have been issued by the Commonwealth Savings Bank regarding their standard home loan building contract (CSBH35) in Victoria, in addition to Instruction B.I. 17/29.
(2) Will the Treasurer make available all instructions, including B.I. 17/29.

(3) On how many occasions since 1974 has the Commonwealth Savings Bank in Victoria approved the use by their home loan clients of the standard home building contracts issued by the Housing Industry Association and the Master Builders Association.
(4) What is the procedure for such approval.
(5) Is the arbitration clause in building contract CSBH35 currently being reviewed in its application in Victoria.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Following normal banking practices, the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia's operating instructions are private and confidential to the Bank's officers and it would not be appropriate to make them public.
Subject to that qualification, the managing director of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation has provided the following information:
(1) and (2) In summary, with regard to building loans made by the Commonwealth Savings Bank, the Bank's Branch Instructions-
(a) require that the borrower must enter a satisfactory contract with the builder;
(b) state that the contract plans and specifications will be examined by the Bank to ensure the Bank's requirements are met;
(c) make provision for acceptance of a contract other than in the Bank's form, provided that certain basic aspects as follows are covered:
(i) a reasonable completion time
(iii) identification of plans and specifications
(iii) a minimum standard of construction
(iv) access by the Bank's officers for inspection purposes
(v) acceptable progress payment provisions
(vi) satisfactory workers' compensation and public risk insurances
(vii) a known contract price.
The Bank is not a party to a building contract either on its own form or any other form of contract. The parties involved are the owner and the builder.
(3) The Bank does not maintain statistics regarding the various home building contracts used by its housing borrowers and consequently is not in a position to provide the details sought.

(4) Provided the Bank's requirements as set out in the answer to Part (2) are met, acceptance of a building contract is made at branch level. Provision exists in instructions for referral of contracts containing special clauses to higher authority. These are examined on their merits. The Bank's preference for its own form of contract (CSBH 35) stems from the knowledge that the contract clauses are fully acceptable without the need for special examination but, as indicated in (2), its use is not compulsory.

(5) The Bank's legal advisers are of the opinion that there is no inconsistency between the provisions of the Bank's building contract and the relevant Victorian legislation. In these circumstances, the arbitration clause in the Bank's building contract as it applies in Victoria is not currently under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Communications been drawn to a program on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television on 31 March featuring Mr Harry Butler.

(2) Did that program deal in glowing terms with the way in which Woodside Petroleum Pty Ltd was caring for the environment on the Burrup Peninsula in Western Australia, which is to be the site of a natural gas depot related to the North West Shelf Project.
(3) Is Mr Butler a consultant paid by Woodside Petroleum.
(4) Did Mr Butler in an earlier programme on the ABC praise the environmental work of West Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd.
(5) Was Mr Butler retained by West Australian Petroleum as an environmental consultant.
(6) Will the Minister take up with the ABC the apparent conflict of interest involved in Mr Butler promoting the work of companies by whom he is retained.

(7) Was ABC management aware of Mr Butler's connection with these companies; if so, why did they allow the programs to proceed without seeking balancing material from other environmental authorities; and if they did not know, why did they not know.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The program dealt in factual terms with the way in which Woodside Petroleum Pty Ltd was caring for the environment on the Burrup Peninsula.
(3) The ABC knew that, at the time, Mr Butler was a consultant to Woodside Petroleum Pty Ltd.
(4) He discussed his own work as performed when working as an environmental consultant.
(5) Yes.
(6) The matter has been referred to the ABC. Mr Butler who is a well known and highly respected ABC personality reported factually on the work being done on the Burrup Peninsula.
(7) Yes. Alternative opinions to those expressed by Mr Butler are frequently given in other ABC programs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated cost in the year 1980-81 of raising the permissable earnings of all
(a) pensioners and supporting parents;
(b) sickness, unemployment and special beneficiaries; and
(c) recipients of sheltered employment allowance to
(i) $30 a week; and
(ii) $40 a week.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) The estimated cost in 1980-81 of increasing the permissable income to $30 a week is
(a) $90m for pensioners and supporting parents;
(b) $5.2m for unemployment, sickness and special beneficiaries; and
(c) $0.4m for recipients of sheltered employment allowance;
(ii) The estimated cost in 1980-81 of increasing the permissable income to $40 a week is
(a) $150m for pensioners and supporting parents;
(b) $6.5m for unemployment, sickness and special beneficiaries; and
(c) $0.6m for recipients of sheltered employment allowance.

These costs are based on the number of pensioners, supporting parents and recipients of sheltered employment allowance current at 19 December 1980, and estimated average unemployment, sickness and special beneficiaries in 1980-81.
The costs for pensioners include a rough estimate of the likely additional cost in respect of those pensioners who would become newly eligible as a result of the increase in the income limits.

The estimated cost for beneficiaries is based on the present distribution of continuing income of existing beneficiaries. It takes no account of the impact of the proposals on casual earnings or labour force patterns. Adoption of these proposals would have the additional effect of making eligible for a part-rate benefit some persons currently excluded by the income test. Not enough information is available to estimate the cost in respect of these new beneficiaries but the additional expenditure might well be substantial.
The estimates are gross costs in that they make no allowance for the additional revenue that would be gained through taxation of the payments concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did leaching from the ore stockpiles during the recent wet season at the Minatome uranium mine at Ben Lomond near Townsville cause an unusually high radiation reading in the waters of Keelbottom Creek.
(2) What were the details of the readings and what action has been taken to rectify the situation.
(3) Is the company exploiting the uranium ore body planning to establish an ore treatment plant in the Yabula area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3). Minatome Australia Ltd is undertaking work to determine the economic significance of uranium and molybdenum mineralisation on a mineral lease granted by the Queensland Government at Ben Lomond near Townsville.
No Commonwealth decisions are involved in mineral exploration at Ben Lomond and the Commonwealth is not involved in the control or monitoring of the exploration.

Minatome has applied for Commonwealth approvals for the development and export of uranium from the Ben Lomond deposits and a Commonwealth environmental impact statement has been directed in relation to these decisions. The impact statement, which is expected to be released for public review in the first quarter of 1982, will cover Minatome's proposals for mining and milling of uranium ore from the Ben Lomond deposits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treaurer, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions are the following Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) collections to be discontinued: (a) survey of consultancy services provided overseas; (b) price indexes of copper materials used in the manufacture of electrical equipment; (c) co-operatives; (d) unit trusts, land trusts and mutual fund rates levied (New South Wales); (e) municipal and shire elections (New South Wales); (f) water authorities (Victoria); (g) eggs set and chickens hatched; (h) tea and coffee; (i) poultry slaughterings; (j) pig survey; (k) transfers and conveyances and mortgages of real estate; (l) mortgages of real estate (Victoria); (m) real estate transactions (New South Wales); (n) land for housing (New South Wales); (o) sales of land and houses (New South Wales); (p) production of minerals and mineral products; (q) boat statistics; (r) forestry; (s) hunting and trapping; (t) boat registration; (u) rock lobsters in cold stores (Western Australia); (v) newsprint usage survey; (w) selected services industries collection; (x) Australian library services; (y) fire statistics (Western Australia and New South Wales); (z) workers compensation (Victoria); and (aa) birth expectations survey.
(2) When were each of the collections introduced.
(3) For what reasons were they introduced.
(4) Are those reasons no longer considered to disclose a continuing need for the statistics to be collected, or have circumstances changed.
(5) What groups in the community, of which the government is aware, had an interest in the information collected in each of the collections to be discontinued.
(6) What assurances can the Treasurer give that those groups will not be disadvantaged by the lack of information.

(7) Can the Treasurer assure the Parliament with respect to each of the discontinued collections that no information will be unavailable to groups in the community, particularly businesses, which could have been used to make more informed more efficient decisions; if not, is it possible that there may be some long-term cost involved in these decisions.
(8) Has any projected estimate been made of that cost.
(9) What does it cost at present to collect and process each particular collection mentioned in (1).

(10) What assurances can the Treasurer give that the cost saved in discontinuing each collection will outweigh the long term cost to the private sector and the economy in general entailed in not having access to the information collected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (10) The collections referred to are considered to be of low priority and are being discontinued in order to reduce the costs incurred by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and by those who supply the information to the Bureau.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to be sold to the private sector.
(2) What money is expected to be raised by this decision.
(3) Will the government receive any advice as to when to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation so as to achieve the best price.
(4) Will sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation be delayed if it appears that the Commonwealth is not in a position to receive the best price, as is consistent with sound business practice.
(5) What investigations have been made concerning the prices which consumers will pay for the services of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation as a result of its sale.
(6) Can the Minister assure the Parliament that prices will not rise, with consequent adverse affects on inflation as a result of the sales of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.
(7) What assurances can be the Minister give that services to the public will not deteriorate as a result of the sale.
(8) Will the proposed sale increase the efficiency of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) It is not possible at this stage to indicate likely sale price. This will be finally determined as part of the sale process.
(3) The Government will receive advice on details of the sale from an interdepartmental committee, which will draw on such assistance and advice as considered appropriate from time to time.

(4) The interdepartmental committee will make recommendations to the Government on the terms and conditions of the sale, including timing of the sale, whether any tender should be accepted or not, and, if necessary, what further action should be taken.

(5) Mortgage insurance premiums are a one-off payment representing on average 0.75 per cent of a typical loan amount. Premium levels depend on a number of factors including claims experience, administrative costs and general competition in the industry.

(6) The Government has indicated its intention to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation as a going concern to a purchaser with the necessary strong financial backing. This will encourage the continuation of a highly competitive mortgage insurance industry and it is expected that premium levels will continue to reflect this level of competition.
(7) The sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation will be subject to the understanding that the purchaser maintains the level of services presently provided.

(8) The Corporation is recognised as an efficient and innovative insurer. Its sale as a going concern and continued operation as part of a highly competitive industry should allow for its continued efficient operation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Experimental Building Station to be sold to the private sector.
(2) What money is expected to be raised by this decision.
(3) Will the government receive any advice as to when to sell the Experimental Building Station so as to achieve the best price.
(4) Will sale of the Experimental Building Station be delayed if it appears that the Commonwealth is not in a position to receive the best price, as is consistent with sound business practice.
(5) Can the Minister assure the Parliament that prices will not rise, with consequent adverse affects on inflation as a result of the sale of the Experimental Building Station.
(6) What assurances can the Minister give that services will not deteriorate as a result of the sale.
(7) Will the proposed sale increase the efficiency of the Experimental Building Station.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's decision is to dispose of the Experimental Building Station, and to examine an increased role for CSIRO, AMDL and the private sector in the provision of EBS services. There are a number of options available involving various financial arrangements apart from the direct sale of EBS.
(2) It is not possible at this stage to make a financial assessment.

(3) and (4) No specific date has yet been established for the disposal of EBS. If EBS is to be sold, the government will receive advice on the details of sale from an interdepartmental committee chaired by the Department of Housing and Construction.

(5) Existing charges by EBS to provide a service are based on the direct cost plus overheads. If EBS is sold and operated commercially, it is expected that charging for testing services will be based on normal commercial practice.

(6) and (7) In examining the options available for the disposal of EBS, the government will be considering how EBS services can best be provided to government, building standards and similar organisations, and the building industry generally. The quality of services to be provided will be an important factor in these considerations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Mugga quarry and Hotmix complex (Australian Capital Territory) to be sold to the private sector.
(2) What money is expected to be raised by this decision.
(3) Will the government receive any advice as to when to sell the Mugga quarry and Hotmix complex so as to achieve the best price.
(4) Will sale of the Mugga quarry and Hotmix complex be delayed if it appears that the Commonwealth is not in a position to receive the best price, as is consistent with sound business practice.
(5) What investigations have been made concerning the prices which consumers will pay for the services of the Mugga quarry and Hotmix complex as a result of its sale.
(6) Can the Minister assure the Parliament that prices will not rise, with consequent adverse affects on inflation as a result of the sale of the Mugga quarry and Hotmix complex.
(7) What assurances can the Minister give that services to the public will not deteriorate as a result of the sale.
(8) Will the proposed sale increase the efficiency of the Mugga quarry and complex.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) It is not possible at this stage to indicate a likely sale price. This will be finally determined as part of the sale process.
(3) The Government will receive advice on the details of sale from an interdepartmental committee chaired by the Department of Housing and Construction.
(4) Any decision on the timing of the sale will be made after the Government receives advice on the details of sale from the interdepartmental committee.

(5) Investigations have been made but no firm conclusions can be reached because prices will be affected by the conditions of sale which are yet to be determined and the market conditions at the time.
(6) No assurances can be given that prices will not rise.
(7) It is expected that the private sector will provide a similar standard of service to that presently experienced.
(8) The Mugga quarry and hotmix plant complex has been operated on a commercial basis and it is expected that the private sector will maintain a similar level of efficiency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister seen reports in the Australian on 30 March 1981 that existing demand for geoscientists cannot be met.
(2) Is the situation expected to improve or deteriorate in the next three years.
(3) Would the situation be as bad as it is if the Government had contributed more fully to the encouragement of training of geoscientists; if not, why not.
(4) Is there a severe shortage of geoscientists at present; if so, when did the Government become aware of the problem.
(5) How closely has the Government been monitoring the manpower requirements of the resources boom.
(6) What steps are being taken now, and will be taken in the future to alleviate this problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) I have seen the article referred to and I am aware of the strong demand for geoscientists, not only in Australia, but also in most countries in the western world. This demand has, of course, resulted from the tremendous upsurge in exploration activity in the petroleum and mineral industries over the last few years. The Government has regular contact with industry in regard to such matters and as a result of discussions earlier this year representatives of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd (APEA) met with the Minister for Education recently to discuss the industry assessment of the situation. I understand the Minister has suggested to APEA that the matters raised be further discussed with the Tertiary Education Commission and the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee.

(5) and (6) I draw the honourable senator's attention to a statement on this subject by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs in the House of Representatives on 4 December 1980 (Hansard pages 446-449); and to the further details provided to him in my letter of 25 March 1981.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Council for Rural Research and Extension

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension in its annual report for 1979-80 say that: 'In principle, public resources should be devoted to research and extension to a level where the expected benefit of the last project funded is equal to the opportunity cost, that is the return if used in alternative investment'. If so, does the Government accept that principle.
(2) What machinery has the government had in the past and what machinery does it have at present to ensure that its expenditure in rural research is optimal in terms of the formula expressed above.

(3) Did the Government decide to abolish the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension because it believed that more than an optimal level of federal expenditure was devoted to rural research, and on what evidence did it base this view.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, however, the Government allocates its limited financial resources amongst competing needs to the best overall advantage of the nation.
(2) Responsibility for recommending rural research will rest as it has in the past, with the various organisations involved.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Consultative Council on Social Welfare

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the second annual report of the National Consultative Council on Social Welfare presented to the Government.
(2) When will it be tabled in Parliament and what is the reason for the delay.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The second annual report of the National Consultative Council on Social Welfare has not yet been formally presented to the Government. However, I assure the honourable senator that I will table the report in Parliament as soon as it is available in the appropriate format.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1033) Senator Townley asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface it by saying that I am one of those who believe this country should follow such energetic countries as Hong Hong and Switzerland and establish a tax rate that is constant no matter what income a person works toward because I believe the present tax rates do remove incentive. Is the Minister able to say how much money would be lost to the Treasury if the maximum tax rate were reduced from the present 60c in the dollar to 50c in the dollar, something that would be at least a step in the direction of an even tax rate? If the Minister is not able to let me know the exact amount at this stage from his notes, I would be grateful if, when he can, he would also advise the percentage loss to revenue of such reduction. Finally, will be Minister advise the Treasurer that many senators and members do believe that a flat tax rate is possible and that the proposition should be examined again in discussions leading up to the Budget?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Based on a projected income distribution of taxable individuals for 1980-81, the loss to income tax revenue for the 1980-81 income year from reducing the maximum marginal rate of tax from 60 cents in the dollar to 50 cents in the dollar is estimated at about $125m. This represents about 0.8 per cent of estimated net income tax payable by individuals in respect of the 1980-81 income year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the fall in the value of the West German mark mean a drop of $5m this year in the amount earned by Australian fox hunters, as reported in the issue of National Farmer dated 14 May 1981.
(2) Is the wild fox population a potential carrier of rabies and is control of foxes important in controlling any possible outbreak of this disease in Australia.
(3) Have there been, on average, up to four rabies scares in Australia each year recently.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Figures for fox skin exports to West Germany are:
Number Value
About 80 per cent of fox skins exported are obtained in Victoria.
During the same period, one Australian dollar has been worth, in West German marks:

There does not appear to be a direct relationship between the value of the West German mark and the number and value of fox skins exported to that market. The decline could be related also to lower availability and quality of fox skins due, for instance, to drought conditions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Natural Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 29 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, a list of priorities which are headed by: (a) Conservation of liquid fuels; (b) Technology of discovery; (c) Liquid fuels alternatives; and (d) Substitution of other fuels.
(2) Are these the Government's priorities.

(3) Has only $5.6m been devoted to research in the highest priority area out of a total government expenditure on Energy Research and Development of $60m in the last 3 years; if so, why is there this imbalance between the Government's stated priorities and its actions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, the priorities are abbreviated in the question and the published document, 'Priorities for R, D&D Support Grants', should be referred to for a complete description.

(2) I approved the release of the above document setting out the priorities for the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration (NERD&D) Program as a guide for applicants and for the Council in developing its recommendations to me.

(3) Grants totalling $5.6m have been made to projects listed under the heading of conservation in the NERD&D Program over the last three years. $3.3m of this amount was committed in 1980-81 and reflects the increasing research effort in the area. In inviting applications for grants in 1981-82 the Council has indicated that energy conservation will be given further emphasis next year. Notwithstanding the above it should be realised that priority is not synonymous with size of program. The following extract is taken from the document referred to earlier:
'Higher priority areas will have the first claim on resources but the level of NERD&D Program support for a program will depnd on:
nature of the technology
whether the technology is at the R, D or D stage
existing level of activity both in Australia and overseas
level of activity considered appropriate for Australia, ranging from maintaining a watching brief to take a major role in a particular energy technology
the perceived need for government support.'

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981, (Hansard, page 1042) Senator Davidson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the Minister's attention to the Auditor-General's most recent report and its reference to the Special Broadcasting Service. Is the Minister aware that the report draws attention to expenditure in excess of that approved and also to expenditure incurred by people without authority to do so? Are those expenditures related directly to the operation of Channel 0/28? If so, can the Minister indicate the Government's intention in relation to multilingual and multicultural broadcasting and television? Will the Government increase the budget for the Special Broadcasting Service to meet those situtations?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Excess monies were expended against a limited number of items (travel, radio programs production, maintenance of broadcasting facilities, furniture and fittings). A total amount of approximately $396,000 was involved, but this was not in excess of the SBS allocation for 1979-80.
The SBS delegates, by Instrument, power of expenditure to particular positions on the SBS establishment rather than to individuals.
The SBS has taken steps to ensure that where temporary employees occupy positions to which the SBS delegates powers of expenditure they do not now exercise these financial delegations.
The expenditures in question were not directly related to the operations of Channel 0/28.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1646) Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. The question concerned the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits (DFRB) Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has supplied the following information:

Although you mentioned the Jess Committee's 1972 Report and recommendations I am not sure specifically what you have in mind in referring to anomalies which have disadvantaged some 7000 ex-servicemen and between thirty and forty widows. I suspect, however, that it is in some way related to the fact that the levels of pensions of DFRB pensioners are generally lower than those granted to their counterparts under the DFRDB scheme which succeeded the DFRB scheme with effect from 1 October 1972.
Perhaps some background to the events emanating from the recommendations of the Jess Committee would be helpful. First the Committee recommended:
'That all contributors to the DFRB Fund be transferred to the Proposed DFRB scheme (ie the DFRDB scheme). The conditions of the scheme should then apply to them.'
and second:

'That pensions and benefits payable under the DFRB legislation at the time the Proposed DFRB Scheme is introduced remain in force and, thereafter, be adjusted in the same manner as benefits payable to recipient members of the Proposed DFRB Scheme.'
Thus it should be clear that there was never any intention that DFRB pensions should be recalculated by applying to them the terms and conditions of the succeeding DFRDB scheme.

DFRB pensioners were in fact granted a pension increase in 1973 under legislation introduced and passed at the same time as the Parliament dealt with the legislation establishing the new DFRDB scheme; and further pension increases have been granted on an annual basis since then to both DFRB and DFRDB pensioners.
I can confirm that DFRB pensions have more than doubled since 1972 and I am informed that the further increases to be granted in July next will be of the order of 9.4 per cent.

It is true of course the DFRB pensions are generally lower than DFRDB pensions. However, there is nothing new about differences of this kind. They existed in levels of DFRB pensions granted at different points in time during the life of that scheme; and for the same reasons they are occurring within the DFRDB scheme.

In other words, the differences are attributable more to tying pension levels to final salary, rather than to changes in the methods used for calculating pension amounts. As salaries continue to rise, so will pensions payable on retirement.

Pension increases in Government sponsored occupational superannuation schemes generally are designed primarily to maintain the real value of retirement pensions. This aim has been more than satisfactorily achieved so far as DFRB pensioners are concerned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 May 1981 (Hansard page 1726) Senator Robertson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned the migration and settlement of East Timorese.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

People from East Timor being resettled in Australia are not refugees and are not considered so by the Australian Government. The United Nations Convention definition of a refugee which is used as a guideline in Government decisions on designation requires that a refugee must be outside his/her country and unable or unwilling to return for fear of persecution. Timorese leaving Indonesia have automatic right to Portuguese nationality and are readily accorded this status by the Portuguese authorities on request. As a consequence, they have a country which is willing to accept them. There is also the issue of return to Indonesia. As all Timorese leaving Indonesia do so legally under normal exit arrangements, the possibility of return to Indonesia is always available to them.

Timorese accepted for resettlement in Australia enter under three separate programs: the group of 625 whose admission was agreed between the Australian and Indonesian Governments in 1978, the special humanitarian program for those outside East Timor on or before 30 september 1980, and normal family reunion migration.

None of these groups is able to meet the terms of the internationally accepted refugee definitions, but nevertheless Australia has relaxed normal entry rules for the first two groups and other Timorese programs in recent years in recognition of their humanitarian claims on our resettlement resources.

East Timorese whose names appear on the list agreed between the Australian and Indonesian Governments are required to do no more than lodge an application form and satisfy normal health and character requirements. Nominations covering in excess of 2,000 East Timorese have already been sent to overseas posts for processing under the special humanitarian program. A similarly abbreviated processing regime applies to these nominees, although it is necessary for individuals to establish that they were in fact outside East Timor on or before 30 September 1980. Some family units, split between Lisbon and Jakarta, are required to complete all visa processing requirements so that entry visas can be granted to all family members at the same time. The delays resulting from these two last mentioned factors are minimal and similar to those occurring under other refugee and special humanitarian programs.

The principal causes of delays in reuniting East Timorese with their relatives in Australia are the difficulties and expenses incurred in gaining permission to leave East Timor for Jakarta and then to travel abroad. The Australian Government has on a number of occasions urged the Indonesian authorities to facilitate family reunion movement from East Timor to Australia and although the Indonesian Government has given positive assurances, the rate of movement to Australia remains slow and irregular.

In reply to the question on the number of East Timorese currently being admitted, of the agreed list total of 625 people 345 have so far arrived here, 45 of them in the 1980-81 program year. I have mentioned that nominations in favour of over 2000 East Timorese have been referred to overseas posts for action, and over 700 persons have been granted entry visas since the commencement of the program in October 1980. Remaining cases are being completed as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 May 1981 (Hansard page 1961) Senator McLaren asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: What person or body now has responsibility for recommending priorities for rural research (in view of the fact that the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension (CCRRE) has been abolished).
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Standing Committee on Agriculture, which services Australian Agricultural Council, is concerned with priorities in and development of rural research. It recently established an Advisory Committee on Priorities in Rural Research and Extension. This Committee is currently examining resources committed to research and extension with a view to providing Standing Committee with relevant advice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2243) Senator Tate asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority to private enterprise.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government's intention with regard to the sale of AWTA remains as consistently stated by the Government. The Authority is to be sold, the expectation being that it will be disposed of to a private corporate body or Foundation, designed largely by the industry itself.

The Government's decision to sell the AWTA recognises that there is no longer a necessity for the Authority to have a link with the Government. In this process however, the fundamental aim is to ensure that the AWTA, in the private sector, continues to operate in precisely the same way as it does today.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 May (Hansard, page 2340) Senator McAuliffe asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority to private enterprise.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Wool Industry Act provided that the Australian Wool Testing Authority (AWTA) has no power to hold real or personal property except monies that become payable to it. The equipment, materials and facilities used by the Authority are owned by the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) and its staff are employees of that Corporation.

The initial funds to set up the AWTA were supplied by the Commonwealth Government and were eventually repaid. Over the years the total operating surpluses generated by the Authority's activities have more or less approximated the cost value of the facilities it employs. Growers have, of course, contributed singificantly to those operating surpluses through use of AWTA services.
The proceeds of the sale of the AWTA will go to the AWC.

The Australian Wool Measurement Standards Authority, is not a statutory body but a section of the Department of Primary Industry. Its establishment was requested originally by representative wool industry organisations.

Since it was first established, its staff has been reduced as the industry gained experience with objective measurement and sale bly certificate and sample, and following the closure of two laboratories which operated in competition with the AWTA. Currently, AWMSA staff totals twelve. AWMSA continues its role in monitoring wool testing to indentify and assist in the correction of improper operating procedures and practices likely to lead to errors and the possibility of buyers being mislead in assessing the value of wools presented for sale by sample and certificate.
In the near future I will be discussing the future role of AWMSA with the Wool Council of Australia and the International Wool Textile Organisation.
